body:
Serviciability of EG  Part of Reliability, Availability, Serviciability, Performance and Functionality of large system EG(Enterprise Guide) versus full Workstation SAS

EG has it place as an excellent data farm for extracting subsets of data and a nice introduction to SAS for non-programmers  but is not an end all be all for a skilled SAS programmer, who needs more than 0.5gb ram and SSD drive speed.  

Most of the information I have on serviciability of EG is from SAS-L,
  not the commercial SAS sponsered list, and my own limited interactions.

  I submit at least one tickect every week with an EG issue.
  Most of the issues are never 'serviced' because
  they are 'unfixiable' for three reasons, issue is
  intrinsic in EG, hotfix was not installed or a more current
  SAS version is needed.

  It must be very expensive to service the large volume of EG problem tickets rather
  than the few originating from workstation or desktop SAS. The 9.4
  SAS install is only around 10gb and easily fits on a thumb drive?

  I have asked repeatedly for a summary of the one months EG tickets
  but I don't even get a written response.

  Currently my primary EG is at 9.3M2 with no plans to install 9.4.
  In August 9.3M2 will be 3 years old.

  Recent  9.3m2 29Aug2012 12.1
  Recent  9.4   10Jul2013 12.3
  Recent  9.4m1 15Dec2013 13.1
  Recent  9.4m2 05Aug2014 13.2

  I could install 9.4m2 in less than an hour, by myself on my workstation.
  Most hotfixes take less than 30 minutes. None of this requires
  IT support, but of course I do need admin priv turned on.
  I usually download the software or hot fix and unzip it.
  Then I call the help desk for a ticket, tech comes to my office clicks
  the setup.exe and run as admin, leaves my office and I send him a
  notice when the install is complete.

  The overwhelming response on the non-commercial SAS-List(SAS-L)
  is that EG is very hard to service or install. One very
  well respected advanced SAS programmer messaged that
  they never got it to work. Scheduled downtime
  of approx 30 days per year also may be an indication.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1979: Dan Bricklin and Bob Frankston, acquaintances at MIT, formed Software Arts Corporation (later renamed "VisiCorp") for the sole purpose of marketing an electronic spreadsheet that Bricklin, as the story goes, was preparing for a Harvard Business School "case study" report and had two alternatives: 1) do it by hand or 2) use a clumsy time-sharing mainframe program. Bricklin thought there must be a better way. He wanted a program where people could visualize the spreadsheet as they created it. His metaphor was "an electronic blackboard and electronic chalk in a classroom." VisiCalc - for "visible calculator" - became the first electronic calculator for the personal computer.

http://www.bricklin.com/history/0172cf00.jpg

group_name: HRSA Office of Women's Health Collaborative
body:
In August 2015, JAMA will publish a theme issue on violence and human rights with an emphasis on the causes, consequences, and management of trauma. Violence is an important cause of physical and emotional trauma, and the scope of trauma care is broad, including care for survivors of unintentional injuries as well as injuries resulting from many forms of violence. Injuries and violence cause 5.8 million deaths each year worldwide, accounting for about 10% of the world’s deaths, more than the number of deaths that result from malaria, tuberculosis, and AIDS combined.1,2 The primary causes of these 5.8 million deaths are road traffic crashes, suicide, and homicide, followed by falls, drowning, poisoning, burns, and war.2 In the United States, data from the Global Burden of Disease 2010 Study indicate the following among the leading diseases and injuries contributing to premature mortality: road injury (fifth leading cause), self-harm (sixth), and interpersonal violence (12th).3 
For the 2015 JAMA theme issue, the Journal is soliciting papers on trauma resulting from unintentional and intentional injury, from interpersonal and community-levels of violence, and from mass conflict, war, displacement, and natural disasters.  Manuscripts received by March 15, 2015, will have the best chance of consideration for publication in this theme issue. More info here:  http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleID=2084869&utm_source=Silverchair%20Information%20Systems&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=MASTER%3AJAMALatestIssueTOCNotification12%2F23%2F2014

group_name: HRSA Office of Women's Health Collaborative
body:
January is Cervical Health Awareness Month. 

Every year, approximately 12,000 women in the United States are diagnosed with cervical cancer. Thanks to screening, cervical cancer can often be found early when the chance of successful treatment is best.  The number of cases of cervical cancer and the number of deaths from cervical cancer have decreased significantly.  Under the Affordable Care Act, most health plans must cover certain preventive health services for women including Cervical Cancer screening for sexually active women. How often you should get screened for cervical cancer depends on several factors noted below:
•	If you are age 21 to 29, get a Pap test every 3 years.
•	If you are age 30 to 65:
o	Get screened every 3 years if you only have a Pap test.
o	Get screened every 5 years if you have both a Pap test and an HPV test.
o	If you are age 66 or older, ask your doctor if cervical cancer screening is recommended for you.
Women are encouraged to talk to their healthcare provider about their risk for cervical cancer.   
For more information, visit https://www.healthcare.gov/what-are-my-preventive-care-benefits/women.

That said, I think there are also frustrations folks have with eCPIC. As for data collection, I believe the only value it has if we make use of it:  if we're collecting information that doesn't result in better outcomes, we need to take a look at it. Let me commit to having a conversation with HHS' CPIC community to understand what we're collecting, how we're using it, and whether we're using the best tool...

cc: [User:6859699:lisaalsop], [User:1526826912:bethkilloran], [User:1489920514:taryncyrus]

Performance section of Reliability, Availability, Serviciability ,Performance and Functionality of EG in a large server environment.

* EG  Benchmarks for a 22gb gig23ful_main.sas7bdat;
 * done on Sunday at about midnight.

 see attachment for code and log output;

BENCHMARK

 proc sql;
     create
       table modbene_idx as
     select
      count(*) as cnt
      ,sum(n1) as sum_n1
      ,sum(n2) as sum_n2
      ,sum(n3) as sum_n3
      ,sum(n4) as sum_n4
      ,sum(n5) as sum_n5
      ,sum(n6) as sum_n6
    from
      gig23ful_main
    where
      idx1<25 and idx2<12 and idx3=3
 ;quit;


                                         EG           Workstation         Newer Wrkstion?
                               ========    ========          ============
Create data (22gb)          265                    129                     60
Sort data                         305                    181                     90
Index data                       227                    111                     55
sql (with index)                7.35                   3.78                     2
sql (without index)         32.34                 10.59                     5

SASFILE
sql (no index)                  32.34*                4.30                      2

SPDE(free with base)
SQL                                  7.35*                0.45                      0.25

GRID
Job (4 tasks)*                    231                  114                      57


Note only 10 grided jobs are allowed by my EG grid manager. A Workstation Dell dual XEON or I7 should
support seven.

Note Dell I7 Laptops support 32gb ram and 4 sata3 ports, DVD, C drive, esata on laptop and
esata on docking station.

*My workstation is an T7400(circa 2008) with 64gb ram(DDR2) and two raid 0 SSDs(sata II) arrays
of 4 disks each. You can get these off lest for about $500.

SPDE is so fast because it uses all three indexes, without SPDE SAS chooses just one index
the one with the highest cardinality. Note indexes can be slower than a table scan.
Don't use an index if pulling 15% or more from the slow EG drives.

Workstation gridding og the sums of squares for regression analysis can be extremely fast.
This is why ordinary least squares is so fast in Teradate.
Might be interesting to compare regression on workstation and Teradata.

EG is a good data farm for extrating data for the workstation to analyze.
Generally datasets <1TB can easily and inexpensively be handled on the desktop.
EG is also good as a learning tool for non-programmers.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1851: Leon Foucault proved the rotation of the Earth experimentally. He wrote in his journal that he made the discovery at 2:00 AM working with his now famous pendulum in the cellar of his house.  While it had long been known that the Earth rotates, the introduction of the Foucault pendulum in 1851 was the first simple proof of the rotation in an easy-to-see experiment. Today, Foucault pendulums are popular displays in science museums and universities.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foucault_pendulum#mediaviewer/File:Pendule_de_Foucault.jpg

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1954: Russian was translated into English by an electronic "brain" today for the first time. Brief statements about politics, law, mathematics, chemistry, metallurgy, communications, and military affairs were submitted in Russian by linguists of the Georgetown University Institute of Languages and Linguistics to the famous 701 computer of the International Business Machines Corporation. And the giant computer, within a few seconds, turned the sentences into easily readable English.

We are pleased to announce the three winning entries for the HHS VizRisk competition. VizRisk challenged data viz, public health, and design experts to create compelling visualizations of CDC’s BRFSS (Behavioral Risk Factor And Surveillance System) dataset. The visualizations are intended to offer insights not immediately accessible in typical tabular formats.

Importantly, the competition marks only the beginning of a process we hope will improve how BRFSS data is displayed and analyzed. Similarly, we hope that some of the solutions and lessons can be applied to other HHS public datasets.

Check out the winners on our site: http://www.hhsvizrisk.org/

If you have an interest in running a similar type of competition, please reach out!

Colleagues -

Secretary Burwell and I are pleased to announce the 8th round of the HHS Innovates Awards, a Departmental recognition program that celebrates you and your creative approaches to problem solving.

Between January 8 and February 27, 2015, HHS employees are invited to submit nominations for innovative solutions that they or their colleagues have developed.

We know that innovative solutions to challenges of varying sizes are put forth by staff at all levels of this Department. The HHS Innovates Awards serve as a powerful mechanism for bringing forth the best of these solutions to the attention of colleagues, Department leadership, and the public at large. In addition to the recognition that comes with receiving an Innovates Award, winners (HHS employees and Commissioned Corps only) may also receive up to $1,000, and participate in the Secretary’s Innovates Award Ceremony. The Innovates Award is also added to the recipient’s official employee personnel file. 

Secretary Burwell and I look forward to this round of the HHS Innovates Awards. To learn more about the HHS Innovates Awards program, including how to submit your innovative solution, nominate a colleague’s work, and read about the exciting program enhancements we’ve put in place this round, visit: http://hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/

Bill Corr
Deputy Secretary

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body:
Hi Debbie..... Assuming age 55 with 8 years of service you really only have 1 option....A regular separation/resignation - In this scenario your benefits work like this:
FEHB - With FEHB you must be actively enrolled for the 5 immediate years preceding your immediate retirement. Any FEHB plan counts and coverage under your federal spouses policy counts also but you must be eligible for an immediate annuity.....
Upon separation/resignation you're given a 31 day extension of health insurance coverage free of charge starting the day after you separate. Once that extension runs out you are eligible to begin enrollment in TCC (Temporary Continuation of Coverage) The catch with TCC, which is very similar to COBRA coverage for private sector employees, is the cost. TCC costs 102% of the full insurance premium. Meaning you're paying the employee share and the governments share plus a 2% admin fee. This coverage can last for up to 18 months and is paid monthly in advance so early enrollment after separating is key to avoiding back premiums that go back to the 31st day extension expiration.

FEGLI - Your coverage ends the date you separate and again you are given a 31 day extension free of charge with the opportunity to convert to an individual policy within 60 days of your separation date. Your HR office SHOULD send you a separation package or something similar to inform you of this post-employment benefit and they SHOULD sent it quickly. In my experience this not something that is not handled well in HR departments.  Persistence may be required from the employee. You will also get the conversion forms as part of your separation package.

TSP - You will lose the privilege of payroll contributions but you can keep your TSP account indefinitely. IRS rules apply to your TSP account regarding withdrawals, etc.. 

NOTE: Because you have already achieved the minimum amount of Federal service (5 years) necessary to be eligible for a retirement you can DEFER your retirement until you reach the age of 62. At age 62 you may contact OPM to activate your retirement. There will be no penalties and the retirement will be processed as if you had just retired at age 62 with 8 years of service. Benefits are not eligible for reinstatement with a deferred retirement so basically this option is good for the money portion of your retirement. Benefits will have to be obtained elsewhere.

Thank you so much - is there any difference for age 56 + and 10 years of service! I am wanting to return to Pittsburgh later this year for personal reasons and it seems federal positions are few and far between for HHS.
If I would happen to find a position with a lapse, will my benefits/seniority/time, etc continue?

Debbie sorry to butt in, but what about full-time Telework? It was recently implemented here at CMS.  I know that so far only a few people have been approved, but I think after the initial implementation, it will get opened up more.  

If that wouldn't work, maybe you could get reassigned to the Philly office (Region 3).  8 hour employees can telework 3 days per week.  I have no idea what the distance is between Philly and Pittsburgh, but it might be doable 2x a week for a couple years until you hit full retirement age.  

Just food for thought.
I am looking forward to supporting the latest HHS Ignite Boot camp.
Thanks Maria, I will consider all options! Staying on is easier than losing everything!

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body:
If your Minimum Retirement Age (MRA) is age 56 and you reach 10 years of Federal you can retire early. However, there is a age reduction of 5% for each year under age 62. So, if you left at age 56 that's 6 years away x 5% = a 30% reduction in your gross annuity for life! However, this type of retirement is considered immediate and therefore all of your benefits are transferable into retirement just like any other retiree....given that you attain minimum benefit requirements such as the 5 years rule for FEHB/FEGLI.
You can also avoid the age reduction by doing a POSTPONED retirement where you would leave Federal service now but delay receiving retirement benefits until age 62 at which time they will be reinstated as if you had just retired at age 62 with 10+ years.

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body: Yes. Any Federal service where you payed into a retirement fund is creditable toward Federal retirement and remains creditable for life. So you can take a break for any amount of time and when you come back your start where you left off in terms of Federal service credit including leave accrual categories.
So I would be approaching age 58 at the 10 years of service computation.  Good to know all the info before big decisions have to be made!

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body: If you never take a refund of the FERS retirement funds the service remains creditable for life. Otherwise you'll have to pay it back plus interest in order for the service to count.

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body: http://www.opm.gov/retirement-services/fers-information/
I would definitely defer until age 62 to minimize loss of benefits.

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body: You mean Postpone.....Deferring retirement loses the benefits. Postponement is eligible to have them reinstated. I know its confusing....took me a while to get them straight too!
Thank you - yes postpone!
I took a loan on my FERS that I am paying back so how does that impact this conversation?

sender_name: Jason Duncan, HR Benefits & Retirement Specialist
body: I think you mean a loan was taken on your TSP. To my knowledge you can only withdraw 100% from the FERS fund and that's only for broken service in the past. For TSP loans, if you do not pay the full amount of the TSP loan before retirement then the balance owed is considered a taxable distribution by the IRS and added to your gross income for the year.
Oh yes it is the TSP which I could arrange to continue to pay.

Approximately 1,000 innovators from the startup community, public sector, and corporate America will gather for two days of engaging conversations and hands on learning.

I have been working with Python, Django, the Oauth Toolkit, the Django REST Framework and the Twitter Bootstrap framework to put together a crude Proof of Concept for A BlueButton Plus Data Service for Medicare Beneficiaries. This is using fake data and data models and Oauth has been disabled in this demonstration. The focus of this proof of concept is to check out the viability of the REST Framework for creating a json and XML data service with a browsable API that follows the FHIR framework ( http://www.hl7.org/implement/standards/fhir/http.html ).

Here is a rough cut demonstration video on vimeo: 
http://vimeo.com/116348719

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1908: Lee DeForest, an American engineer and scientist with over 180 patents to his credit, broadcast a program of opera phonograph records from the Eiffel Tower in Paris. This was just an experimental stunt to approximately 50 other nearby hobbyists and not considered a public broadcast as the general public had no access to receivers at the time. But it did reach hobbyists with receivers over 500 miles away, making it the first long-distance radio transmission.

group_name: NIH IC Applications Show and Tell
body: The National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) Office of Management's Information Technology and Applications Center (ITAC), NIH Office of Chief Information Officer (OCIO) and the NIH Center for Information Technology (CIT) would like to invite the NIH community to our fifth NIH IC Applications Show & Tell on Wednesday, February 11, 2015. This event provides a venue for functional experts and IT stakeholders from across the NIH to share the tools that are working well for us, including apps our teams have bought, built, or borrowed, and to learn from the experiences of others. It's an opportunity to leverage IT investments made by others and to work together to meet common needs as good stewards of public funds.   With your contributions, presenters will offer brief demonstrations of a variety of tools that span the interests of Intramural, Extramural, Administrative and Technology programs.  Our first four events addressed a mix of functional needs each time. What:  IC Applications Show & Tell #5, a series of brief application demos to introduce the NIH community to their most prized capabilities   When: Wednesday, February 11, 2015, 9:30am to 11:30am   Where: Bldg 31 Rm. 6C6 and by webcast - register below to receive the URL and program.   To help with planning and to receive additional meeting details, please register for the event by going to https://nihshowandtell5.eventbrite.com (https://nihshowandtell5.eventbrite.com/).  Select your registration type (in-person, remote, etc.) and a quantity of “1” and click the “Register” button.   Enter your name and NIH email address and click “Complete Registration   **Webcast details will be distributed prior to the event only to those who register, along with the event guide with demo descriptions   Have a tool you're eager to demo for your peers? Want to be involved with planning future events? Join the HHS Yammer group for the event and pitch your idea there! https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/groups/nihicapplicationsshowandtell (https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/groups/nihicapplicationsshowandtell)  If you are not already using Yammer, it's easy to join with your NIH email address in "first.last@nih.gov (http://mailto:first.last@nih.gov)" form   If you have questions or would like to propose an idea directly to the Show and Tell team, email the organizers at ShowAndTell@mail.nih.gov (http://mailto:ShowAndTell@mail.nih.gov)   (http://mailto:ShowAndTell@mail.nih.gov) Individuals with disabilities who need Sign Language Interpreters and/or reasonable accommodation to participate in this event should contact Susan Haddad, NHLBI Portfolio Manager by email at susan.haddad@nih.gov (http://mailto:susan.haddad@nih.gov), telephone (301) 480-1095, and/or the Federal Relay 1-800-877-8339

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1976: Raymond Kurzweil, a pioneering scientist in artificial intelligence, and the leaders of the National Federation of the Blind unveiled the Kurzweil Reading Machine, the first text-to-speech machine. Walter Cronkite used it to deliver his signature sign-off, “And that’s the way it was, January 13, 1976.” Kurzweil had appeared on Steve Allen’s “I’ve Got a Secret” television show as a high school student back in 1965, when he had already invented a computer capable of composing music.

On the last Cohort 3 Conference Call we discussed the idea of a Developer Camp at the Health Data Palooza in June. The rough draft proposal is uploaded here: https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/29410552

I welcome any improvements. The idea is for a 2-day learning camp about BlueButton and other RESTAPIs being made available by HHS. The event would happen before or after the Health Data Palooza in June 2015.

An idea for a panel session at Health Data Palooza: 
Proposals are due by Jan 23rd.

Panel Title: 
Health Data: Unleashed by the Patient for the Patient

Panel Summary:

Bringing together a panel of speakers from the ONC, CMS, the VA and Industry to present the progress made in creating a Health Data Service for patients and consumers that enables them to connect their data to applications and services that help to improve their health and well being. This panel will also address the benefits that accrue to other Health Care stakeholders by the patient and consumer being able to act as a hub for their health data.


The ask: 
Suggestions for participant panelists from across HHS/VA or elsewhere?
Add bullet points for topics to be addressed by the panel.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: In HAB, we have Cross-Part Meetings in which POs from different divisions but who share a geographic region across HAB meet to discuss their grantees. These meeting help us to create a cohesive system of care and minimize duplication of services across programs. During these meetings we often share budgets, data reports, monitoring updates, site visit reports, quality management reports, technical asistance resources and best practices. The groups meet a minimum of once a quarter but many meet more frequently. These meetings provide an opportunity for POs to share valuable information and coordinate across divisions.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 2005: The European Space Agency's Huygens Probe was delivered to Titan, Saturn’s largest moon, by the Cassini Orbiter after a dormant interplanetary journey of 6.7 years - although Huygens was activated every six months for health checks. It was the first landing in the outer solar system, and the furthest from Earth.

body:
Great job on the presentation:  Some ideas for focusing the description of what you are delivering:
Goal: efficient risk-based investigator assignment
Target customer: supervisors of field food investigators
Value Proposition: streamlined, transparent decisions for assigning investigators based on experience, schedule and geography
Key Differentiation: risk-based assignment of investigators that leverages investigators preferences
Benefits: resource decisions leading to higher quality investigations, higher investigator job satisfaction, more efficient use of investigator resources

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 2001: Wikipedia, the free Wiki content encyclopedia, went online as a feeder project for Nupedia, an expert-written online encyclopedia. Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger launched Wikipedia; Sanger coined its name, a portmanteau of wiki (from the Hawaiian word for "quick") and encyclopedia. Although Wikipedia's content was initially only in English, it quickly became multilingual, through the launch of versions in different languages.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/80/Wikipedia-logo-v2.svg

cc: [User:1533055272:yvettewaples], [User:1533055271:calebbriggs]

yeah, there's a few tricky things--but it won't take long to get the hang of it.  

I REALLY like the live-editing and document management on here.  Having closed groups for private matters is also great too.  One trick I really like using is the "notes" in a group...you can use it like a file folder (since folders aren't an option on here).  For example, we had a director meeting coming up so I made a note with the agenda, and hyper-linked all the attachments so people could find everything in one place.

The whole thing is pretty confusing up front, but in a week or so you can usually figure it out.

I found this article on employee engagement to be pretty interesting.  Essentially is surmises that when we are examining the challenge of employee engagement we aren't considering the whole employee in the life/world they live in. It suggests that our strategies - such as change management need to consider and could benefit from understanding the "whole self" of employees - otherwise strategies could miss the mark.  For example, when considering where employees spent their energy outside of work — the external self portion of the model [the whole self model] they found - "Without fail, over 90% of respondents cited individual activities: cooking, running, knitting, cycling, reading. Outside of family time, few engaged in collaborative, group-minded activities, or really wanted to. Combine this with their roles as individual contributors during the workday and it’s clear why adapting to a more collaborative workplace wasn’t easy or comfortable for them." - https://hbr.org/2015/01/employee-engagement-depends-on-what-happens-outside-of-the-office

Our office ran into a problem with the latest OPM "Optional Telework" day. Some of us didn't have office laptops at home and we had a need to send out an email that needed to have some photos and hyperlinks embedded into the body of the email. The Webmail option does not give us full email functionality so we needed to get into the full Outlook program. 

After two phone calls to the ITIO Help Desk, I was finally able to log into the VPN and the server site for my virtual network. But I ran into two problems. 

1) I had to go get an outdated laptop running an old version of Internet Explorer 9 and outdated virus definitions in order to log on. If we can only log onto the server network through an older version of IE, where can we go to download it? I tried the Microsoft site, but it only listed "IE 9 for IT Professionals and Developers--Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008." If we have to use IE 9, can't HHS provide a site we can go to and download it?

2) I was told to keep all of my files on my laptop hard drive because we don't have the space to store them on servers. I've been unofficially told to get an external device to back up files to, but we don't have the permissions to set auto backups to anything. 

Suggestions? Recommendations?

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1986: The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) met for the first time in San Diego, California with 21 participants. The IETF has published more than 4,500 documents since then, called RFCs, that describe standards for the fundamental technologies and widely used services on today's global Internet. These include the email people use every day around the world, and the TCP/IP protocol suite, which is the foundation for Internet communications.

How to dramatically reduce the times for EG table scans

see attached upload(utl_sqz.sas) for cleaner view. Would like to use a fixed font in Yammer. Guttenberg where are you.

In the example here I reduced the wall clock time for a full table scan of
3,000,000 records from 9.78 seconds to 1.13 seconds.
This will scale to minutes, hours, days.

How I did it

   1. Reduced the record length from 306 to 168 bytes. As a side benefit
      Dollar sums should be more accurate.

   2. Turned compression off, compression increases the size of the 168
      byte dataset.

   3. Multiplied the dollar and cents by 100 to get pennies and
      rounded. Fractions of a cent are considered to be bad data.
      This reduced lengths from 8 to 5 or even 4 bytes without loss.

   4. Ran my utl_optlen macro, attached, which builds a length statement
      with lengths long enough to represent all the data exactly.

* note you need to use a picture format or convert pennies to
  Dollars by dividing by 100 in your final step.

I find that most of my adhoc queries of large SAS datsets do not involve
fat variables like name, address or county name, If this is the case
then sometimes you can reduce the wall clock time for an EG job by
a factor of 10 with lower cpu utilization. This allows higher
muti-programming levels with the same CPU load. All IT cares about
is CPU utilization.

/*
* original non optimised data run in EG;
proc sql;
   create
     table fultym(compress=binary) as
   select
     *
   from
     tstdat
   where
     drg1='ABCDE'
;quit;

/*
NOTE: PROCEDURE SQL used (Total process time):
      real time           9.78 seconds
      user cpu time       8.69 seconds
      system cpu time     1.08 seconds
      memory              1018.46k
      OS Memory           15400.00k
      Timestamp           01/19/2015 09:44:19 PM
      Page Faults                       1
      Page Reclaims                     0
      Page Swaps                        0
      Voluntary Context Switches        41
      Involuntary Context Switches      160
      Block Input Operations            0
     Block Output Operations
*/

* optimised data run in EG;
* real time is clock time;

proc sql;
   create
     table hlftym(compress=no) as
   select
     *
   from
     tstdatpnyxpn
   where
     drg1='ABCDE'
;quit;

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) issued the following operating status update for Wednesday, January 21, 2015:  FEDERAL OFFICES ARE OPEN WITH OPTION FOR UNSCHEDULED LEAVE OR UNSCHEDULED TELEWORK (D.C. METRO AREA).  What the OPM status means for NIH:
  
NIH facilities (Campus and leased offices) in Montgomery County, Maryland are OPEN, however, employees have the following options:  
 
Emergency employees (Tier I) report for duty onsite and on time, as scheduled, and remain for the duration of their tours of duty unless otherwise directed by their supervisor.
 
Non-emergency employees/teleworkers (Tier II) who choose not to report to their worksite may request unscheduled telework for the entire workday, request unscheduled leave, or a combination of both.  Those regularly scheduled to telework should do so for the entire workday.  Tier II employees reporting to the office are expected to begin work on time.
 
Non-emergency employees/non-teleworkers (Tier III) report to their worksites as scheduled or contact their supervisors to request (1) unscheduled leave; (2) LWOP; (3) to change their regular day off under a compressed work schedule; or (4) to rearrange their work hours if on a flexible work schedule.
 
Campus/NIH Leased Facilities Access: During and after this weather event, there may be limited access to the NIH campus/leased facilities, and local/regional issues may preclude safe commuting.  Safety of our employees is our first priority.   
 
ITAS: Employees are reminded that regular and ad hoc telework must be recorded in ITAS.  
 
Helpful Links:
NIH OHR Operating Status Page: http://hr.od.nih.gov/workingatnih/operatingstatus/default.htm
OPM Operating Status Page: http://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/snow-dismissal-procedures/current-status/ 
Resource for Operating Statuses outside of the DMV area: http://hr.od.nih.gov/workingatnih/operatingstatus/resources.htm 
AlertNIH: http://www.alert.nih.gov

The Federal-wide Buyers Club inaugural conference supporting innovative acquisitions will feature both individual speakers as well as a moderated panel to inform, inspire, and encourage the use of innovative acquisition methods necessary to successfully meet federal IT service needs, though many of the methods may be applicable to non-IT service acquisitions.     The conference will feature both subject matter expert speakers and a moderated panel on the following innovative acquisition methods and issues: 
  #Incentive Prize Tools and the America COMPETES Act
  #Milestone-based Contracting
  #Staged Contracting
  #CrowdSourcing Methods
  #Rapid Technology Prototyping
  #Other Transaction Authority (where permissable)
  #Broad Agency Announcements (BAAs) and Open BAA's
  #Agile vs. Waterfall Implementation Methods
  #HHS Buyers Club Community of Practice and Model
  #U.S. Digital Service's Model
  #GSA's 18F Digital Consulting Program and Model
  #Digital Service Playbook, TechFAR Handbook, and Innovative Contracting Case Studies, among other best practices, guidance, and resources.

Thanks for all the online and offline construtive criticism, I think the code is much better now,
After futher offline communications with SAS_L, I implemented most of the suggestions.

1. Code should handle thousands of variables (macvar 64k limit was restricting?)
2. No global variable, user supplies an input and output dataset
3. Does not use the slow sashelp dictionaries, uses proc contents
4. Order of the variables remains the same as input dataset
5. Much more error checking, checks for empty and missing input datasets
6. Handles completely missing variables, previous code would try to set length to 0
for entirely missing variables.

see attached file utl_optlen

(Policy Analyst) has [Tag:80903:joined] the U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services (HHS) network. Take a moment to welcome Stuart.

Dr. Morrison's observations are clear.  Unfortunately, he offers no solutions or policy alternatives to address the obvious and unintended consequences of these changes.  The healthcare industry is going through structural realignment.  Disruptive innovations are on the horizon to be fueled by the use of technology by consumers.  These will be exciting and changing times.

I believe that the mission we are on to put information in the hands of Consumers (and by extension) the apps and services they trust is what will drive the most change in the industry. Providers, payers etc. will have to embrace the consumer as a true peer since they will increasingly hold the most complete and current view of their health status,
Yammeer

Hi everyone,
[User:1499559954:ixj5] kindly shared information about a really itneresting (free) conference coming up in February on innovative federal procurement. Mark will join our Monday teleconference and will be able to provide more information about the event to those who are interested.


The Office of Federal Procurement Policy, the Federal-Wide Buyer’s Club, the HHS’ Buyers Club, and GSA’s 18F Program invite you to the Inaugural Conference for Innovative Acquisitions.  This is an event you don’t want to miss!  It is scheduled for Wednesday, February 18, 2015 from 8 AM to 1:00 PM in the GSA Auditorium at GSA HQ, 1800 F Street, NW.  We encourage wide dissemination of this invitation and hope you and your staffs and other colleagues in your agency can attend.  Do you have a team beginning planning for an upcoming acquisition?  Bring them all – contracting officer, program manager, contracting officer’s representative, attorney, budget analyst, among others - to learn some innovative strategies to consider.  The event is free and you can register athttps://www.eventbrite.com/e/federal-wide-buyers-club-inaugural-conference-for-innovative-acquisitions-tickets-15233421574?ref=estw  We look forward to seeing you there!  

More information on the event:
The Federal-wide Buyers Club inaugural conference supporting innovative acquisitions will feature both individual speakers as well as a moderated panel to inform, inspire, and encourage the use of innovative acquisition methods necessary to successfully meet federal IT service needs, though many of the methods may be applicable to non-IT service acquisitions.
 
The conference will feature both subject matter expert speakers and a moderated panel on the following innovative acquisition methods and issues:
•        Incentive Prize Tools and the America COMPETES Act
•        Milestone-based Contracting
•        Staged Contracting
•        CrowdSourcing Methods
•        Rapid Technology Prototyping
•        Other Transaction Authority (where permissable)
•        Broad Agency Announcements (BAAs) and Open BAAs
•        Agile vs. Waterfall Implementation Methods
•        HHS Buyers Club Community of Practice and Model
•        U.S. Digital Service's Model
•        GSA's 18F Digital Consulting Program and Model
•        Digital Service Playbook, TechFAR Handbook, and Innovative Contracting Case Studies, among other best practices, guidance, and resources.
An agenda will be posted prior to the meeting.

Thoughts about SAS/WPS/R/Python

http://www.pcworld.com/article/2874832/microsoft-to-acquire-r-language-powerhouse-revolution-analytics.html

http://tinyurl.com/mo5leyf

“R is one of the most widely used programming languages specifically designed for statistical computing and predictive analytics, alongside SAS, MatLab, Mathematica and a number of Python libraries. Microsoft will use the software to offer cloud services and on premise applications for its customers to undertake big data-style analysis”.

SAS and WPS(SAS clone) are tightly integrated with R, R can read and write SAS datasets when SAS m IML is installed, although it requires full SAS not EG SAS?
WPS has PROC R.

WPS may become another future key product. SAS is pricing itself out of the workstation/desktop/laptop unbundled market.

Gartner had some positive comments about WPS(SAS clone) recently. 

Full WPS-SAS($1,900? unbundled full) SAS ($13,000? first year unbundled full SAS with Base/Stat/Graph/Access Oracle on power workstation).  Pricing is approx, very had to get exact costs.

SAS bundling cannot be understood. unbundled means you pay fro each product or you buy some products in different years.

I know SAS is very concerned about R,  WPS and Python with good reason.

Integration is the answer not parochialism

Topic:  Executive Presentations: How To Be Well Spoken

When:   Wednesday, February 4, 2015

Where:  Masur Auditorium, Building 10   

Time:   12:30 p.m. - 1:30 p.m.

About The Speaker:

A nationally recognized professional speaker, Chris Jahnke founded her firm Positive Communications to help people from all walks of life stand and deliver before audiences large and small.  

Chris works with senior leaders in business, government, and the nonprofit sector.  Executives at companies as diverse as Avon, NASCAR, National Geographic, and Northrop Grumman have turned to Chris for presentation training.  She provides strategic guidance to leading nonprofits, including: Annie E. Casey Foundation; Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation; Cornell University; League of Conservation Voters; Nuclear Threat Initiative; Union of Concerned Scientists; United Nations Population Fund; World Wildlife Fund; and many more.  Chris prepped First Lady Michelle Obama for her first international speech and provided speaker training to Hillary Clinton's Presidential Campaign.  

She has coached more women candidates and elected officials than any other trainer.  She is the author of The Well-Spoken Woman: Your Guide to Looking and Sounding Your Best.

Other Information:

To access this event by videocast, please visit www.videocast.nih.gov.   This highly interactive session will help you articulate your expertise with polish and credibility.  The skill-building exercises will help you refine your signature speaking style and project with confidence.

This event is in partnership with Office of Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (EDI) and Asian Pacific American Organization (APAO).

Sign Language Interpreters will be provided.  Individuals with disabilities who need reasonable accommodation to participate in this event should contact Tyrone Banks, Strategist, Asian American and Pacific Islander Portfolio, Office of Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion, Bankstc@mail.nih.gov or 301-451-9692, and/or the Federal Relay (1-800-877-8339).

group_name: Indian Health Service Division of Environmental Health Services
body:
$2 billion in funds headed for cleanups in Nevada and on the Navajo Nation from historic Anadarko settlement with U.S. EPA, States
 
Release Date: 01/23/2015
Contacts: Margot Perez-Sullivan, perezsullivan.margot@epa.gov, 415-947-4149 or Suzanne Skadowski, skadowski.suzanne@epa.gov, 415-972-3165
SAN FRANCISCO – Today, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice announced the settlement reached with Anadarko and Kerr-McGee is now final, allowing funds to be disbursed for cleanups across the country. 
 
The settlement secures payments of $5.15 billion to resolve claims that the defendants fraudulently transferred assets in part to evade their liability for contamination at toxic sites around the country. Of this total, approximately $4.4 billion will be used to clean the environment. This is the largest sum ever awarded in this type of a bankruptcy-related environmental settlement with the federal government. 
 
“Communities from the Navajo Nation to Henderson, Nevada are finally getting the funding needed to take crucial steps toward cleaning up toxic legacies that pollute their environment,” said Jared Blumenfeld, EPA’s Regional Administrator for the Pacific Southwest. “After decades of trying to avoid their environmental responsibilities, Anadarko is today paying billions of dollars to immediately fund these and other critical environmental cleanups.”
 
“This recovery will lead to cleanups across the country that will undo lasting damage to the environment, including contamination of tribal lands, by Kerr-McGee’s businesses,” said John C. Cruden, Assistant Attorney General for the Justice Department’s Environment and Natural Resources Division. “This result emphatically demonstrates the Justice Department’s commitment to environmental justice for all Americans, and it fulfills the Department’s promise to hold accountable those who pollute and those who try to foist their responsibility for cleanup on the American taxpayer.” 
 
An estimated $1.1 billion will be paid to a trust responsible for cleaning up a former chemical manufacturing site in Nevada that led to perchlorate contamination in Lake Mead. The site is located within the Black Mountain Industrial complex near Henderson, Nev. Fifty to 100 pounds of perchlorate are still seeping into Lake Mead every day, and the funds will allow that state’s Department of Environmental Protection to clean up the remaining underground sources of contamination.
 
The Henderson site is the largest perchlorate groundwater plume in the country. By way of the Las Vegas Wash, the plume has contaminated Lake Mead, which feeds into the Colorado River, a major source of drinking water in the Southwest. Perchlorate, a component in rocket fuel and fireworks, can interfere with the production of thyroid hormones, which are needed for prenatal and postnatal growth and development, as well as for normal metabolism and mental function in adults.
 
More than $985 million is expected to be paid to the U.S. EPA to fund the cleanup of approximately 50 abandoned uranium mines in and around the Navajo Nation, where radioactive waste remains from cold-war era Kerr-McGee mining operations.  Additionally, the Navajo Nation is expected to receive more than $43 million to address radioactive waste left at the former Kerr-McGee uranium mill in Shiprock, New Mex. The EPA is currently meeting with the Navajo Nation and the State of New Mexico to plan work to occur there later in 2015.
 
Kerr-McGee mined over 7 million tons of ore on or near the Navajo Nation from the late 1940s through the 1960s in the Lukachukai area, and from the 1950s to the 1980s in the Eastern and Ambrosia Lake areas. The Kerr-McGee Corp. was founded in 1929 as an energy company involved with oil and gas exploration and production, and uranium mining.  The company left abandoned uranium mine sites, including contaminated waste rock piles, in the Lukachukai Mountains of Arizona, the Eastern Agency of the Navajo Nation in New Mexico, and in the Ambrosia Lake/Grants Mining District of New Mexico. 
 
Exposure to uranium and other radioactive elements in soil, dust, air, groundwater and surface water, including waste rock piles and materials used in building structures, poses risks to human health.
 
In addition to the cleanups in Nevada and on the Navajo Nation, funds are also starting to flow to cleanups across the nation, including sites in Jacksonville, Florida, West Chicago, Illinois, Columbus, Mississippi, and Navassa, North Carolina.
 
On April 3, 2014, the United States Department of Justice announced this settlement, which was then subject to a period of public comment and judicial approval.  After considering comments from the public, the United States sought approval of the settlement, and on November 10, 2014, the district court approved the agreement as “fair and reasonable.”  The deadline for any appeals from the district court’s decision passed on January 20, 2015, without any appeals having been taken.

group_name: Indian Health Service Division of Environmental Health Services
body:
Training opportunity available in injury prevention:
(from Hillary Strayer, Senior Specialist in Injury Prevention)
Greetings!

Registration for the IHS Level 2 Intermediate Injury Prevention training to be held in Anchorage Tuesday March 24 through Friday, March 27 is now open. I have attached a brochure that gives more information about the course.

If you are planning to attend, please register as soon as is convenient so we can get an idea of class size and adjust our preparations accordingly.
Please complete both the attached registration form (for ANTHC’s records) and the form on the IHS Environmental Health Support Center website, http://www.ihs.gov/EHSCT/index.cfm?module=class&clID=1697&qs=module=classes&catID=5 (to inform IHS who is taking the course and give them information to generate the CEU forms).

The main trainers for this course will be me (Hillary) and Rob Morones from the IHS Phoenix office who has led many of these trainings in the past. I have attached bio’s of the other instructions who will be involved, and the course agenda as it now stands.

Please share information about this course with other groups at your organizations: Environmental Health Officers, PHNs, CHA’s, CHRs (or their equivalent) and many other job categories have participated in this training.  For this Level 2 course, we are NOT requiring the introductory course (Level 1) as a pre-requisite: anyone may attend.

If you have any questions about the course, feel free to get in touch with me.

Hillary

Hillary

Hillary Strayer
Senior Specialist, Injury Prevention Program

Alaska Native Tribal Health Consortium
Division of Community Health Services
3900 Ambassador Drive, Suite 401
Anchorage, AK  99508
Ph: 907-729-3513
Fx: 907-729-3652

UPCOMING EVENT ON FEB 10:  HHS INNOVATES YAM JAM

We invite you to join us for a special virtual town hall event on February 10 from 2-3 PM ET in the HHS IDEA Lab Yammer Group. This is a great opportunity to chat virtually with members of the Awards Committee and hear from colleagues who have won Innovates Awards. Here is the information I received in the HHS 508 Yammer group about using timelines for 508 Power Points.

cc: [User:1489920687:janetdudrick], [User:1489964939:martharandazzo], [User:1489920308:jonmathis], [User:1489919390:kristeenasigler]

Consider whether you'll be only presenting the Powerpoitn in a live session, and so is it accessible to those looking at it (w/low vision, color blind, etc.), and/or whether you're distributing it and need for it to be accessible also to those listening to it (i.e, with full alt-text).

One acceptable approach is to use a modest Alt-Text for the image and then put a true, text equivalent into the Notes field.  Something like, This timeline indicates OM's progress in achieving X from 2005 to 2015, with an X % improvement spiking between 2007 and 2009.  For full details and data, see the Notes field below.

This way, your alt-text is the take-home message that you want everyone to get.  The additional content/background information is presented separately, as a footnote of sorts.  Use the alt-text just to deliver The Message or The Point you're trying to convey.

FYI about this free webinar!  Caring Economics is a fascinating and truly impactful movement...I'd love to start an informal discussion group of federal staff interested in exploring ways we can incorporate the work of Riane Eisler into our work...let me know if you're interested!!!

Learn about the Caring Economy movement

We all know the profound impact that care and care giving work have on human development and well-being, but in order to shift our patterns of investment, we must also be able to show the value of care in economic terms.
 
The Caring Economy Starter Course
Wednesday, February 4, 2015 11am Pacific 
REGISTER
The Caring Economy Starter Course is a free 60 minute webinar with Riane Eisler that introduces the Caring Economy Campaign and shows how you can be a part of a growing movement to finally make visible the dollars-and-cents value of the work of care and caregiving that forms the essential foundation of our collective prosperity.

•	What is a Caring Economy? 3 essential components

Good Question!  Because Microsoft is marketed to a wider audience and not just the US Federal government, their Accessibility Checker tests for a reasonable level of accessibility.  It does not reach the level of Section 508 conformance for documents or electronic files (depending on what it is you're specifically working on).  Using MS's Checker (available for Word, PowerPoint, and Excel) is an excellent start, but no, it doesn't reach the same technical level as Section 508's success criteria or HHS's standards for Section 508.

It IS certainly an excellent start!

Once you've run the Accessibility Checker, still refer back to the HHS checklists: http://www.hhs.gov/web/508/accessiblefiles/checklists.html

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Follow Up from Yam Jam - 
Question - In the role of the PO what is the change in the IDC?

Answer - IDC stands for Indirect Cost Rate.
In the HHS codification of the Uniform Guidance Indirect Cost Rates may be found in Subpart E - Cost Principles (Section 45 CFR 75.414).  Information is also available in the Appendices in the Uniform Guidance, but 75.414 is the primary location.

Please note - IDC may also be referred to as F&A (Facilities and Administration) costs.

The PO should be aware of the following changes re: IDC (F&A):
1) The negoticated ICD rate must be accepted by HRSA.  The exception is when the programmatic statute or regulation requires a specific IDC rate reimbursement (e.g. a 'cap' on IDC that may be applied to a particular program).

2)  IDC must be included in the FOA.  The HHS FOA Template includes language for programs to include any statutory/regulatory limitations to IDC.

3) NEW applicants, may elect to charge a de minimis IDC rate of 10%

4) Existing applicants with a current negotiated IDC rate may apply for a one-time extension for up to four (4) years.  Grantees may not request a rate review until the extesion period ends.  This will allow grantees that may have an expiring IDC rate time to re-apply/re-negotiate their IDC without interrupting their current award.

Kudos to USPHS! I had the misfortune of having to take one of my kids to the emergency room at Ft. Belvoir this weekend and she needed to see a specialist. The care that the military gave us was very much below the standards anyone should endure, and they heard about it! Fortunately, and to my surprise, the specialist who ended up taking care of us was from the USPHS! He was absolutely amazing. I've never had to work closely with any Public Health Service members until now so I had no experience to draw from. I have a new found respect for you all after my experience with Lt. Hill!

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Follow Up Question from Yam Jam:
It is my understanding that HRSA/HHS is requesting a waiver for the training grants, can you tell us about that?

Answer: 
Both applicants and HRSA staff should follow the guidance provided in the FOAs for training programs.

HRSA is very mindful of the requirements in the Uniform Guidance.  During this period of transition, HRSA is researching the regulatory direction provided in the Uniform Guidance.

If there are any changes from the guidance provided in HRSA FOAs for training programs, HRSA will notify our constituent communities immediately and provide additional direction. 

PLEASE NOTE - HRSA is working as part of a team with HHS and several other OPDIVs to assess our ability to continue to apply an IDC cap in our training programs.  This assessement will require review and approval by OMB.  The bureaus/offices with training programs will be informed immediately when there is additional guidance/direction from HHS or OMB.  As the assessment and OMB review are in progress; information regarding a 'waiver' is not for public/external communications.

body:
Follow up from the Yam Jam - 
Question: Are there new rules governing the implications for late A-133 audit reports?

Answer - 
The auditing reporting requirements will no longer be referred to as the "A-133" reports as they will now be referred to as "Single Audits."  

"A-133" was the number associated with the old OMB Circular that has been superceded by the Uniform Guidance.

All auditing requirements are now included in section Subpart F - Audit Requirements - starting in section 45 CFR 75.500, and the remedies for non compliance are found in 45 CFR 75.371.

body:
Yam Jam Follow Up

Question: 
I’ve heard that cost principles for hospitals were NOT finalized in the uniform guidance. Is that correct?

Answer: 
The Uniform Guidance does not include cost principles for hospitals.  The cost principles for hospitals may be found at 45 CFR 74 Appendix E.  

Please note the administrative and audit requirements in the uniform guidance are applicable to hospitals.

As well, 45 CFR 75 (the HHS codification of the Uniform Guidance) includes an appendix titled “Appendix IX, Principles for Determining Costs Applicable to Research and Development Under Grants and Contracts with Hospitals.”

body: An enhancement was made to EHB late last year to improve access for HRSA users to Division of Financial Integrity (DFI) products.  Specifically, a DFI Institution Folder has been added to EHB and this will serve as the central repository for viewing all the documents/products produced by DFI in the context of an institution.  They include the Financial Assessment, Audit Findings and Resolution and Special reviews (including Site Visits) performed by DFI.  The DFI Folder is located in EHB by following these steps:   Click on the Folders tab in EHB.  One of the options is DFI Institution Folder.

February is Earthquake Awareness Month: 

An earthquake is a sudden, rapid shaking of the earth caused by the breaking and shifting of rock beneath the earth’s surface. Earthquakes strike suddenly, without warning, and they can occur at any time of the year, day or night. Forty-five states and territories in the United States are at moderate to very high risk of earthquakes, and they are located in every region of the country.  

If an earthquake were to occur, in MOST situations, you will reduce your chance of injury if you:
•	DROP down onto your hands and knees. This position protects you from falling but allows you to still move if necessary. 
•	COVER your head and neck (and your entire body if possible) under a sturdy table or desk. If there is no shelter nearby, only then should you get down near an interior wall (or next to low-lying furniture that won't fall on you), and cover your head and neck with your arms and hands. 
•	HOLD on to your shelter (or to your head and neck) until the shaking stops. Be prepared to move with your shelter if the shaking shifts it around.

For additional information: FEMA offers online training on Earthquake Basics called FEMA Independent Study (IS) – 325. The training can be accessed by clicking here. Following course completion, you will have the opportunity to print your FEMA IS - 325 certificate.
Employees with Disabilities: The Earthquake Country Alliance offers advice on how to better prepare and survive an earthquake. Please access the Earthquake Preparedness Guide for People with Disabilities for additional information. Contact Occupant Emergency at 410.786.3223.

In this week's "YPN Tips for a Positive Work Environment":

1. STAND UP for yourself! The Alternative Dispute Resolution Team at CDC is here to help you through conflict. Fellows & Contractors may also have access to this resource. 

2. KNOW what’s expected of you and be FLEXIBLE with management styles. 

3. EXERCISE the 3:1 rule. Identify 3 positive feelings to every 1 negative feeling you have about your job and/or environment. 

4. In RESOLVING a conflict, a Mediator is always there as a neutral party. You can seek mediation solely or have present parties with whom you are experiencing conflict. 

5. You can BECOME a mediator using your ILA Funds. Contact Dana Williams at gwj5@cdc.gov for more information! 


Tips derived from the webinar, "How to Create a Positive Work Environment"

YPN would like to thank everyone who came out to support and donate to our "Brunch for a Cause". The event was a success with over 30 people. Café 458 broke a record for number of attendees on any given Sunday. 

All of the proceeds for brunch, including tips, went to support the Atlanta Center for Self Sufficiency, a non-profit agency whose mission is to help homeless men and women achieve self-sufficiency. We also donated approximately 100 professional clothing items and shoes, which will be distributed for job interviews and/or for work attire. 

If you're interested in supporting YPN's efforts in giving back to the community or have ideas on ways we can contribute to the local community, please contact Beza Ayalew at ybp2@cdc.gov

I have been looking at OAuth as part of a FHIR-based API for BlueButton.  This leads me down a rabbit hole...

OAuth requires a process for Developers to get Authorization credentials for their App so that Beneficiaries can connect their data to the app....

So this needs a framework for Developers to sign up and obtain those credentials....

So this in turn needs some type of Developer Agreement or Terms of Use...

This is all standard stuff in the world of the Internet where numerous platforms offer OAuth connections for consumers to connect apps together. So after some research I looked at various "Terms of Use" and decided that a BlueButton Developer Terms of Use document might look a lot like something that LinkedIn has used...

So here is a first draft of a "Developer Code of Honor"

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1W8EKXLHlcfQyM54bpkRK-C3kSY8kWBzvLpvCO_ApsbQ/edit?usp=sharing
 
I am not a lawyer and welcome any comments and advice.

Access and communicate on Yammer through email   It is now easier to connect Yammer and emails!  Unlock all that great information stuck in email and share it on Yammer!  Just scroll down to the right side of any group to "Access Options" and click on "Post to this group by email" or right click and copy the email.  Save your group Yammer email as a contact and you can post on Yammer via email without leaving Outlook. (See attached screenshot) 
  #Users can now email to Yammer, and specific Yammer groups.
  #When you forward an email into Yammer attachments show up, and the entire email shows up. 
  #Users can reply to a Yammer post via email.  Group Search  Group Search allows users to search for conversations and content within a specific Yammer group, directly from the group's description box. (See attached screenshot)

•	Can anyone at HHS participate in this program?
you can check out the hhs innovates website under the Overview Tab:  http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/

Yes!  Any employee or Commissioned Corps member can submit an entry.  Typically, there are a number of people highlighted as part of the team.  Team members can include contractors, as well as non-HHS employees (including those from other government agencies, the private sector, or the public sector).  In addition, all employees are eligible to nominate their colleagues to apply, or to vote during the employee voting, which will occur in May.
What kinds of resources do you offer for prospective applicants?

We have a number of terrific resources to assist prospective applicants in putting together the strongest application possible.  These include:  1) Agency points-of-contact from the OPDIVS and STAFFDIVS who can speak with applicants in more depth about their entry; 2) Innovates Mentors who are past winners, and can provide peer-to-peer counseling and advice on how they put together winning applications.  Prospective applicants can also review the past winning projects on the HHS IDEA Lab Gallery or review the HHS Innovates Webinar in which we highlighted the advice of past winners and committee members.  More information can be found at: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/#tab-1418077115791-5-1
•	I want to talk with someone about my entry.  Who can I speak with?

Hi Sandra! You can talk to your Agency Point of Contact or a past winner (also called Innovates Mentors) about yoru entry. Check out the Innovates website, under the More information tab: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/
[User:1510928495:mareyes]
I understand that there is employee voting.  What is that about, and who gets to participate?

To be eligible for this award, the innovation must have been piloted in some way.  Employees can resubmit innovations that were submitted in prior round (as long as there is something new to how they were written or new information).

Employee voting, which will occur May 4-15, is an opportunity for us to showcase the top innovations submitted this round.  We will invite all employees across the Department to review the innovations and select their favorite.  The innovation that receives the highest number of employee votes will be considered the “Employee’s Pick.”  Employee voting is a great way to learn about new innovations happening at HHS.

There are multiple levels of review for the Innovates Awards.   There are:  1) Agency review 2) Committee Review 3) Selection of the Employee Pick and Secretary’s Pick.  You can learn more about the evaluation process at http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/#tab-1418076912773-3-2
how is innovation defined for the purposes of hhs innovates?

Hi Sandy! For this awards program, an innovation is defined as the introduction of something entirely new (e.g., a product, process, system, service, or business model) or an unusual application of an existing product, process, system or service in a manner that improves an operating division’s or HHS’s ability to accomplish its mission. The innovation can be executed within the United States, or abroad, provided it is relevant to the mission of HHS or an operating division.

Insights into a SAS dataset

see files
      oto_voodoo.sas   Tool with sample data;
      oto_zipcode.txt  Output (sashelp.zipcode)
      zipcode_summary.txt

Probably will not run in EG due to less than 1gb ram.
  
  Be careful setting maxvar and maxval, espcially with all posible pairings of variables.

  
Here is what the tool does

1.   Dataset level summary -- ie number of obs, variable types, static data
2.   Cardinality page  (primary keys, codes/decodes  number of unique
     values for every variable - EG fails here)
3.   Complete frequency for all variables numeric and character with less
     than 200 levels
4.   For variables with over 200 levels top 100 most frequent and bottom
     100 least frequent
     Least frequent are the more interesting cases.
5.   Proc means on all numeric variables
6.   Proc univariate on all numeric variables
7.   Special datetime  analysis
9.   Histograms on all variables with less than 200 levels
10.  Proc contents
11.  Frequency of all numeric variables Missing, negative, zero and positive
12.  Duplicates on single or compound key. Output printed vertically for
     easy comparison
13.  Cross tabs of every variable with every other variable top 16 levels
     (if selecetd)
14.  You can also selecet one variable to cross tab with all other variables
     max top 16 levels
16.  Maximum and minimum lengths to hold all numeric and character variables
     exactly (optimize)
17.  Correlation of all pairs of numeric variables sorted by largest
    correlation to lowest.
18.  Nice display of max and mins for numeric and character in one table
19.  List of identical columns ie date and date1 have equal values on all
     observations
19   One to Many, Many to One, One to Many and Many to Many
20   Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel Statistics  
     Measure of the 'correlation' between two categorical(nominal Variables)
     * need to present as a list strongest to weakest
20   Printout of first 20, middle 20 and last 20 observations.

I ran it on SASHELP.ZIPCODES add a few variables to highlight some of the items above

Here are some of the intersting discoveries

1.  NO need for PONAME and CITY - They are exact duplicates? (note same number unique vals is also a tipoff)
2.  ZIP is the primary key
3.  Using optimum lengths reduces the size of the dataset by 72 bytes (fat variables should be codes)
4.  Longitude is very strongly related to numeric zipcode spearman cor of 0.96
5.  Greenwich meantime is obviously related to zipcode, since it is a measure of longitude?
6.  Outlier analysis through univariate
7   One to One      GMTOFFSET to TIMEZONE ( may not need both of these variables)
8   One to One      STATE to STATECODE  (need both?)
9   One to One      STATE to STATENAME  (need both)
10  The strongest association between unordered catagorical variabkes is STATE * STATECODE
11  The weakest is Rand_A * Rand_B

Hi Ian, Some of your members may have set their notifications to not receive emails from Yammer or may not have "subscribed" to receive emails.  The best way to ensure that everyone in your group receives your message via email  is to make an "Announcement" in the group instead of "Update".  See the attached screenshot.  When an "Announcement" is created in Yammer it supersedes any notification setting that a user may have established.  
Hope this helps.

We are delighted to know that you are interested in learning more about the HHS Innovates Awards Program.  

This forum is designed for you to ask questions of the HHS Innovates committee members and interact with past award winners.  For the next hour, HHS Innovates committee members and past winners will be online and answering your questions in real time.  We will continue to monitor the page for new questions afterwards, so if you miss us today, don’t worry.  Stop by any time!  Also, if you see a question that interests you, feel free to ‘like’ it, respond or add to it.  

Not sure of what the HHS Innovates Awards program is, or how it could benefit you?   Ask us!  You are in the right place!

•	Are you new to the HHS Awards Program Innovates and wondering what this awards program celebrates and how it has helped past winners?  

The HHS Innovates is an Awards Program aimed at building a culture of innovation at the Department of Health and Human Services through facilitating the exchange of innovative ideas and showcasing creative approaches developed by our employees to solve tough problems. This program recognizes and rewards employee-led innovation, and helps to spread promising solutions across the Department and beyond.  More information about the awards program can be found here: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/
Each year, HHS employees are invited to submit innovations they have developed.  The innovations are initially reviewed by an internal committee and highest scored innovations are posted for online employee voting. The voting process provides an important mechanism through which good ideas are shared across the Department, and employees are invited to provide their feedback on the top innovations. The winners are personally recognized by the Secretary in an awards ceremony, and also receive a certificate signed by the Secretary, which is placed in their employee performance file.

•	I know there have been many changes in this round of HHS Innovates.  Let’s ask the HHS Innovates Coordinator, Elizabeth Kittrie, to highlight some of the new features.  Elizabeth, what’s new this round?
We’ve made a lot of great changes this round.  We’ve added six new submission categories that focus on high impact areas or relevance (these are: transforming health, optimizing human services, creating building blocks for success at every stage in life, enhancing operational effectiveness, biggest bang for our buck, and out-of-the-box solution).  We’ve streamlined the nomination process (e.g. we’ve added new questions, and we allow entrants to submit collateral materials).  We’ve improved the award selection process, as well as found opportunities to provide additional recognition for meritorious entrants.  You can read more about these changes here http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/ or in our blog post on this topic at http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/2015/01/05/hhs-innovates-launches-8th-round-awards-new-improved-submission-process/

Hi Andrew! Great question. The HHS Innovates Awards are for employees who have already implemented creative solutions can submit entries to HHS Innovates. If you have recognized a problem in your office/OpDiv and an idea to address it, but haven't necessarily acted, Ignite would be a good program to test out your idea. And finally the Entrepreneurs-in-Residence Program is geared towards HHS employees who have a higher-risk project that want to bring in a new employee (ie entrepreneur-in-residence) with expertise to address that problem within a 13 month time frame. Definitely check out the program webpages and feel free to reach out to the Program Managers listed within each page with your questions (usually under More Information) http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/

The key contributors to the winning innovations will receive a cash prize $1,000 per team member for the Secretary’s Picks and the Employee’s Picks, and $500 per team member for Employee’s Pick (HHS employees and Commissioned Corps only). We have a number of terrific resources to assist prospective applicants in putting together the strongest application possible.  These include:  1) Agency points-of-contact from the OPDIVS and STAFFDIVS who can speak with applicants in depth about their entry; 2) Innovates Mentors, who are past winners, and can provide peer-to-peer counseling and advice on how they put together winning applications.  Prospective applicants can also review the past winning projects on the HHS IDEA Lab Gallery, or review the recently held HHS Innovates webinar in which we feature dialogue with past winners and committee members. How is innovation defined for the purpose of this Awards program?
I want to talk with someone about my entry.  Who can I speak with?

For this awards program, an innovation is defined as the introduction of something entirely new (e.g., a product, process, system, service, or business model) or an unusual application of an existing product, process, system or service in a manner that improves an operating division’s or HHS’s ability to accomplish its mission. The innovation can be executed within the United States, or abroad, provided it is relevant to the mission of HHS or an operating division.  Learn more about the eligibility rules at http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/#tab-1418076763211-2-2
We have 15 minutes left for this Yam Jam.  What other questions do you have for us?

Hi Shawn! You have a couple of options -- 1) You can speak with a representative from your OPDIV/ STAFF Division; 2) You can speak with a past winner, a HHS Innovates Mentor, who can provide peer-to-peer advice on your entry; or, 3) You can schedule a 30-minute “office hour” and talk to IDEA Lab staff about your entry.  A list of these individuals can be found here: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/#tab-1418077115791-5-1
I'm sorry if I missed this question but how many Innovates awards are given each year?
Our team would like to recieve feedback for a draft submission.  Who could we send it to so that major and minor issues are identified?

Solicitations for award submissions are conducted annually. For this round, applicants have until February 27 to submit their entry.  It is anticipated that up to six teams will be recognized as award winners per award cycle. In addition, meritorious innovations will be eligible to receive written recognition from the Deputy Secretary.

Here is the scoring criteria:

1.Significance to the HHS/OPDIV Mission or to Operational Efficiency [25 points]
 2. Novelty of the Innovation [25 points]
 3.Impact/Return-on-Investment [25 points]
 4.Potential for and Scalability and Transferability across HHS [25 points]


More information can be found at under the evaluation process section of the HHS Innovates Website: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/

Here is the scoring criteria:
 
1.Significance to the HHS/OPDIV Mission or to Operational Efficiency [25 points]
 2. Novelty of the Innovation [25 points]
 3.Impact/Return-on-Investment [25 points]
 4.Potential for and Scalability and Transferability across HHS [25 points]
 

More information can be found at under the evaluation process section of the HHS Innovates Website: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/
Are resubmissions from prior rounds allowed?

Great question!  Applicants may resubmit entries that were submitted in a previous cycle but not chosen as the top 3 winners by the Secretary. Resubmissions must fall within the eligible time period and the resubmitted entry must contain updated information (such as new studies or results, development or initiation of new program or projects, demonstration of additional impact/scalability, or new lessons learned).

Hi James! You can either reach out to us at the IDEA Lab (idealab@hhs.gov) to discuss your draft so far or you can also reach out to your Agency Representative as well (L'Tonya Davis). A list of the agency reps can also be found here: http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/what-we-do/hhs-innovates/#tab-1418077115791-5-1
Can anyone at HHS participate in this program?
Hi James, I'm L'Tonya Davis, FDA's representative for HHS Innovates so if after office hours you have questions or need assistance, I'll be happy to further assist. Just let me know. Good luck!

Yes!  Any employee or Commissioned Corps member can submit an entry.  Typically, there are a number of contributors highlighted as part of the team.  Team members can include contractors, as well as non-HHS employees (including those from other government agencies, the private sector, or the public sector).  In addition, all employees are eligible to nominate their colleagues to apply, or to vote during the employee voting, which will occur in May.
Can non HHS-employees participate in this awards program?  For example, what about contractors, or those from the private sector.

Non-HHS employees can be part of the teams nominated for an award (however, they are not eligible for the cash awards, only the certificates). Note that the lead submitter for the innovation entry must be an HHS employee or member of the Commissioned Corps.
I understand that there is employee voting.  What is that about, and who gets to participate?

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
YAM JAM Follow Up

The Uniform Guidance indicates that each NOA list specific goals/objectives for each grantee. Has this time consuming work been factored in to the calendar/process to get the NOA issued?


The Uniform Guidance describes the information contained in a Federal award at 45 CFR 75.210.  

In section 75.210 (d) Federal Award Performance Goals, we at HRSA are required to provide an indication of the timing and scope of expected performance.  In the “reporting requirements” section of the Notice of Award (NoA) HRSA describes our expectations for annual, semi-annual or quarterly reporting.  

The Uniform Guidance also states HRSA “may include specific performance goals, indicators, milestones, or expected outcomes with an expected timeline for accomplishment,” where appropriate.  This should NOT be interpreted as a requirement for NoAs to include grantee-specific goals/objectives.  NOAs may include programmatic goals/objectives under the “program-specific terms” section, which would be applicable to all the grantees under the program.  This is not a requirement, it is an option.  The programmatic performance requirements should be aligned with the agency strategic goals.  

It is anticipated that program offices will generally obtain grantee-specific goals/objectives from grant applications, performance reports, progress reports, quarterly/semi-annual/annual reporting requirements, TA calls, site visits, etc.
