It has been reported recently that Skillsoft online courses are not launching with Java 8 Update 31 installed.


•	One option to correct this issue is to have users install Java 8 Update 25.

•	Another way to resolve it is by updating the Java options.  Open the java control panel -> Advanced tab -> Advanced Security Settings -> Uncheck TLS 1.1 and 1.2 -> apply changes.  

General Physics is working with SkillSoft and their hosting group on this to see if there is a more permanent solution where settings don't need to be updated.

If any learners report to you that they are having issues launching any online training, please have them check their version of Java.

Reminder in case you don’t have this on your calendar yet! Today is the HHS Digital Media Round Table Call - where we discuss timely topics, questions, share news and learn from each other’s experience –

Once a month a group of people jump on an old media technology (the telephone) to talk about new media issues (not the telephone). If you have a question or topic that you’d like to throw out to the group, you can send it ahead of time, or just plan on bringing it up yourself. Or just jump in other people’s topics. Or just silently, lurkingly, listen in…

Join us!

2:00 PM

Dial +1 (312) 878-3070

Access Code: 435-425-958

Back in 2012 [User:1490145196:ryanpanchadsaram] did some great work to lay out a claims format for BlueButton. I have used that pioneering effort as a basis for a Medicare BlueButton XML and JSON format. I have published the update on my Github account:

https://github.com/ekivemark/claims

I am hoping that other interested parties (eg. Payers) will contribute to this work so that we have some level of commonality.  

Since Medicare publishes self-entered data as part of BlueButton and these self-entered data segments correlate with sections of the Clinical Document Architecture I have used a <source></source> field within each data segment with a value of "patient" or "mymedicare.gov"  to identify where the data came from.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 2001: Microsoft gave the first public look at their new version of Windows, called Windows XP, formerly codenamed Whistler. Windows XP was designed with more emphasis on multimedia features such as Web publishing and streaming audio and video. It was built on the same platform as Microsoft's Windows 2000 operating system and was the first consumer operating system since Windows 95 that has an entirely new underlying code base. Microsoft ended support of XP in 2013, stating that 12 years was the longest they had supported any previous operating system.

http://www.g2techgroup.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/xp.jpg

Good Morning Lorraine,

While the committees actual scoring sheet is not yet available, below is the scoring criteria for selection which is on our website:

Step 2:  HHS Innovates Committee Scoring and Selection of Finalists
 
Proposals that are cleared by agency leadership will be evaluated by the HHS Innovates Committee based on the following criteria:
 1.Significance to the HHS/OPDIV Mission or to Operational Efficiency [25 points]
 2. Novelty of the Innovation [25 points]
 3.Impact/Return-on-Investment [25 points]
 4.Potential for and Scalability and Transferability across HHS [25 points]
 
The top scoring innovation in each category (Transforming Health, Optimizing Human Services, Creating Building Blocks for Success at Every Stage in Life, Enhancing Operational Effectiveness, Biggest Bang for Our Buck, and Out-of-the Box Solution) will move onto the finals.  In cases where there is a tie within a category, the Awards Committee may select multiple innovations to move onto the finals.  Those selected as finalists will be asked to participate in a brief interview with members of the HHS Innovates Committee.
 
Highly meritorious innovations that do not proceed to the finals will be eligible to receive written recognition from the Deputy Secretary.


Unfortunately, prior applications are no longer available on our new website.

Please let me know if you have any other questions.

Thanks,

Hi Keyla, I do believe that all systems are usually piloted first on a small population and then reviewed for fixes, bugs, and improvements.  Once the pilot is completed the system that has been reviewed is usually rolled out, sometimes in phases to the rest of the population.  On a few occasions some organizations will deploy a system without the phased approach, which I think is risky.  However, sometimes organizations have timelines they must meet and the old system has expired and business needs to be accomplished using the new system.  I hope this was helpful.  Feel free to ask more questions if you need clarification.  Maybe we have other Change Management Specialists here that can chime in.

Tips to Consider During Winter Storms and Extreme Cold:

 •Stay indoors during the storm.

 •Walk carefully on snowy, icy, walkways.

 •Avoid overexertion when shoveling snow. Overexertion can bring on a heart attack—a major cause of death in the winter. Use caution, take breaks, push the snow instead of lifting it when possible, and lift lighter loads.

 •Keep dry. Change wet clothing frequently to prevent a loss of body heat. Wet clothing loses all of its insulating value and transmits heat rapidly.

 •Signs of Frostbite: Occurs when the skin and body tissue just beneath it freezes. Loss of feeling and white or pale appearance in extremities, such as fingers, toes, earlobes, face, and the tip of the nose.
What to Do: Cover exposed skin, but do not rub the affected area in an attempt to warm it up. Seek medical help immediately.

 •Signs of Hypothermia: Dangerously low body temperature. Uncontrollable shivering, memory loss, disorientation, incoherence, slurred speech, drowsiness, and apparent exhaustion.
What to Do: If symptoms of hypothermia are detected take the person’s temperature. If it is below 95°, seek medical attention immediately. Get the victim to a warm location. Remove wet clothing. Warm the center of the body first by wrapping the person in blankets or putting on dry clothing. Give warm, non-alcoholic beverages if the victim is conscious. Seek medical help immediately. ◦The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends, if you detect symptoms of frostbite, seek medical care. Because frostbite and hypothermia both result from exposure, first determine whether the victim also shows signs of hypothermia. Hypothermia is a more serious medical condition and requires emergency medical assistance.
 
•Drive only if it is absolutely necessary. If you must drive: travel in the day; don’t travel alone; keep others informed of your schedule; stay on main roads and avoid back road shortcuts.

•Let someone know your destination, your route, and when you expect to arrive. If your car gets stuck along the way, help can be sent along your predetermined route.

•If the pipes freeze, remove any insulation or layers of newspapers and wrap pipes in rags. Completely open all faucets and pour hot water over the pipes, starting where they were most exposed to the cold (or where the cold was most likely to penetrate).

•Maintain ventilation when using kerosene heaters to avoid build-up of toxic fumes. Refuel kerosene heaters outside and keep them at least three feet from flammable objects.

 •Conserve fuel, if necessary, by keeping your residence cooler than normal. Temporarily close off heat to some rooms.
 •If you will be going away during cold weather, leave the heat on in your home, set to a temperature no lower than 55ºF.

Using Human-Centered Design (HCD) in Human Service Programs

Join us to learn how three Office of Family Assistance grantees are using HCD to:

Blair, as we discussed phone just now, the grantees themselves would not be eligible to participate in the HHS Innovates award or to submit an entry.  But, I do think the grant program itself could be elibigle if there is something innovative in the way that particular grant was offered or designed. The accomplishments produced by the grantees would then serve as evidence of the impact/result of this approach to HHS grant-making.  In the last round of Innovates, NIH won an award for the Breast Cancer Start-up Challenge, which was an innovative way of working with private sector to develop and commercialize breast cancer treatments.  In that case, the 11 winners/new start-ups of the NIH-led challenge served testimony to the success of the approach.

"Soft delete" means you can still retrieve the information in Yammer on the back end through a data export.   However, this will not allow for us to preserve an individual who has been deleted, unless they are in "suspend" mode, and you can check this by looking in the "Remove Users" section in the Admin Console. If the User is not in suspend mode, the user will need to be re-added and will need to create a new profile in your network. Call me if you need additional information.

The Spring 2015 Virtual Tech Exchange is just over two weeks away on Wednesday, March 11, 2015 from 8:30 am to 12:30 pm. 

This session provides an opportunity for HHS personnel to learn, collaborate, and discuss security trends in cybersecurity, HHS initiatives, privacy, and other areas of technology.  In order to allow attendance by HHS personnel located outside of the DC area, this Tech Exchange will be held via webinar.  This session is open for attendance by all HHS employees and contractors.  

Presentation topics are below:
- McAfee and CDM
- WebInspect and CDM
- FY2015 US-CERT Cyber Incident Reporting Guidelines and HHS
- CSIRC Revamp 
- Identity Relationship Management

body:
Follow Up from the last Yam Jam
QUESTION: 
In the new Uniform Guidance, are grantees called “grantees?”   And are applicants called “applicants?”

ANSWER:
Applicants are called “applicants” in the Uniform Guidance.
The term “grantee” is REMOVED from the Uniform Guidance.

Grantees are referred to as a “recipient” and/or “non-federal entity.”

This is basically because “recipients” may be in receipt of a variety of types of ‘awards’ available across the entire federal government (e.g. ‘grant’ or a ‘cooperative agreement’ just to name two).

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Follow Up from the last Yam Jam

QUESTION:
Does the Uniform Guidance restrict the transfer of funds or re-budgeting within an award to 10% (from 25%)?

ANSWER:
No.  The Uniform Guidance does not change current HRSA Grant Policy/Operations.  The Uniform Guidance does provide HRSA with the ability to restrict the transfer of funds, as appropriate, for direct cost categories or programs.  The Uniform Guidance states that the HHS awarding agency “may, at its option, restrict the transfer of funds….. (when) the cumulative amount of such transfers exceeds or is expected to exceed 10 percent of the total budget.” 

At this time, HRSA choses to follow current grants management practices in alignment with the Grants Policy Administration Manual (GPAM) chapter 903.4.2.1.1 Significant Rebudgeting.  The GPAM states, “Rebudgeting, or moving funds between direct cost budget categories in an approved budget, is considered significant when cumulative transfers for a single budget period exceeds 25 percent of the total approved budget (inclusive of direct and indirect costs and federal funds and required matching or cost sharing).  The base used for determining significant rebudgeting excludes carryover balances but includes any amounts awarded as supplements.”

Please note: HHS is working with all OPDIVs to update the GPAM.  Any future modifications to the GPAM that modify this requirement will be communicated to the Bureaus/Offices.

Save the Date! March 19th 12:30 - 1:30. Training opportunity available to anyone in HHS from the Office of Assistant Secretary of Health (OASH).

Title:  How Good Workplace Communication Improves Employee Morale

Summary: Communication can instantly start off on the wrong foot when it’s approached negatively rather than positively. When information is transferred insufficiently or inaccurately, workplace productivity goes down. The good news is that the opposite is also true. Good workplace communication can have positive effects on performance including increased productivity, higher employee morale, repeat business, improved employee retention, and a healthier work environment overall.

Date: Thursday, March 19

Time: 12:30 – 1:30 pm

Presenter: James Egbert is a Human Resources Specialist in the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Positioned in the Office of the Secretary, Office of Human Resources, James helps to formulate and implement workforce programs and strategies to promote a positive, healthy, and innovative HHS workforce.
 
For Participants:
URL: https://www.mymeetings.com/nc/join/
Phone Number: 877-924-1752
Conference #: PW1265713
Audience passcode: 1540787

Participants can join the event directly at: 
https://www.mymeetings.com/nc/join.php?i=PW1265713&p=1540787&t=c

body:
Greetings from Atlanta!

As the largest Region in CMS cross cutting IT projects can become incredibly complex in a nano second.  In order to take our work to the next level and look at these 3 lines of business as the Medicaid Enterprise this workgroup is created as a collaboration tool.  

For those who are not familiar with Yammer the use rule is posted below (please read):

*****************************************************************

U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services (HHS) Acceptable Use Policy

Welcome to HHSconnect!

Our goal is to provide a collaborative work environment for you to connect with staff from your own organization and across the Department.

Treat this space like a community bulletin board! Find help. Share ideas. Advertise meetings. Build a community. But don’t post something you wouldn’t feel comfortable hanging in your office hallway.

The HHSconnect Space is a service provided by a third-party vendor. The policies and procedures that apply to the use by a federal agency of the Internet and social media, apply here as well.

As a participant in this space, please remember to do the following: 
1. Adhere to the HHS Rules of Behavior (for Use of HHS Information Technology Resources): HHS Rules of Behavior at http://intranet.hhs.gov/it/cybersecurity/docs/policies_guides/ROB/hhs-rob.pdf . 

2. Engage only with the HHS, (e.g., do not tweet or disclose your profile information to the public) and those external individuals who are authorized members of formally approved external networks. Do not disclose non-public information to anyone outside HHS.

3. Be aware that the information contained on this site may have federal record status, and that portions may be required to be disclosed to parties outside HHS (e.g., in response to Freedom of Information Act requests, requests from Congress, and court orders). Remember all information posted on the HHS Collaboration Space site belongs to the U.S. Government.

4. Do not share any Personally Identifiable Information (PII) (e.g., work or non-work-related sensitive information).

5. Conduct discussions in a respectful/professional manner (e.g., offer opinions, agree to disagree).

6. Keep news posts informative, statements interesting and questions thought provoking (i.e., think wisely when posting comments to limit the time required to explore answers/options).

7. Do not use profanity, post inflammatory/offensive language or refer to inappropriate materials. Misuse of the tool is prohibited and will be reported.

8. Do discuss and work through draft documents which will become public, but do not use this space for the final approval process.

9. Use your work email address when collaborating. For availability, transparency, records management, and other reasons, agency business cannot be conducted using a personal email account. 

10. While meeting our responsibilities as members of a federal agency, we want to foster a culture that sustains both our community and organization. In terms of your online behavior, “keep it professional,” act appropriately, and always practice sound judgment. If you are found to be in violation of this agreement, your approval to use the HHSconnect Space will be revoked. Depending upon the severity of the violation, you may be subject to disciplinary action.

If you need clarification or have any questions regarding this User Agreement or the HHSconnect Space, please send your inquiries to Sandra.scarbrough@nih.gov or Tori.garten@nih.gov. 

Visit the HHS Yammer 101 group to get started and find answers to your questions

Good morning,

As you know, February is African American History Month.  The theme for this month is “A Century of Black Life, History and Culture.”  We have invited Kerrie Cotten Williams, Special Collections Manager for DC Public Library.  Ms. Cotten Williams will be giving us useful tips on how we can preserve our own family histories with a hands-on, interactive talk. 

Please join us Friday, February 27, 2015 at 12 Noon in White Oak Building 2, Conference Room 2031 for what promises to be a useful and delightful talk.  

We look forward to seeing you.

*****


Further details below:

Program:  African American Heritage Month
Theme:  A Century of Black Life, History and Culture.

Date:  February 27, 2015, 
Location:  WO Bldg. 2, Room 2031

View SAS dataset in Excel and Old Text Editor Functions

see attached file for cleaner copy  VueXls.txt

options cmdmac;

Viewing a SAS dataset in Excel

If you highlight sashelp.cars and type xlsh in the old text editor
command line then sashelp.class will be opened in excel.

* if you put these two macros in your autocall library member c:\oto\xlsh.sas.
You do not have to store them in two macros.
You also need SAS Access to PCFiles. Could substitute ODS excel if you have 9.4.
Also you need options cmdmac.

%macro xlsh /cmd ;
   store;note;notesubmit '%xlsha;';
   run;
%mend xlsh;

%macro xlsha/cmd;

    filename clp clipbrd ;
    data _null_;
     infile clp;
     input;
     put _infile_;
     call symputx('argx',_infile_);
    run;

    %let __tmp=%sysfunc(pathname(work))\myxls.xlsx;

    data _null_;
        fname="tempfile";
        rc=filename(fname, "&__tmp");
        put rc=;
        if rc = 0 and fexist(fname) then
       rc=fdelete(fname);
    rc=filename(fname);
    run;

    libname __xls excel "&__tmp";
    data __xls.%scan(__&argx,1,%str(.));
        set &argx.;
    run;quit;
    libname __xls clear;

    data _null_;z=sleep(1);run;quit;

    options noxwait noxsync;
    /* Open Excel */
    x "'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\OFFICE14\excel.exe' &__tmp";
    run;quit;

%mend xlsha;

Poor man's program versioning( I also set autosave to 1 minute )

    Tap the middle mouse button or function key and a time stamped version
    of the program will be saved in c:\ver and a production
    version in the SAS present program folder.

    1. Create a versioning directory call c:\ver
    2. The top of editor window
       %let pgm=utl_RogPgm;
    3. In your autoexec
       %Let _q=%sysfunc(int(%sysfunc(time())));
    4, On function key or better on middle mouse button.
       pgm;file &pgm..sas;file "c:\ver\&pgm.&_q..sas";%let &_q=%eval(0&_q+1);
    5. When you hit the fuction key or middle mouse button a time stamped
       version of you program will be saved in c:\ver\utl_RogPgm20145.sas


My invocation of SAS

E:\sashome\SASFoundation\9.3\sas.exe
-work e:\wrk

-RLANG

-nosplash
-autosaveloc c:\ver\pgm.sas
-config e:\cfg\sasv9.cfg
-nodmsexp
-sasautos c:\oto
-awscontrol notitle
-emailsys SMTP


   Very fast point and shoot editing and code submit in the old text editor.

   suppose you have submit on the right mouse key

   Use the ALT key as you hold down the mouse button and drag the mouse
   to select a rectangular block (or column) of te

   After the highlight above hit the right mouse button and the highlighted code will
   be executed.

   type change x y on the command line

   then x will be changed to y only in the highlighted area.

   Simple actions like typing 860 on the command line will take to line
   860. On long programs I sometimes jot down the location of
   keta lines.


   USEFUL EDITIONG COMMANDS
   *************************


  The prefix area  Many of these commands can be put on function keys using a ':', ie :ts.

  D99----  Delete next 99 lines (also could cut with mouse)

  I999---  Insert 999 blank lines useful when autoadd is set

  IB55---  Insert 55 lines before

  C3-----  Copy next three lines to some target

  A000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy after)

  B000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy before)

  M------  Move this line somewhere

  M3-----  Move next 3 lines somewhere

  O3-----  Move source lines over these lines

  R3-----  Replicate the next 3 lines

  DD00103  Block delete   CC00103  Block Copy    MM00103  Block Move
  0000104                 0000104                0000104
  DD-----                 CC-----                MM-----

  OO00103  Target Over    RR3----  Block Replicate
  0000104                 0000104
  OO-----                 RR-----

  (4-----  Shift left first 4 columns into bit bucket (distructive shift)
  )4-----  Shift right first 4 columns (distructive shift)
  >5-----  Nondistructive shift right
  <5-----  Nondistructive shift left
  >>5----  Non distructive shift right of a block of commands
  0000101
  0000102
  >>-----
  <<,)),(( Similar to single character versions
  UC----- Upper case line  - more useful on function key as :UC
  UC26--- Upper case next 26 lines
  LC----- Lower case line
  LC26
  LLC---- Block of lines -lower or upper case
  UUC
  TF----- Text flow lines until blank line
  TS----- Text split at cursor better on function key as :tf
  MASK - BUILD TEMPLATE FOR ENTERING DATA


   Only available with ISPF editor

   X    Hide a line
   XX   Hide mutiple lines
   XX
   flip reverse hidden lines , ie only show hidden lines



   no need to look up a P-Value
   put this on any command line
   %put %sysfunc(probnorm(1.96)); /* try this on command line */

   ?          - previous command history
   subtop     - submit top line of editor
   icon
   rchange    - change on function key hit
   rfind      - find on function key hit
   save  prg       /# save program in your profile #/
   copy  prg       /# recalls program from your profile #/
   change     - c today yesterday ic all   ( ignore case all)
   cols
   reset
   keys
   top
   bot
   n           - go to line n
   left  n
   right  n
   spell all - check spelling of all words in editor
   autoadd   - add aline at a time to editor ( usewith mask and bounds )
   vscroll 25 - set scroll amounts for forward and backward
   hscroll 10
   backward max n
   forward max  n
   bounds
   mask
   copy
   paste
   find - f 'data' first last next prev prefix suffix word
   find 'Mac' prefix
   change - c todat yesterday ic all
   rchange - change on function key hit
   rfind   - find on function key hit
   mark - highlight string, lines for submit or edit
   mark block - highlight rectangle within editor
                does not have to be full lines

   CAPS on/off

   fse

   Example 1 -- Just a dumb script
   --------------------------------

   1;F ' ';MARK;HOME;2;HOME;MARK;HOME;STORE;HOME;UNMARK;

   If the first line in active editor contains

   000001 %Macro MyLongMacroName

   This script will put MyLongMacroName into the paste buffer.
   You can then paste MyLongMacroName anywhere you want.
   (This only works on windows). Try it, just copy
   the one line script to the command line.

   My function keys I turn off scrool bars and use f1 and f2

   F1         left 3; /* ctl D is MMB versioning program */
   F2         right 3;/* ctl R wattention|ctl f1 2nd MMB contents last */
   F3         gsubmit '%last';      /* last 40 obs           */
   F4         note;notesubmit '%lastall';   /* last all obs          */
   F5         store;note;notesubmit '%uxp';    /* 40 obs highlighted */
   F6         store;note;notesubmit '%uxpall'; /* all obs highlighted */
   F7         store;note;notesubmit '%uxpcon'; /* contents highlighted*/
   F8         rfind  /* data;v1=;v2=3;v3=2;callsortn(of v1-v3);put v1 1v2 v3;*/
   F9         rchange
   F11        note;notesubmit '%unxcon'; /* constant(pi,big,small,logbig) */
   F12        ~;;;;/*'*/ *);*};*];*/;/*"*/;%mend;run;quit;%end;end;run;endcomp;%utlfix;
   SHF F1     :tf

   SHF F6     :a;copy box;/*n ? "hil";n=*"PFil Mason";n gt:"Phil";n le:"Phim"; sql - eqt    */
   SHF F7     :a;copy hdr;/*libname x excel ".xls";proc sql;update x;set y=2;where n="Roger"*/
   SHF F8     log;file "./&pgm..log";note zx;notesubmit '%utl_logcurchk(./&pgm);';
   SHF F9     home; /* proc print blankline=5; * blanks every 5*/
   SHF F10    ~%let dtetym=%substr(%sysfunc(outn(%sysfunc(datetime(),datetime22.)),1,15);
   SHF F11    ~proc print split="*";attrib _all_ label="*"; * print without col names;

The following winter storm home-preparation suggestions, from FEMA, may be helpful:
• Make sure flashlights and battery-powered radios are working, and keep extra batteries, candles and matches on hand.
• Unplug sensitive appliances such as the TV, VCR, computer and microwave. If the power goes off, turn off all major electrical appliances.
• Keep refrigerator and freezer doors closed. If you lose power, frozen food will generally keep for 48 hours. Discard perishable food that has been at 40 degrees for more than two hours. Odor or appearance is not an indicator that food is safe. When in doubt, throw it out. 
• If you use an emergency-heating source such as a wood stove, kerosene heater or fireplace, keep fuels away from the flames and ventilate properly. Never leave a fire unattended.
• If it seems likely that your home will be without heat for several days, drain your water pipes.
• If you use a generator, read all the instructions that accompany it and be aware of the hazards that come with misuse. Use a qualified electrician to connect a generator to the house wiring. Never run a gasoline-powered generator in the house-the fumes are deadly.

Since there is no way to prevent nature's winter storms, being prepared in your best defense:
• Create a family disaster plan and practice it regularly.
• Learn and teach others in your family how to turn off electricity, gas and water.
• Store extra blankets and warm clothes where you can find them easily. Layer winter clothing to trap body heat.
• Keep emergency telephone numbers with you.
• Have a first aid kit on hand.
• Stock up on drinking water and canned or dried foods. Be sure to include a non-electric can opener with your supplies.
• Have at least a week's supply of prescription medications on hand.
• Fill your car with gasoline.
• Have cash available.

You can find more helpful info & tips at http://www.ready.gov/winter-weather

body:
The 2015 Federal Award Oversight Manual for Project Officers (https://sharepoint.hrsa.gov/GOMRPO/SitePages/Home.aspx) is now availalbe at HRSA's Sharepoint home page (click on title to go to link).   The manual is intended to:    
  #Be a guide and reference for POs, describing their role and responsibilities, in the context of a team approach that involves PO managers, GMSs, GMOs, program integrity analysts, and others; and   
  #Provide the fundamental requirements all POs must follow to comply with basic performance standards and ensure the success of Federal awardees and HRSA's mission.    A summary of PO and GMS/GMO responsibilities by stage in the federal award cycle (https://sharepoint.hrsa.gov/GOMRPO/Tools%20Library/PO%20and%20GMS%20Responsibilities%20Table_Final.pdf) was also issued with the manual this year. (click on title to go to link).     Bureaus and Offices must ensure that their program-specific standard operating procedures are aligned with the key components of monitoring outlined in the manual. Please contact your Bureau or Office point of contact for any program specific questions in relation to this manual.

This detail application open period has been extended. Applications will be accepted until March 9, 2015. Two items to highlight: 1. There is a possibility for this detail to become a permanent position within the Center for Global Health at the GS-14 level. 2. Also, this can be a reimbursed detail position. Please consider this opportunity for career growth and to participate in this exciting program.   Wanda Neal Chief, Epidemiology, Therapeutics & Sciences Branch National Cancer Institute, NIH, HHS 9609 Medical Center Dr. RM 1E614 MSC 9705 Bethesda, MD 20892 ph: (240) 276-5403 wn21j@nih.gov (mailto:wn21j@nih.gov)

Detail Opportunity with the NCI Center for Global Health (CGH)
http://www.cancer.gov/aboutnci/organization/global-health
The CGH provides focus for the NCI’s global research programs by serving as members in multi-national organizations and participating in diplomatic relations related to cancer research and cancer control by: facilitating international research efforts, including NCI-sponsored clinical trials; developing international programs in cancer research to achieve mutually beneficial goals that translate into advances in both research and clinical effectiveness; and building capacity for cancer research globally.
We are seeking someone with contract expertise to help us move our work in clinical research networks forward.

Contracts Specialist, GS-1102 13/14 The Center for Global Health/NCI is seeking candidates to serve as a Contracts Specialist Duration of Detail: The Detail will begin on or around April 1, 2015 for 120 days and may renewed in 120-day increments up to a year. This can be a reimbursed detail. There is a possibility for this detail to become a permanent position within the Center for Global Health. Duties and Responsibilities:  Prepare R&D SOWs for foreign sites in the to-be-established Burkitt Lymphoma Treatment Network (BLTN)
Prepare R&D SOWs for foreign sites in the Latin America Cancer Research Network (continuation of activity) http://www.cancer.gov/aboutnci/organization/global-health/research-programs-initiatives/us-la-crn
Oversee support contract
Prepare sole-source justifications
Other related activities
Skills/experience required: Looking for an experienced contracting officer who has worked with research and development projects, clinical trials, human subjects, OMB clearance, foreign sites, and complex administrative matters. Needs to be a self-motivated individual working outside of a COAC in program office to function as the COR for a complex portfolio of approximately 12-14 contracts.
Qualification Criteria: This detail is intended for individuals in job series 1102 at the GS-13 or GS-14 grade level or equivalent. A temporary promotion is not available. Contractors are not eligible to apply.  Application Procedures: Interested applicants should submit a letter of support from your supervisor, cover letter, and resume or CV outlining relevant qualifications and experience via email to NCICenterforGlobalHealth@mail.nih.gov by COB Wednesday, February 25, 2015.  Selection Process: Applications will be reviewed and interviews may be scheduled. The program office will notify the selectee and negotiate the effective date of the transfer between the loaning and gaining supervisors.

Daylight Savings Time begins on Sunday, March 8, and is a good time to test your smoke alarms and change the batteries.

Working smoke alarms are an important part of a home fire escape plan. When there is a fire, smoke spreads fast. 

Working smoke alarms give you an early warning so you can get outside quickly. 

Also, please remember to turn your clocks forward one hour.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1992: The first media-hyped computer virus reached fever pitch as the Michelangelo boot sector virus began to affect computers. The virus, which triggered when a computer's clock registered the date March 6, coincides with the famed painter Michelangelo's birthday. Any PC that had the virus would have a blank disk drive if it was powered up on March 6. Therein was the virus' weakness - it wipes itself out every year by killing its host. 

http://kingofgng.com/media/20140330_michelangelo_hype.jpg

body: Melvin, this is a virtual discussion over the month of March through posting to the Forum. This allows folks to check in to the discussion on-line when their schedule allows.

Hi Beth - We use Jira to track bugs and future enhancements for 3 systems here in HRSA's Bureau of Health Workforce.  As far as training, it's been ad-hoc.  Some folks jump right into it, others are slower adopters.
http://www.inc.com/jeff-haden/39-incorrectly-used-words-that-can-make-you-look-bad.html

Same here at NIH/NIAID. We use JIRA for a good many scientific software development projects. We don't formally train people, but I or another administrator will often give a quick primer (in person or over a screen-share) when setting up an account for a new user. We also often bring it up during team meetings to help review/prioritize tasks for a given product release, so it's become part of the culture for multiple projects, which helps drive adoption. Happy to chat further with you offline if you'd like.

Welcome to Retirement Club! If you don't want email notifications for every posting, click on your highlighted name by your picture (or non-picture). We plan to keep documents under “files” that you can use for reference, and news and articles under conversations. Please feel free to post what you’ve found and share with the group. We started with 8 people last year, and four of them went on to a happy etirement! That's the way we like it!

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1960: Using his own invention, Dr. Belding Hibbard Scribner implanted the first shunt into a patient, which allowed the patient to receive hemodialysis on a regular basis. Thanks to the device, which became known as the Scribner shunt, the first of many patients it saved was Clyde Shields, who survived his chronic renal failure for more than eleven years.

Jay's Quote of the Week
---
"How you look at a situation is very important, for how you think about a problem may defeat you before you ever do anything about it. When you get discouraged or depressed, try changing your attitude from negative to positive and see how life can change for you. Remember, your attitude toward a situation can help you to change it -- you create the very atmosphere for defeat or victory."

Franco Harris

MCH Research Webinar: Estimating Absolute Differences and Relative Rate Ratios from Regression Models. Wednesday, March 18, 2015. 3:00 PM - 4:30 PM ET. Learning objectives: Recognize the advantages of absolute contrasts for making causal inferences and for quantifying public health impact. Understand the disadvantages of odds ratios and how to avoid them. Gain knowledge of the different approaches to obtaining absolute and relative contrasts from regression models in Stata and SAS software packages. Good afternoon, We would like to invite you to the next session of Conéctate (Get Connected!) with Acquisitions to be held on Wednesday, March 25, 2015 from 3:00-4:30 pm at 2115 E. Jefferson St., Conference Room B57BB Lower Level.  

Mr. Gary Morin from the NIH Office of the Chief Information Officer accepted our invitation to provide a briefing regarding Section 508 and the roles and responsibilities of acquisitions staff when purchasing electronic IT products and services.  We will also continue talking about engagement strategies for the upcoming spring/summer.  We would like to inform you that Conéctate with Acquisitions participants can get 1.5 Continuous Learning Points.   If you would like to submit your questions in advance, please send an email to NIH Section 508 Help (mailto:Section508Help1@mail.nih.gov?subject=Questions%20for%20March%2025,%202015%20Acquisitions%20Presentation) (NIH/OD OCIO)(Section508Help1@mail.nih.gov (mailto:Section508Help1@mail.nih.gov)) 

The following telephone line is provided for those of you that can’t attend in person: 
Toll Free Number: 877-356-1736  Pass Code:  34030772 

We hope you can join us. Thank you!  

Juan Tayco taycojl@mail.nih.gov (mailto:taycojl@mail.nih.gov)  

Conéctate (Get Connected!) is sponsored by the NIH Office of Equity, Diversity and Inclusion (EDI).  The activity is intended to foster and promote a positive and inclusive work environment that supports and values career advancement and growth.  Leaders and employees are encouraged to join, participate, and support NIH’s ongoing commitment to diversity and inclusion.  Conéctate (Get Connected!) is open to anyone interested to attend.  Individuals with disabilities who need reasonable accommodation to participate in this activity please contact Gerard Roman, at 919-541-3430, or email roman@od.nih.gov (mailto:roman@od.nih.gov).

UPCOMING EVENT ON MARCH 23: HHS ENTREPRENEURS-IN-RESIDENCE WEBINAR
 
Need outside expertise to tackle a health or human service challenge at HHS? If so, join an informational webinar on March 23 from 1-2 pm about the HHS Entrepreneurs-in-Residence Program. You can register for the webinar at http://ow.ly/JTnoD This is a great opportunity to hear from HHS IDEA Lab staff and program alumni: Kevin Larsen (http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/projects-item/accelerating-clinical-quality-measures-for-the-affordable-care-act/), ONC and Richard Gilbert (http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/projects-item/modernizing-the-national-plan-and-provider-enumeration-system/), CMS.
 
The HHS Entrepreneurs-in-Residence program:
- allows participating teams to complete a high-priority project that requires an external skillset in about a year
- attracts and onboards external talent that would be difficult to identify without support from HHS IDEA Lab
- provides support from HHS leadership to complete a potentially risky or disruptive project
- gives access to a network of innovators affiliated with HHS IDEA Lab
- provides project management and mentoring support to project teams
 
The HHS Entrepreneurs-in-Residence project application period is currently open. Applications can be submitted at: http://ow.ly/JGSRm

March is Women’s History Month.  In honor of this observance, OWH is collecting brief stories from HRSA staff from March 9 - March 13, 2015.  Story themes will be highlighted in intranet postings later in the month.  Contributions may address the following prompts:

•Who is your favorite historical women’s health hero or heroine? Why is his/her work inspirational to you?
•Describe a women’s health hero or heroine in your life.  What did he/she do to make a difference?
•Describe a health care provider who helped you or a female family member on their journey towards better health.
 
To share your short story or for questions, e-mail: Sarah Debel, HRSA Office of Women’s Health, at sdebel@hrsa.gov

Health Data Initiative Updates
---
Dear Health Data Leads,

First I would like to sincerely thank you all for your prompt responses to the recent Sunlight Foundation FOIA request for government wide metadata about the resources in our catalogs. Your thorough responses have helped OMB to provide timely reply to this request.

Next, I am happy to inform you that we are working on launching a new version of HealthData.gov this spring. There are several goals for the revitalization of this public face of the HHS Health Data Initiative including advancing the platform's technology base for improved data and catalog management capabilities, improving platform usability and administration functions, and creating a space that will support various user communities. This procurement process will also take advantage of the new HHS Buyer's Club<http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/2014/06/24/membership-has-its-privileges/> pathway for innovative IT procurements allowing more agile development cycles for a more effective implementation and reduced costs over the life of the project.

Finally I'm reminding you that the Health Datapalooza<http://www.healthdatapalooza.org> is coming in early June. Once again I'll lead the Datalab, a session where I'll match you (or your colleague), the data owner, with one of your interesting or effective data users. The goal is to demonstrate how and why the data was collected with how it is alternatively useful when the data is made openly available. My ask is that you please connect me with your suggested data users now so that we can begin fleshing out the session.  I'd Iike to have an introduction to your recommended data user by Friday March 20 pls. We need ample time to evaluate the candidates, and for them to organize their travel to the event in June.

As always, thank you for your efforts toward a more robust HDI.

Damon

Damon<http://about.me/damondavis> | 301.646.8292-m| 202.774.2307-o | HHS IDEA Lab | HealthData.gov | @damonldavis<https://twitter.com/damonldavis>

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1985: The Southern New England Telephone Company turned on ConnNet, the nation’s first local, public packet-switching network. Customers could access CompuServ, NewsNet and other services at a (then) blistering 4,800 to 56,000 bits per second. The service’s X.25 protocol went obsolete in the 1990s with the popularity of the Internet Protocol (IP).

http://image.slidesharecdn.com/iws4-100317114542-phpapp01/95/iws-4-6-728.jpg?cb=1268844395

body:
Dear Forum Users,
 
The HHS Yammer Administrators are coming to Rockville to demo the Yammer platform and demonstrate its capabilities! The event will be on March 31 from 3 pm to 4 pm, in 5W11. For those in the regional offices, or wishing to stay at their desks, we will send Adobe Connect and teleconference information closer to the date of the demo. Please pass along the info to your HRSA colleagues. If you require special assistance, please email Suzanne Auerbach (sauerbach1@hrsa.gov (mailto:sauerbach1@hrsa.gov)).


cc: [User:1491027871:sbolon], [User:1501236026:areyes]

Team, this is the current version of the What's Your Why video I keep mentioning.  We are still editing and the final product may look/feel very different but this will show you the direction we are hoping to take this.  Let me know your thoughts! http://youtu.be/l_4OqzpK314

My initial thoughts:

The cuts to the side shot are a bit jarring. I think this is due to using the cut too many times. High frequency cuts are good when the music is up tempo and the content is fast paced. This video and music are much more calm in a sense so it needs more time to engage the viewer to the front shot before moving to a side shot. Will watch again and see if I come up with anything else.
Registration requires a conference ID#. Will you share the number for the meeting?

I've been using my iPad for notes.  I use the notability app because I can mark up documents, or just take a blank page of notes and file them according to topic and date.  Helps keep me organized.  I think a lot of it is finding an app that works for you and a stylus that works with your handwriting.  I'm on my third app and fourth stylus and think I finally found a winner.
I have been using my Google Nexus 9, I love it.  Now if only I could get access to sharepoint from it.

I've taken it to child support conferences because they're starting to use conference apps now. I bookmark the workshops and plenary sessions I've attended so I can go back and review the notes of the briefings later when I'm looking for leads for stories for our monthly newsletter. It also allows me to find state-level and county-level contacts that I would normally have to go through a multi-step process to find.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1923: Inventor Lee De Forest demonstrated the Phonofilm for the press. It was the first motion picture with a sound-on-film track.  All or part of the Paramount Pictures features "Bella Donna" (premiered 1 April 1923) and "The Covered Wagon" (premiered 16 March 1923) were filmed with Phonofilm as an experiment. However, the Phonofilm versions were only shown at the premiere engagements.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/a5/The_Covered_Wagon_poster.jpg

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1882: At the Royal Institution, Eadweard J. Muybridge demonstrated his zoopraxiscope, an early device for displaying motion pictures. The zoopraxiscope, considered to be the first movie projector, projected images from rotating glass disks in rapid succession to give the impression of motion. The stop-motion images were initially painted onto the glass, as silhouettes. A second series of discs, made in 1892–94, used outline drawings printed onto the discs photographically, then colored by hand. Some of the animated images are very complex, featuring multiple combinations of sequences of animal and human movement.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/17/Zoopraxiscope_16485u.jpg

MAJOR RESPONSIBILITIES 
The Committee's major responsibilities are as follows: 

1.	Evaluate results of the Employee Viewpoint Survey each year to develop, prioritize and implement ongoing recommendations.

2.	Consult with the Leadership Development Board on a routine basis.

3.	Provide updates to Center Leadership on a regular basis. 

4.	Present results to Management Council at least twice a year. 

5.	Work with Center management to identify special needs and initiatives. 

6.	Encourage continued engagement of the broader CFSAN community.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1926: Robert Goddard launched the first liquid-fueled (gasoline and liquid oxygen) rocket in Auburn, Massachusetts. Present at the launch were his crew chief, Henry Sachs, Esther Goddard, and Percy Roope, who was Clark's assistant professor in the physics department. 

The rocket, which was later dubbed "Nell", rose just 41 feet during a 2.5-second flight that ended 184 feet away in a cabbage field, but it was an important demonstration that liquid propellants were possible. The launch site is now a National Historic Landmark, the Goddard Rocket Launching Site.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7c/Goddard_and_Rocket.jpg

12:00 p.m. – 1:00 p.m.
WO, Bldg. 71, Room 1206

1.	Introduction (Get to Know your Needs)

2.	DHHS Yammer Website “Retirement Club” Group:   https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/#/threads/inGroup?type=in_group&feedId=4835926

4.	Angie will ask you to submit your information through EWITS, the Enterprise Workflow Information Tracking System, that allows you to submit retirement estimate requests online: https://ewits.prod.hhs.gov/retire/editemployeeRequest.html
This system limits requests to a maximum of 3 estimates within a 12-month period. You need to have your personnel user ID to enter this system.

5.	Go to the Social Security Administration website: www.ssa.gov and create an account to retrieve a copy of your Social Security Benefit Estimate (FERS only).

6.	Open for Discussion

Glad to see you made it to our OFPA Yammer Group!  
 
To celebrate St. Patrick’s Day this week, we’ve got a little contest for our OFPA Yammer members:  
 
We will give a $5 Starbucks card to the first team member to add 3 posts to the OFPA Yammer Wall on three separate days this week.  But it can’t just be any post!  You need to post a fact each day about Ireland from Wikipedia that is related to some aspect of the type of work OFPA and/or ASPR does in America.  That could be any facts about the government of Ireland’s budget process, medical emergency response programs, disaster & hospital preparedness, vaccination development, etc.  Check out ASPR’s https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/phe.gov for more ideas.  We will announce the winner after they have made their 3rd post!  So check out our FPA Yammer page every day this week and play along!  
 
The Luck of the Irish be with you!

You’re invited to an online Brown Bag Session sponsored by the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health - Employee Satisfaction and Morale Committee. 

Title:  How Good Workplace Communication Improves Employee Morale
Summary: Communication can instantly start off on the wrong foot when it’s approached negatively rather than positively. When information is transferred insufficiently or inaccurately, workplace productivity goes down. The good news is that the opposite is also true. Good workplace communication can have positive effects on performance including increased productivity, higher employee morale, repeat business, improved employee retention, and a healthier work environment overall.
Date: Thursday, March 19
Time: 12:30 – 1:30 pm
Presenter: James Egbert is a Human Resources Specialist in the United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Positioned in the Office of the Secretary, Office of Human Resources, James helps to formulate and implement workforce programs and strategies to promote a positive, healthy, and innovative HHS workforce.

We're always looking for ways to improve our impact with social media. Shawn and I are working on a plan for 2015 with some changes to the program, some experiments, etc. I think I shared this article via email with some folks, but it has some ideas to consider when thinking about social media. Of course being government will have some affect on what we can do - but perhaps this will jump start some ideas for a few folks. https://hbr.org/2014/12/the-art-of-aggressive-social-sharing

Did you know there was an NIH Social Media Collaboration Group? They have a Yammer Group and also have just about monthly meetings with different topics. This month the topic is about how to produce a ThunderClap - what is a Thunder Clap you ask? Very briefly it is a tool that allows individuals to sign up their social media accounts that they choose (like FB, Twitter, etc) to make a specific post at a specific time that the Thunderclap organizers provide. It helps get a message out en masse and perhaps have the opportunity to trend.  

Here are the details:

Our next meeting will take place next Tuesday, March 24, 12:30 to 2:00 p.m., and will be a tutorial on launching a Thunderclap. https://www.thunderclap.it/
In a nutshell, a Thunderclap involves getting lots of accounts to send your message to their followers to significantly increase the reach of your messages and people who do not follow you will see it.
 
Our guides will be Brooke Leggin, Office of Women’s Health (Thunderclaps on National Women’s Health Week and National Women and Girls HIV/AIDS Awareness Day), and Kate Perch, who Thunderclapped on behalf of NICHD’s Safe to Sleep anniversary last October: https://www.thunderclap.it/en/projects/17192-safe-sleep-for-baby.
 
Thanks to Audrey Wellons for instigating this topic!!
Please bring your lunch if you’re so inclined.
 
Jeannine @ NHGRI
 
For those who can’t attend in person, the call in number is -- 866-692-3158
Participant pass code: 430-892-3400#
GoToMeeting ID: 314-889-837

Pedestrian Safety Tips

Let’s start with Drivers. Drivers need to recognize the special safety needs of pedestrians, especially those that are children. Young, elderly, disabled, and intoxicated pedestrians are the most frequent victims in auto-pedestrian collisions. Generally, pedestrians have the right-of-way at all intersections; however, regardless of the rules of the road or right-of-way, drivers are obligated to exercise great care and extreme caution to avoid striking pedestrians.

What can drivers do to safely share the road with pedestrians?
•	Look out for pedestrians.  Don’t engage in distracting behaviors while driving.  You can encounter pedestrians anytime and anywhere. They can be very hard to see - especially in bad weather or at night.  
•	Respect crosswalks.  When entering a crosswalk area be prepared to and drive slowly enough, that you can stop if needed.  Don’t block the crosswalk when stopped at a red light or waiting to make a turn. Doing this will force pedestrians to walk in the drive lane. Stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk. 
•	Always watch for children.  Children are the least predictable pedestrians and the most difficult to see. Take extra care to look out for children not only in school zones, but also in residential areas, playgrounds, and parks. 
•	Be extra cautious in school zones.  In a school zone especially when the school zone flashers are blinking, you must slow down and stop to yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a marked crosswalk or at an intersection with no marked crosswalk.  Always stop when directed to do so by a school crossing guard. 

What can a pedestrian do to prevent pedestrian accidents? 
•	Walk on the sidewalk.  Stay on the sidewalk when available and use crosswalks. Avoid walking in traffic where there are no sidewalks or crosswalks.  If you have to walk on a road that does not have sidewalks, walk facing traffic. 
•	Walk defensively - Be prepared for the unexpected.  Don't let cars surprise you even if a motorist does something wrong like running red light or making a sudden turn. Pay attention while walking along roadways. Just like drivers eliminate distracting behaviors. Keep your eyes and your ears open.
•	Cross streets at intersections whenever possible - Look in all directions before entering the street.  Be especially alert to a vehicle that may be turning right on a red signal. If there are marked crosswalks, use them but do not assume that you are completely safe in a marked crosswalk.  Yes you may have the right of way but making sure of your own safety by looking left, then right, and then left again before you step out into the crosswalk can save you a great deal of pain. Pushing your right to the right of way isn’t worth getting hurt in an accident.
•	Be careful in parking lots - Pedestrians are supposed to have the right-of-way in parking lots too but many drivers don't wait for or even see pedestrians.  Parking lots can be more hazardous than streets.  On streets the direction of traffic is usually predictable but in parking lots vehicles might be moving in all directions, including backwards. 
•	Avoid dangerous moves - Any movement a pedestrian makes that drivers are not expecting could be dangerous.  Don't step into traffic from between parked cars since this is a sure way of surprising drivers. 
•	Keep your view of traffic clear at all times - A pedestrian needs to be able to see vehicles around him.  Don't block your view with packages, umbrellas, or other objects.
 
Drivers, keep your mind on your driving and the traffic around you – including pedestrian traffic.  Pedestrians, remember to make eye contact with drivers to ensure they see you.  Crossing safely is up to both of you!

Upcoming Webinar - Invitation to Participate in a National Dialogue and Pilot on Reducing Reporting Compliance for Federal Grant and Contracting Partners

In Spring 2015, the Chief Acquisition Officers Council, General Services Administration, and the Department of Health and Human Services will launch a national dialogue and pilot regarding Section 5 of the Digital Accountability and Transparency Act (DATA Act), with the goal of identifying approaches to reduce the burden and costs associated with reporting and compliance requirements for grant and contractor communities. 

It is widely acknowledged that those receiving Federal tax dollars via grants, loans, contracts, or sub-awards must navigate a complex, burdensome, and costly process to comply with reporting and other requirements while ensuring quality results are delivered for tax dollars investments. Progress was made following the 2014 National Dialogue on streamlining Federal procurement; this year’s dialogue will build on the innovative ideas collected and expand to meet the requirements of the DATA Act.

The DATA Act Section 5 Pilot Team is soliciting the participation of Federal partners receiving grants and contracts in this important initiative. Participation in the pilot will offer organizations a unique opportunity to guide the future of the government-wide implementation of the DATA Act.

To learn more about the pilot, interested organizations are invited to participate in a webinar with the DATA Act Section 5 Pilot Team on April 1, 2015 from 1:00PM to 2:00PM EDT. DATA Act Section 5 Pilot Grants Lead Lora Kutkat and DATA Act Program Management Office Communications Lead Christopher Zeleznik will lead the discussion, sharing the background and goals of the DATA Act Section 5 Pilot, expected outcomes, and participant opportunities and requirements. There will also be ample time to address any questions you might have about the pilot.

Please register online for this informative and interactive event. In the event that you are unable to attend, a recording and documentation from the event will be posted to the Outreach section of www.grants.gov. Questions regarding the DATA Act Session 5 Pilot Webinar may be directed to Emily Gartland at emily.gartland@gsa.gov.

The participation and engagement of our grant and contractor community partners is essential to the success of this pilot. We greatly look forward to working with you on this important initiative.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1918: The U.S. Congress officially establishes time zones and approves daylight saving time. The U.S. was one of the last major countries to adopt the concept of DST;  starting on 30 April 1916, Germany and its World War I ally Austria-Hungary were the first to use daylight savings time (German: Sommerzeit) as a way to conserve coal during wartime. Britain, most of its allies, and many European neutrals soon followed suit. Russia and a few other countries waited until the next year.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e1/Victory-Cigar-Congress-Passes-DST.jpeg

Women’s History Month – 2015 Theme:  Weaving the Stories of Women’s Lives
---
WOMEN’S HISTORY MONTH
Women’s History Month is a celebration which had its origins in 1981, when Congress passed Pub. L. 97-28, authorizing and requesting the President proclaim the week beginning March 7, 1982, as “Women’s History Week.”   From 1982 through 1987, Congress continued to pass joint resolutions designating a week in March as “Women’s History Week.”   In 1987, after being petitioned by the National Women’s History Project, Congress passed Pub. L. 100-9, designating March as “Women’s History Month.”  Since 1995, Presidents Clinton, Bush, and Obama have issued a series of annual proclamations designating the month of March as “Women’s History Month.” The Department of Health and Human Services joins in paying tribute to the generations of women whose individual and collective contributions have helped to shape our world.  The theme for 2015, “Weaving the Stories of Women’s Lives,” presents the opportunity to weave women’s stories into the essential fabric of our nation’s history.  We are also provided an opportunity to acknowledge and celebrate the myriad ways in which women have contributed to our rich and meaningful past.  During this period of celebration, we recognize the extraordinary accomplishments of women throughout the Department of Health and Human Services who have honored their predecessors by continuing the vital work of ensuring quality health care research, services, and accessibility for all Americans. We are grateful for the strides we have made and the challenges we have overcome.  However, we must continue our efforts to work toward true gender equality by bringing more women into science and health professions and extending opportunities for all to realize their fullest potential in our society.  As we celebrate and remember the women who have blazed trails before us, let us pledge with even greater resolve to continue their legacy. History, Art, and Archives – United States House of Representative Publications: The Women’s Right Movement (1848-1920):  http://history.house.gov/Exhibitions-and-Publications/WIC/Historical-Essays/No-Lady/Womens-Rights/<http://history.house.gov/Exhibitions-and-Publications/WIC/Historical-Essays/No-Lady/Womens-Rights/%20> Legislative Interests and Achievements:   http://history.house.gov/Exhibitions-and-Publications/WIC/Historical-Essays/No-Lady/Legislative-Interests/ Crafting an Identity:  http://history.house.gov/Exhibitions-and-Publications/WIC/Historical-Essays/No-Lady/Crafting-Identity/ Presidential Proclamation:   http://www.nwhp.org/womens-history-month/presidential-proclamation/

I like WebEx.  It offers three options based on your meeting room capacity requirements: Meeting Center, Training Center, and Event Center. The WebEx Suite allows you to facilitate small, impromptu staff meetings, training sessions, webinars, and large online events. WebEx productivity tools let you integrate your WebEx personal meeting room with Microsoft Outlook to use the “1-Click" feature to invite colleagues to a meeting to share documents, stream and share video, and use other collaboration tools such as annotation.
Other features include:
- Ability to host a meeting with external stakeholders
- HD Video
- Content sharing features
- White boarding feature
- Close Caption features for videos
- Can be used on mobile devices, meaning anyone can join the meeting via their phone, tablet, and laptop or desktop

MS LYNC provides everything Webex provides, including integration with outlook, screen sharing, VOIP, Video chat, whiteboarding, polling, and more.  Even provides URL's for external partners to join via a web app if they don't have Lync installed

We have a couple events coming up that you won't want to miss!
 
March 31, 3:30 to 4:30 PM EST: Yammer Demonstration by HHS Yammer Administrators, available by Adobe Connect; limited seating in RM 5W11. 3:30 to 4:30 PM. Link and call in numbers will be sent closer to the event date.  
 
April 15, 3:30 to 4:30 PM EST: YAM JAM discussion on the 2015 HRSA Awardee Oversight Manual for Project Officers (https://sharepoint.hrsa.gov/GOMRPO/Tools%20Library/Final_2015%20HRSA%20Federal%20Award%20Oversight%20Operations%20Manual_2.18.15.pdf). Staff will present on major updates to the manual, and then we will open up for a facilitated panel discussion, including Project Officer and Grants Management Specialist perspectives, on their roles in grants oversight and monitoring. We will take questions from listeners via the Forum's yammer site. Call in numbers will be sent closer to the event date.

Hi Team

  Is it possible to add a link to objects in my Yammer  'files' container within a posting?

I have excel sheets, pdfs, sas code, pngs, rtfs... in my Yammer files container.

TIA

Hi Roger- Yes this is possible.  All you need to do is click on the link to your file and you will be navigated to the file page.  Each object in your file container has it's own URL.  Copy the URL and you can paste it in your posting.  I like to open up two tabs and toggle between the tabs to perform this task.  This will prevent additional clicks.  Here is an example:
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/11860301

group_name: Cloud Computing/HHS/Cloud Computing Strategy and Implementation
body:
Hi Team

  Local vs Cloud computing for Power SAS Programmers in a non-transactual environment.

    Clould computing has it place but so do power laptops, workstations and desktops.

    Before you jump on the clould for power programming and development consider the
    Reliability, Seviceability, Availability, Performance and Functionality of the Cloud
    vs a local power laptop, desktop or workstation. I also believe the workstation with
    encryption is a more secure enviroment then the cloud.

    My local system is an off lease Dell T7400 purchased for $600.
    from ebay. I added 2 SSD raid 0 arrays on separate channels. I have 64gb ram and dual quad 3.0ghz
    XEONS(8 cores). This is 2008 technology and unfortunately flash drives are hard to find?

    I also have the SAS scallable performance data environment which supports data patitioning and
    mutiple parallel indexing.

    The cloud computer is  5 Unix boxes 3 with 8 quad cores and 256gb ram for a total of
    96 cores and two Boxes with 4 quad cores for an additiona 32 cores, no hyperthreading.
    All available drives are spinning raid 5 SAN drives. There is no scallable data server software,
    like Netezza, Greenplum or the SAS SDS. Currently the clould
    cannot sort a table over 333gb. I can sort a larger tables on my workstation.
    Intersystem data transfer rate in the cloud is capped at 12gbs?

    Other restrictions on Clould environment. 0.5gb ram per SAS process, max on 12 concurrent SAS processes.
    Down approximately 30 days a year. Does not support a SAS workspace over 1TB and cannot
    sort a table over 333gb. Certain memory intensive summaries run forever in the clould but
    complete in hours on my workstation. Proc distinct when the levels do not fit in memory and
    SAS pages it brains out(0.5gb ram).

    Big Data vs Small data

       The clould shines when accessing big data, defined as ANY SINGLE TABLE OVER A TERABYTE.
       RAID 5 and data backups are also a strong point for clould services with petabytes of data.
       The clould is best as a data server when extracts are processed locally by power programmers.

       But for tables less than a terabyte my old power workstation is at least an
       order of magnitude faster. RAID 0 is ok because the clould has the source data.

       Newer workstations appear to be at least twice as fast as my old T7400.

This was a significant development towards the building of skyscrapers; moving at a speed of 40 feet per minute, acceptance of this safe mode of transport turned a corner, making them a must-have as the Industrial Revolution kicked into high gear.

We use Adobe Connect with no problems. We can add in videos, share pdfs, ppt documents as well as share screens. We use it for everything from staff meetings to remote speaking engagements and grantee webinars. We've tinkered with all of the discussion/collaboration features (poll questions, notes, chat, q&a, etc.). Reviewing/editing fo the recording is easy, you're able to email the chat and notes transcript directly to you directly from those individual pods. The tutorial videos are very helpful but with anything the more you use it the better you're able to navigate and incorporate different features. And it's easy to teach others how to use the basic features.

You will often find that "Scope" (upper case) is sometimes the high level description that is part of an IDIQ to frame what the task orders should look like.  Then it is also used at one level below the "Statement" to generally describe the "scope" (lower case) of the work to be performed.  These words are often interchanged and sometimes mis-applied, but then again, that isn't a new phenomenon in organizations.

It determine where you are flexible and where your muscles are tight and causing issues. It also determines where you need to build strength. Based off of the results they (those who work at the gym) build a workout regiment for you.

Hello,
 
You are receiving this announcement because you are currently in the Yammer Community Manager (CM) Group.  Your commitment to helping expand Yammer across HHS has reaped benefits and shown the need to:
- Formalize the CM role (providing a length of time for this role, setting clear expectations for this role, and guidance on how you can best contribute on a monthly basis)
- Provide official recognition for the Community Manager role (Certificate that goes into your SF50 file at the end of the performance year)
- Expand the use of Yammer across HHS (now that we have a great baseline, let’s make our agency-wide social media tool more creative and effective) 
 
As a current Community Manager, would you like to continue to be a CM for this new performance year?  See the new guidelines below and respond to this post or email YammerAdmins@hhs.gov (mailto:YammerAdmins@hhs.gov) by March 30th.  After that date, we will send a note out to the all company feed to recruit new CMs.  We would love your creativity and commitment this year.  Volunteer and bring a friend!
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
HHS Connects (Yammer) is about connecting people across HHS, not just a new technology.  The Community Manager brings the goal of cross-Operating and Staffing division connection to life through tasks that help build community, strengthen networks, and provides consistency of process.
 
A Yammer community manager   
- Understands company culture & strategic business initiatives
- Drives engagement activities
- Models great behaviors gardening the HHS network (e.g., highlight activities in their OpDiv that may be of interest to the entire Department, respond to posts, tag interesting posts for easy searching, answer Yammer questions)
- Serves as a Yammer subject matter expert for your OPDIV and HHS
Benefits if you become a Community Manager:
- Exclusive training on how to use Yammer.  Learn something new!
- Official recognition in your SF-50 with a memo and certificate recognizing you as a HHS Community Manager who  contributed the overall success of HHS communications and social innovation.
- Opportunity to Interact with leadership and people across HHS you normally wouldn’t be exposed to
- Ability to shape how Yammer is used across HHS (the only technology outside of email that is available across the agency)
- Be the in the know!  Have a broader sense on what is going on in your group and across HHS
- Diversify your current work experience
Role Duration:
- One year (can continue every year or help find a replacement after the one-year term)
Time Requirements:
- 1-3 hours a week
Experience Needed:
- None (you will be trained)
Requirements of the Community Manager role:
1. Post something relevant to HHS Connects (Yammer) from your organization once a week
2. Be a Yammer SME / go-to for your organization
3. Ensure questions asked via posts are answered by connecting questions with people who may have answers
4. Organize Yam Jams / drive engagement activities using Yammer
5. Tag posts for easy searching
6. Share your experience once a month at a ½  hour meeting with Community Managers across HHS

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), DATA Act PMO  invites you to participate in the DATA Act Section 5 Grants Pilot Boot Camp where you can learn about the Department’s efforts to implement Section 5 of the Digital Accountability and Transparency Act of 2013 (DATA Act), P.L. 113-101. The DATA Act requires the Federal Government, among other things, to establish a pilot program to facilitate the development of recommendations for standardized reporting elements across the Federal Government; the elimination of unnecessary duplication in financial reporting; and the reduction of compliance costs for recipients of Federal awards.

The Office of Management and Budget tasked the Department with providing tactical leadership and serving as the executing agent to establish a pilot program under Section 5 of the DATA Act for federal grants. 

Register for the DATA Act Grants Pilot Boot Camp to learn more about HHS’ efforts! You can register for the Boot Camp by contacting Lora Kutkat at LK82g@nih.gov. This is an internal meeting for HHS personnel only. 

Location: Humphrey Building, Room 537H, 200 Independence Avenue, SW
March 31, 2015
10 am to 12:30 pm

SharePoint 2013 Search - Part 4
Searching File Shares

You can also search files shares for content and information using SharePoint search. To setup file share search, follow these steps:

1. Open SharePoint Central Administration site.

2. Click General Application Settings.

3. Click Farm Search Administration.

4. Click Search Service Application.

5. Click Content Sources under Crawling in the left side menu.

6. Click New Content Source.


7. In Name field, enter FSSearch. In Content Source Type select File Shares. In Start Addresses type the file share that you want to search. In Crawl Settings, you have two options. You can crawl the main folder and all subfolders or you can crawl only the main folder. Choose your preferred option. In Crawl Schedules, click Create Schedule under Full Crawl and setup a schedule. Click OK.

8. On Manage Content Sources  page, right-click FSSearch content source and select Start Full Crawl. It will take some time for the crawling to complete depending on the amount of data in the file share.

9. Once the crawl is complete, go to SharePoint site and create search and search results pages. I will not repeat the steps in this section. Once you have created and configured the search pages, try out the search. Just remember one thing, you have to add contentsource:fssearch in the Query text box in the search results web part. FSSearch is the name of the content source you created in the previous step. By adding this content source in the Query text you limit the results to this content source only. See previous section for details if you have any confusion. You will see results for your searched term on a SharePoint page. This functionality is really useful for companies that hesitate in bringing all data from file shares into SharePoint. Some companies avoid it because of the storage costs and other limitations. SharePoint allows you to search files that are sitting outside SharePoint but still can be indexed and surfaced within SharePoint sites.

Business Connectivity Services is a centralized infrastructure in SharePoint 2013 and Office 2013 that supports integrated data solutions. SharePoint 2013 acts as an interface that you can use to surface data from external data sources. Enterprises do not store their data in one location. Enterprises use myriad of data sources and applications with each application connected to a separate data source. Before Business Connectivity Services, surfacing data from different sources was not easy and required lot of effort and custom programming.

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33043542

SharePoint Business Connectivity Services - Part 3
BCS Login failed for user NT Authority

If you have created an external content type and are trying to access it in a list and get Access Denied that is because you have not given permissions to the logged in user to use that external content type. You can easily give permissions to that user or to all users in your site by going to central administration site and configuring business connectivity service.

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33043819

SharePoint Business Connectivity Services - Part 4
Modifying External Content Type

You can modify external content type if you want to make changes. For example, in the above figure you may have noticed that you only see three records where the country is US. What if you want to show all records? You can remove the filter from the content type.

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33043886

SharePoint Business Connectivity Services - Part 5
Business Data List Web Part

Now that you have learned how to setup Business Connectivity Services, you will learn how to use Business Data list web part to show external data on any SharePoint page  you want.

Department of Justice FOIA SUCCESS STORIES

Department of Health and Human Services (HHS):  Improving Proactive Disclosures through Postings on Hot Topics and Greater Collaboration

During 2014, the Department fielded many information requests regarding unaccompanied children entering the United States.  HHS's Administration for Children and Families' (ACF) FOIA Office worked with the agency's Office of Public Affairs, its program office, and the web team to ensure that information on this topic was posted and regularly updated.  ACF maintained a web page where it posted regular updates of information such as where children were released to sponsors, a breakdown by country of origin, copies of forms, a factsheet, and FAQs.  The content of this webpage was chosen based on the nature and number of inquiries received by the FOIA Office and the press office.  The result was a 75% drop in FOIA requests for the information posted.

Point and shoot programming.

This message is in

    utl_PerPacMsg.txt

    https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33108749

There are three ways to fast programming

 1. Point and shoot with mouse actions(fastest)  ie push middle mouse button proc means hi-lited dataset
 2. Point and shoot with the keyboard      ie hit F2 after dataset hi-lite for proc means
 3. Point and shoot with the command line. ie type avgh on command line after hi-liting dataset

This type of 'fast' programming is only supported by the old display manager text editor(not EE) with the simple
clean command line on all windows.
How to map macros to the mouse and keyboard and remember actions to follow,

You need to download  the command macros and include the package.

    utl_perpac.sas

    https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33108752

Here is what is in the package  (* most used or most critical)

  avgh     proc means last dataset
  cnt      cnt name*sex - last dataset number unique combinations
  cnth     cnt name*sex - hi-lited dataset
  cntv     cnt hilited ariavle last dataset
  con      contents last dataset
  conh     contents hi-lited dataset
 *debugh   macro debug hi-lited
 *dmp      contents with sample data
 *dmph     contents with sample data hi-lited dataset
 *frq      freq sex*age last dataset
 *frqh     freq sex*age hi-lited dataset
  frqv     freq hilited variable last dataset
  iota     column of consecutive integers
 *ls40     40 obs last dataset
 *ls40h    40 obs hi-lited dataset
  lsal     all obs last dataset
  parh     does hi-lited code have matched paraentheses
  proch    syntax for the proc - hi-lite 'proc reg' and get syntax with example
 *prtw     prtw 'sex="M"' - last dataset subset printed
 *prtwh    prtw 'sex="M"' - hi-lited dataset subset printed
  sumh     statistics on hi-lited column of numbers
  sumv     statistics on hi-lited variable last dataset
  unv      proc univariate on variable in last dataset
  vu       viewtable last dataset
  vuh      viewtable hi-lited dataset
 *xlsh     view and edit hi-lited dataset in excel (may need a sleep w slow systems)
 *xplo     xplo SUBaSUM put exploded chars in past buffer


Note '?' on the command line retrieves previous commands.

***************************************************************************;

Example 1.  Which line in the macro is causing the error.

 In the macro below variable 'name' is a character but a numeric variaqble is needed.
 However SAS reports the error on the invocation line '%errmke'. We want SAS
 to tell us which line inside the macro is causing the problem.


 %macro errmke(dummy);
     data class;
        set sashelp.class(obs=1);
        if name=2 then sex='M';
     run;quit;
  %mend errmke;

  %errmke;

 If you highlight the macro with invocation and type debugh you will see the following
 in the log. Note SAS has identifies line 1403 columg 4 (position of name varable)
 as the issue.


 1401 +data class;
 1402 +set sashelp.class(obs=1);
 1403 +if name=2 then sex='M';
 ERROR: Character value found where numeric value needed at line 1403 column 4.
 1404 +run;

*****************************************************************************;

Example 2. I would like to view and edit the dataset in excel

  data class;
     set sashelp.class;
  run;quit;

  Highlight class and type xlsh on the command line


******************************************************************************;
