ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1899: Guglielmo Marconi,  Italian inventor and electrical engineer known for his pioneering work on long-distance radio transmission, made the first wireless transmission from France to England. A message was sent 32 miles from Wimereaux near Boulogne, France, to the South Foreland lighthouse near Dover, England. This became an important alternative to laying undersea cables for telegraphy.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/76/Guglielmo_Marconi_1901_wireless_signal.jpg

OK, for the sake of discussion, here is the new guidance from the AP Stylebook on how to refer to the ACA. 

"Affordable Care Act

   "Shorthand for the formal title of the health care overhaul that President Barack Obama signed into law in 2010. Its full name is Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Use President Barack Obama's health care law or the health care law on first reference. "Obamacare" in quotation marks is acceptable on second reference. Affordable Care Act can be used on subsequent references when necessary to refer to the law, but should be used sparingly. Polling indicates that not all Americans know the law by its formal name."
How do your offices require you to refer to the ACA on first and subsequent references?

SAS DISPLAY MANAGER COMMANDS AND SCRIPTS USING THE OLD TXT EDITOR

This message is at

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33353103

 I have posted command macros, function keys and mouse actions for
 a fast development environment

 Below are some other features of the old text editor not available
 in recent Enhanced and Super Enhanced SAS editors.

   Very fast point and shoot editing and code submit in the old text editor.

   suppose you have submit on the right mouse button

   keydef RMB log;clear;out;clear;pgm;submit;home;rec;home;log;z;z;

   Use the ALT key as you hold down the mouse button and drag the mouse
   to select a rectangular block (or column) of te

   After the highlight above hit the right mouse button and the highlighted code will
   be executed.

   Simple actions like typing 860 on the command line will take to line
   860. On long programs I sometimes jot down the location of
   key lines.


   USEFUL EDITIONG COMMANDS
   *************************


  The prefix area  Many of these commands can be put on function keys using a ':', ie :ts.

  D99----  Delete next 99 lines (also could cut with mouse)
  I999---  Insert 999 blank lines useful when autoadd is set
  IB55---  Insert 55 lines before
  C3-----  Copy next three lines to some target
  A000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy after)
  B000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy before)
  M------  Move this line somewhere
  M3-----  Move next 3 lines somewhere
  O3-----  Move source lines over these lines
  R3-----  Replicate the next 3 lines

  DD00103  Block delete   CC00103  Block Copy    MM00103  Block Move
  0000104                 0000104                0000104
  DD-----                 CC-----                MM-----

  OO00103  Target Over    RR3----  Block Replicate
  0000104                 0000104
  OO-----                 RR-----

  (4-----  Shift left first 4 columns into bit bucket (distructive shift)
  )4-----  Shift right first 4 columns (distructive shift)
  >5-----  Nondistructive shift right
  <5-----  Nondistructive shift left
  >>5----  Non distructive shift right of a block of commands
  0000101
  0000102
  >>-----
  <<,)),(( Similar to single character versions
  UC----- Upper case line  - more useful on function key as :UC
  UC26--- Upper case next 26 lines
  LC----- Lower case line
  LC26
  LLC---- Block of lines -lower caSE
  UUC
  TF----- Text flow lines until blank line
  TS----- Text split at cursor better on function key as :tf
  MASK - BUILD TEMPLATE FOR ENTERING DATA


   no need to look up a P-Value
   put this on any command line
   %put %sysfunc(probnorm(1.96)); /* try this on command line */

   ?          - previous command history
   subtop     - submit top line of editor
   icon
   rchange    - change on function key hit
   rfind      - find on function key hit
   save  prg       /# save program in your profile  ie pgm.source #/
   copy  prg       /# recalls program from your profile #/
   change     - c today yesterday ic all   ( ignore case all)
   cols
   reset
   keys
   top
   bot
   n           - go to line n
   left  n
   right  n
   spell all - check spelling of all words in editor
   autoadd   - add aline at a time to editor ( usewith mask and bounds )
   vscroll 25 - set scroll amounts for forward and backward
   hscroll 10
   backward max n
   forward max  n
   bounds
   mask
   copy
   paste
   find - f 'data' first last next prev prefix suffix word
   find 'Mac' prefix
   change - c todat yesterday ic all
   rchange - change on function key hit
   rfind   - find on function key hit
   mark - highlight string, lines for submit or edit
   mark block - highlight rectangle within editor
                does not have to be full lines
   store
   zoom z
   up 2
   down 4
   CAPS on/off
   home
   cursor
   nums on/off
   %let
   vt
   pmenu off /# functon key #/
   pmenu on
   end
   print
   submit
   unmark unmark all
   tabs
   redo
   nums on/off
   fse
   fsv
   fsb
   libn
   filen
   fslist
   vt
   print

Some insights from Harvard Business Review (HBR) on some benefits of online collaboration, and the types of work/projects that may benefit more from online collaboration than face to face. This paragraph reminded me of something [User:1489919592:shawnhumphrey]  from sharing with [User:1490411828:sauerbach1] and [User:1489534424:sandrascarbrough-guest]  yesterday when we were talking about Introverts and Online Collaboration Tools - "A final benefit of online collaboration is the ability to accommodate a wider range of communication and working styles. If you’re the kind of person who always speaks up in meetings (guilty as charged), the traditional workplace may work just great for you. But you’re missing out on the perspective and talents of people who like to mull on a problem before contributing, or that of people who communicate better visually or in writing than they do out loud." On my team we've been looking at different ways of working together, using strength, considering communication styles, and looking at having better - and perhaps less - meetings.  I like the concept that online collaboration isn't supposed to be a substitute to in person or face to face - but rather addresses some needs for communication, collaboration, cooperation and specific types of project work that haven't been met well previously. What do you think?     https://hbr.org/2015/04/collaborating-online-is-sometimes-better-than-face-to-face

Check out this article. What do you think? Are there ways we could be working together a little differently to reduce email and meeting time burdens by using online collaboration tools a little more purposefully?

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Drum Roll Please: The answer to our Poll Question is: 

Draw Down Restriction is a Term!

Here's Why:  At HRSA, due to the EHB system functionality, DDR is a term on the NoA.  Conditions create a specific due date for required recipient information.  Since HRSA does not dictate when a recipient must make a payment request, a term is placed on the NoA stating the reason for the restriction and providing instruction for submitting a prior approval request when reimbursement is needed.  Therefore,  DDR operates much like a condition of award because the system requires recipients to send in a prior approval request in order to draw down funds.

HHS Connects (Yammer) is about connecting people across HHS, not just a new technology.  The Community Manager brings the goal of cross-Operating and Staffing division connection to life through tasks that help build community, strengthen networks, and provides consistency of process.
 
Benefits if you become a Community Manager:
- Exclusive training on how to use Yammer.  Learn something new!
- Official recognition in your SF-50 with a memo and certificate recognizing you as a HHS Community Manager who  contributed the overall success of HHS communications and social innovation.
- Opportunity to Interact with leadership and people across HHS you normally wouldn’t be exposed to
- Ability to shape how Yammer is used across HHS (the only technology outside of email that is available across the agency)
- Be the in the know!  Have a broader sense on what is going on in your group and across HHS
- Diversify your current work experience
Role Duration:
- One year (can continue every year or help find a replacement after the one-year term)
Time Requirements:
- 1-3 hours a week
Experience Needed:
- None (you will be trained)
Requirements of the Community Manager role:
1. Post something relevant to HHS Connects (Yammer) from your organization once a week
2. Be a Yammer SME / go-to for your organization
3. Ensure questions asked via posts are answered by connecting questions with people who may have answers
4. Organize Yam Jams / drive engagement activities using Yammer
5. Tag posts for easy searching
6. Share your experience once a month at a ½  hour meeting with Community Managers across HHS
Next Steps: 
- Reply to this post with your interest OR send an email to Yammeradmins@HHS.gov (mailto:Yammeradmins@HHS.gov)
- Deadline is Wednesday, April 8th.  
Looking forward to hearing from you!

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Volunteers Needed: 

The HRSA PO and OFAM Forum (Forum) was designed to cut across silos and create a larger community of staff involved in grants administration. The Forum leverages staff expertise and partnerships from all across HRSA. In this spirit, a cross-agency work group is being formed to provide strategic direction and input into the Forum.  We are looking for Bureau/program staff who can provide a fresh perspective on grants administration and support agency-collaboration/ communication. If you are interested or want to hear more about this opportunity, please contact [User:1490411828:sauerbach1] at sauerbach1@hrsa.gov.

In case you haven’t heard, Capital Camp and Drupal GovDays have combined and are now Drupal GovCon.  This year’s conference is July 22 - 24, 2015 at the NIH Campus in Bethesda, MD.  Dries Buytaert, Drupal founder and lead developer, will be keynoting. The event is free, but registration is required. Hope to see some of you there.

online is definetely the world we live in now for collaboration. i like the fact that our taem doesn't need to be in the same room to get things done. We'll all meeting and focusing on the problem regardless of where we are physically. However in regards to different personality types i actually think that sometimes online collaboration can be more detrimental to introverts. Because you can't use body language to gauge reaction all the time, when they are thinking it appears to others that they are just being silent and have nothing to offer. I've had to adjust in some meetings based on these learned cues for individuals.

Hi everyone, I wanted to make sure you had seen the recent article from the Partnership for Public Service highlighting the HHS IDEA Lab http://bestplacestowork.org/BPTW/index.php (I've also uploaded the article to the files section of this site.

I think its critical to have a mix of meeting types when you work with a group. I work much better online with people that I schedule face-to-face meetings with as well. I get to know the people in the face-to-face meetings in a way that translates to how I interact with them online that is invaluable. 

I agree that it takes getting used to some silence on a conference call or online meeting when thinking is happening. But  like I said, the better I understand how my colleagues think and work, the more I can adjust my behavior online...and face-to-face as well. 

Listening is a skill we all need to work on and there is something about online meetings that really force you to listen in a way that face-to-face doesn't. And though I agree with Alice that the lack of body language may hinder an introvert, the shield of a computer may also encourage someone to speak up who may not otherwise.

It should be noted that its much easier to have an online meeting when everyone is online instead of a mix of online and face-to-face and I think our group is getting much better about setting those up when they can.

Has anyone ever created a purchase vehicle for productized services?  In this vision, let's say one would buy Small Needs Analysis which could be defined as review of 2 hours to understand project, development of a 10 question interview template, 5 1- hour stakeholder interviews, and a 1 hour presentation on results.  If you need 12 stakeholder interviews, you buy the Medium Needs Analysis package instead because it includes up to 15 interviews.   I see it as similar to healthcare -- instead of paying for the surgeon, the hospital, the radiologist, etc., you pay a fixed fee for the knee replacement operation.  Any thoughts?

I would point out too that this isn’t just about online meetings versus in person meetings – there is an aspect of the work being done online through collaboration tools asynchronously – in other words NOT at the same time.  Extends the “meeting” work overs a span of time to allow for that thinking and consideration, perhaps could help to keep the talkers from dominating the “think” process. Maybe even reconsider what HAS to be decided in a meeting atmosphere versus what pre-thinking or tossing around of thoughts could be done prior to decision go –time.

Report Details Public's Hopes, Fears About Using Data to Improve Health 

http://www.rwjf.org/en/about-rwjf/newsroom/newsroom-content/…
 
Washington, D.C.—An independent advisory committee, with support from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF), today released Data for Health, Learning What Works. The report gives an overview of the insights, concerns, and ideas that communities shared during “listening sessions” about how to harness data to improve health. Local leaders, residents, and professionals from a wide range of sectors offered thoughts on what data was important to them for improving health in their communities and what is needed to facilitate useful data sharing. The listening sessions took place in five cities across the country in late 2014.
Please count me in for this exciting and wonderful opportunity. Thanks!

Project Structure with Tokens and self locating files

for a clean version of this message:
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/33631508

This really only works with the old text editor
because durring development a
program can easily be 10,000 lines
and many macros. Only the old text editor can
instantly go to a macro line instantly. You need a prefix area.
Alos EG is just too slow to handle 10,000 lines of code.
EG is like dial up from home?

Whenever I start a new project I create a unique three letter token,
for the Fabulous Fab Detergent Campaign, I might use fab as the token.

fab is then used in all correspondence, all inputs, outputs
temp data...

I generally start out with an initial sas file named

fab_000Drv;

fab_000Drv is what I call the driver program,

Drv is arbitrary

The first section in the fab_000Drv program might be

%macro fab_100GetDat
...
%mend fab_100Get Dat;

all outputs of fab_100GetDat macro would have the names like

fab_100GetDatDem.sas7bdat
fab_100GetDatDem.xls
fab_100GetDatDem.ppt
...

These are self locating files because the directory
where the outputs are stored are in the file name.

fab_100GetDatDem.xls   is stored in c:/fab/xls/
fab_100GetDatDem.ppt   is stored in c:/fab/ppt/

One exception all SAS objects are stored

fab_100GetDatDem.sas7bdat  c:\fab

the next sections might be macros

%macro fab_100GetDat;
...
%macro fab_200SumDat;
...
%macro fan_300Findat;

at the end of the large driver program
would be the real driver

%fab_100GetDat;
%fab_200SumDat;
...
%fan_300Findat;

When I move the project into production I put each
macro in c:\fab\oto and keep just the
driver part in fab_000Drv with extensive header..

I use a very flat filesystem for my projects.
After the project is finished and the project is
readonly, I add descriptions to the folder names
and sometimes move stuff around


I usually just add description.
Sometimes I

ie rename fab to fab_FabulousFabDetergentCampaign_20150630

C:\fab
   +---cfg
   +---csv
   +---dat
   +---dic
   +---doc
   +---htm
   +---log
   +---lst
   +---mdb
   +---msg  Emails
   +---ora
   +---oto  Autocall macros
   +---pdf
   +---png
   +---pl_
   +---ppt
   +---prl PERL stuff programs in SAS
   +---rtf
   +---rda R workspaces all programs in SAS
   +---readme
   +---sas
   +---sav SPSS data
   +---sql
   +---txt
   +---utl
   +---vdo Validation and Verification voodoo output
   +---wpd WPS datasets
   +---xls
   \---zip

Anthony, I liked it and am even more impressed that this is your first attempt -!!  It also makes me wonder if MY agency is going to bar-code.  I will mention a couple of tiny typos - only because your work is worth it.  Beyond that, aside from the clever use of graphics, before-after, etc. really liked how you came out and said this could be kind of fun - certainly more fun I imagine, than rooting through half-torn cardboard boxes on the 6th set of shelves, 8 feet up and toward the back ;'] for a report that looks sadly like so many many others?  My humble addition re typos (because I used to write/edit for a living);  (1) on 'challenge 2' slide - I think you meant associateD  (2) on 'what people had to say' slide - First quote - Verb tense seems to fluctuate but hey someone else said this so I'd leave it alone too, but please make it 'AN electronic scan' (3) same slide (and keep in mind, I'm not a morning person) - 2nd quote - I didn't quite understand the point being made by the phrase '....many more tools' etc.  Maybe include the rest of that sentence or add a couple of words to clarify.  Beyond that, I was delighted to see you using a bit of 'sell copy' to engage your trainees, for instance, making sure they understand the value of this new tool to begin with. Actually, I spent more time reading this than expected because you made it interesting. Future generations will revere you !

Our template mirrors slide 10 pretty well already, but for government work I think it could be especially handy to have the organization spelled out. We also added in a "unique facts" field which I don't feel strongly about either way. It may capture useful notes or elements that the other fields don't, but we could cut it and add in the "current project knowledge" from slide 10 (the only thing we're really missing from that slide).

We  need your expertise.  Come on over to College Park for a detail assignment as an Instructional Systems Designer.  Help us get food and feed safety staff across the U.S. ready for the future!
The Center for Applied Safety & Nutrition (CFSAN) is offering multiple detail opportunities. The Details are available immediately for a period of 120 days. A temporary promotion may be considered. This is a Non-Bargaining Unit Position.

Position:                                 Instructional Design and System Specialist GS-11/12/13

Bargaining Unit Status:       Non-Bargaining Unit Position

Duty Location:                      CFSAN, Office of Management
Harvey Wiley Building
5100 Paint Branch Parkway
College Park, MD 

Opening Date:                       March 25, 2015
Closing Date:                        April 8, 2015

Area of Consideration:        HHS-Wide

The Staff College (SC) is responsible for developing, coordinating, and implementing learning events and organizational development programs for the Center and for Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA)-related activities. SC also develops learning goals and objectives; evaluates Center-wide/FSMA training and education needs; plans and implements FSMA learning and the Center’s scientific, technical, legal/regulatory, managerial &supervisory, and applied soft-skill trainings; plans and/or oversees the development and design of course materials; instructs and facilitates individuals and/or groups of employees in specific subjects; identifies and applies new technologies, as appropriate; and develops multi-media learning programs.. 

DUTIES INCLUDE:
•	Plans, coordinates and develops components of instructional design.
•	Advises on feasibility and tradeoffs inherent in different Web technologies; understands the interplay between text, graphics, audio and video and takes responsibility for design and development activities.
•	Resolves issues which are controversial and complicated and may involve coordinating or negotiating matters of considerable consequence to CFSAN and FSMA programs.
•	Develops and applies new program methods, approaches, and technology. 
•	Identifies tasks that can be efficiently and effectively supported by job or skill performance aids.
•	Applies a systems approach to training and instructional design.
•	Partners effectively with training specialists, vendors, CFSAN Offices and subject matter experts (SMEs) 

DESIRED QUALIFICATIONS INCLUDE:
•	Knowledge of performance/instructional technology principles including the ability to analyze, select, understand, and evaluation training methods, media and materials. 
•	Knowledge of technology-based learning environments to leverage current and emerging learning technologies.
•	Skill in developing courses using a variety of mechanisms and software including Authorware, Toolbook, Protools, Sound Designer, and Premiere.  
•	General understanding of learning systems functions and specific knowledge of all components in the FDA learning environment.
•	Knowledge of typical problems in the FDA learning environment and their symptoms and causes.
•	Competence in use of diagnostic tools/test equipment in the FDA instructional design environment.
•	Knowledge of appropriate data collection and search methods. 
•	Ability to communicate effectively orally and in writing in order to interact with staff at all levels.
Application Procedures:  

This detail opportunity is open to all qualified candidates. Interested applicants should submit a brief resume or CV; a copy of their most recent SF-50 (Notification of Personnel Action) identifying current pay plan, series, grade, and tenure for the detail to:

Supervisory concurrence is required in order to accept a detail (it is NOT required to apply)

Contact: Donna Snow 	
Title: Program Analyst, Office of Management	

Address:  5100 Paint Branch Parkway, College Park, MD 20740	

Phone:  240-402-3106	

E-mail:  donna.snow@fda.hhs.gov

Tornado Season is Upon Us!

Tornadoes are quick, random, and can be incredibly destructive. One major tornado goes across a corn field one year and another tornado rips through a heavily populated area the next, each with entirely different results. For some of us tornado season has hit early. Tornadoes have already produced damage in Oklahoma.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: This month we will focus on the Objective Review process. Objective Review is part of the application phase of grants management, when applications undergo an evaluation by subject matter experts and are rated according to certain review criteria.  OFAM's Division of Independent Review (DIR) is the lead for HRSA on this process. During the month of April, DIR will provide some helpful tools and fun facts! If you have any questions on Objective Review or want to discuss a particular aspect with our Forum community, this is your opportunity!

For the past few weeks I have been working on a little python utility to convert a CMS BlueButton File in to a structured JSON file. after running a number of tests this utility seems to be ready for wider testing. 

The idea behind this is to give more technically adept beneficiaries (or their caregivers) a way to convert the BlueButton text file in to something that can be imported in to other applications. 

Check out the python code here: 

https://github.com/ekivemark/python-bluebutton 

The code is based on some great work that Alan Viars did a few years ago.

How might this be useful? If you download a BlueButton text file you can convert it to json and then paste that resulting file in to one of a number of online JSON converters. For example if you do a Json to CSV conversion you can then import the resulting file in to Excel and select the columns of data you want to work with.

In terms of they Yammer membership.

I'm only speaking from my own experience, but being extroverted is a skill have had to learn for development. But in group situations that I'm not leading, I find it difficult to contribute. For me, I need time to think about what I want to say and how I want to say it in order to avoid communication problems. I enjoy having the time to research my answers, as well. It's quite difficult for me to recall information that might be more readily available online.

And I think the case can be made to say that being able to find information is more useful now than actually having information. Not that being informed is bad, of course. If I can look up, analyze, and place information in the right context without a lot of on-the-spot pressure, I feel like I'm contributing more.

And I reiterate- just speaking from my own experience! Everyone's experience could be quite different.
They won't be able to get in if they do not have a PIV card and if their NED accounts are deactivated.
Ah, but the Yammer account will still exist... because we keep the information. I guess I didn't think that through. Of course we want the account to still exist.
Yes, the Yammer history  will exist although their profiles will be deleted.
But wait, I think we're missing something here. The deactivation- how is that done?
Is that handled through NED?
I ask because a person has been found to have left yet has an active Yammer ID, or so it's been reported to me.

Oh wow! Turkish Sign is extremely similar to American Sign Language! I recognized many signs, and profoundly rusty in ASL. I suspect they're part of the same language group, French Sign.

Interesting fact- ASL is a branch of the French Sign Language, NOT the version used in the English (UK, not language) deaf community. The British form used in parts of the world are not the same as Americans would know.

We do the deactivation from Yammer. NED does the Deactivation so they can't get into Yammer even if they have an active account in Yammer.  They are both two different systems.  AMS which gets info from NED is the Gate Keeper, NED is where info filters into AMS and Yammer is the final destination.
Yammer or Yammer plug-in is being stupid.  I had to download the document to edit.

Okay. I follow this. So- NED deactivates, it goes through AMS, then on to Yammer. But we still DO deactivations in Yammer, even though they can't get in through NED or AMS. And that would be- manually? Or do you do some sort of bulk push? I used to check bounced emails in NIAID and NIH, but never saw any so I stopped worrying about it.
And though deactivated, their previous posts and history exist.
Well, actually- I just went into NIH and I see now it is automated. After 90 days, they get removed from the system.
Yes, their previous posts do exist.  After 90 days of a Yammer profile being suspended they are auto deleted.
Good deal. Thanks for confirming.

If you've heard me talk about breathing through my heart while thinking about kittens as a method for dealing with difficult people - this HBR article lays out the basic process. I find it to be very effective! The title makes it seem like it is just about dispelling a bad mood, but it is more than that. I learned about it at a presentation on neurobiology and leadership, and it was presented in the context of how to recover from an amygdala hijack (the engaging of the flight or fight response) -  and get back to business.  Try it out! I'm better at doing it when I plan in advance, haven't achieved the in the moment reset yet.

TWO IMPLEMENTATIONS OF THE LEAD FUNCTION IN SAS

  
 data class;

 set sashelp.class end=dne;

 lead=_n_+1;

 if not dne then do;
    set sashelp.class(keep=name rename=name=leadname) point=lead;

    put name leadname;
 end;

 run;

The NIH Library is once again hosting the Drupal Government conference, now called Drupal GovCon.  It will be July 22-24, 2015 in Natcher (Building 45).  This free conference will feature over a hundred breakout sessions and three exciting keynote speakers including Dries Buytaert, creator of Drupal and CTO/Co-founder of Acquia. 

We want to have a good representation of the great Drupal work being done at NIH so we are looking for session submission ideas.  Unfortunately, time is running out since submissions are due this Friday (April 10th)!

We encourage submissions on any Drupal topic and have specific tracks lined upon focused on:

- Drupal Business, Non-Profit and Government
- Case Studies
- Configuration, Testing and Site Building
- Code and Development
- Design and User Experience
- Security

In order to submit a session or register for the conference, go to: https://www.drupalgovcon.org/.

REMINDER: YAM JAM/ASK GRANTS SESSION

APRIL 15, 2015 from 3:30 to 4:30 PM EST

CALL IN:  1 (888) 390-1272, Participant Passcode:  1885349   

TOPIC: Federal Award Oversight Manual for Project Officers - 2015 Updates and Panel Discussion on HRSA's Team Approach to Program Oversight

GUEST  PANELISTS: Rick Goodman, OFAM Associate Administrator; Bryan Rivera, Team Lead, Division of Grants Management Operations; and Dalana Johnson, Project Officer, BPHC, Pat Lockett, Director, HLI; Suzanne Auerbach, Special Assistant/PO and OFAM Forum Community Manager.  

POST YOUR QUESTIONS! We will take questions from listeners via the Forum's site during the event. Also, you can post your questions in advance to the Forum for discussion. Please let us know what you want to hear about!

RESOURCES: Please review the two resources attached below in preparation for this session: 1) 2015 HRSA Federal Award Oversight Manual; and 2) Summary of PO and GMS Responsibilities.

Looking for Experts on Open SSL for https configuration?

Hi!  I am running an apache MacOS X based webserver that could use a bit of input from an expert with Open SSL... I understand that I need to reconfigure apache's conf file and load the appropriate module, as well as to change some parameters in the 'Sites' directory to run https, but, I am insecure about obtaining a certificate...

Is there someone out there that has done this before that can hold my hand? 

[User:1500676700:bertgold]

One of the questions that came up yesterday was how soon your pension starts arriving after you retire. I posed this question to our recently retired colleague Janet, who was in FERS. This is what she emailed back to me. "I got my first interim payment 5.5 weeks after my last work day. When you would get your first payment depends on what day of the month you retire. Since I retired on the last day of January, my pension started on Feb. 1. Don't forget you'll also get your last paycheck, which will include your lump sum for unused annual leave, so that helps tide you over until your pension checks start.
When you retire, you might want to take some time for yourself to adjust and kick back. I seem to have a dread of not having stuff to do, so I signed up for a course and volunteered for several different organizations, on top of the things I'm already doing. I'm so busy now, finding time to do stuff around the house is ludicrously difficult." She said she adopted a reforestation site at Sligo Creek Park among her many endeavors!

It was discovered in March 2008 in an archive in Paris by a group of American audio historians. This predates Edison’s invention of the phonograph by nearly two decades.

Shawn, what you may have seen were "auto-generated" captions, which uses Google's/YouTube's speech recognition software to create draft transcripts on the fly and are sometimes an agency's way of fulfilling their obligation, although it doesn't actually work well or consistently.  In this case, it seems that HHS may be working on proper captions, although that doesn't address audio-description, which is a requirement for making videos accessible to persons who are blind or have low-vision.

I too noticed that YT captioning was off the mark, but I was able to follow the story with the sound turned off.  Can anyone recommend a DIY audio-description service/tool that can be integrated with YT?

MAGpie, from WGBH, seems to be the only application with the specific capability of adding audio-description, per se, although anything that allows a narration to be added to a video would possibly work.
It starts at 12 PM CDT / 11 AM MDT.

Online SAS Tutorials "Advanced Programming Path."

Here is a link to the home page for these tutorials:  

http://web.utk.edu/sas/OnlineTutor/1.2/en/60477/index.htm.  

(I am sorry I do not know how to use tinyurl or its other counterparts.)
 
You have to have licensed the Online Tutorial in your SAS Installation to use the actual datasets for your 
own code on the "Try It" pages of each lesson.  To see if you have the license:
 
Go to "Help-Learning SAS Programming" in your SAS Session
 Click on OK on the dialog box that pops up
 
If you see an note in your SAS Log that the Sample datasets and 
files are ready, then you have licensed the Online Tutorial.
 
This was a hidden gem that I did not know until Roland posted his 
message and I did some exploring.

We use the full range of collaboration tools available within SharePoint 2013 that are made available on our Project Sites, created when a Project Professional 2013 schedule is published to Project Server 2013 with the "create project site" option selected.  That includes blogs, wikis, document libraries, lists (as in Risk List/Registry), and meeting sub-sites.  These are all provided within a FedRamp-approved hosting company through our GovZone program and contract.

NTEU has updated its Member Benefits Guide to include all of the discounted products and services that are currently available to NTEU members.

This guide only contains general information about each of the many benefits that are available.  Members will still need to log in to the NTEU web site and visit the Member Benefits page to obtain contact information, codes, or coupons needed to take advantage of these benefits.

Although I attached an electronic copy of the Member Benefits Guide here, it is also on the NTEU web site under “Union Office,” “Fliers,” and “Member-only Benefits.” This is the area of the NTEU web site that contains all of the fliers relating to Member Benefits, and the Member Benefits Guide is available for printing or downloading from this page.  As new discounts and benefits become available, NTEU National will place an updated copy on the web site.  So visit the web site periodically to ensure that you are distributing the most up-to-date copy of the guide.

If you have any questions or need any additional information concerning this updated guide, please let me know.

Hey HRSA OFAM , Bureaus and Offices!  I’m posting the Reviewer Specification Form and Projects Officers (PO) Reviewer Recruitment Module (RRM) Manual for your use and or edification.  The Review Administrators (RA) in DIR use the information to query RRM for potential reviewers and chairpersons for each FOA. Once a sufficient number of reviewers and chairs indicate their interest and availability for an upcoming objective review, the PO and RA can go to RRM and review the qualifications of each reviewer.

Enlightening Thanks

Most of the graphics later in the presentation can be produced with minimal code using R or SAS.

SOAPBOX ON
As smart as point and click can be, it will never be as flexible as a program built using Knuth's 7 basic building block instructions. Third and Fourth generation systems like SAS and R form functions from these instructions that simplify programming.

Point and click can get you started, especially if the point and click can produce the background code that the programmer can enhance.  SAS can do this.
SOAPBOX OFF

I have no association with SA or R.
Share!

We use Hootsuite to manage the @FDA_MCMi  Twitter account. I've added a Hootsuite stream for Yammer, and can immediately see how it will help me better keep up with Yammer conversations. 

Our Twitter stream mostly targets a niche audience (people interested in medical countermeasures against chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear threats, and emerging diseases), so I don't think automatically posting every tweet to Yammer would be a good idea. However, we may want to occasionally cross-post items with broader appeal.
Bldg 33 Admin meeting 04/10/2015

I'd like to Echo [User:1505409154:aprilfinnen]'s comment--the audience for our @NCIEpi Twitter account is also pretty specialized (researchers in cancer epidemiology and genomics) and there aren't really any relevant Yammer groups that we would post to.

That said, if you use Hootsuite a lot (and I do!) it could be a great way to keep up with what's happening in your groups (instead of email notifications), better share with other communications colleagues, and keep up to date on any relevant *Yammer* content that might be useful for posting to other channels.

Charlson Comorbidity Index

R is heavily used in clinical programming. Here is a R package and some SAS macros.

http://tinyurl.com/n956ooj

Package ‘medicalrisk’
February 20, 2015
Type Package
Title Medical Risk and Comorbidity Tools for ICD-9-CM Data
Version 1.1
Date 2015-01-04
Description Generates risk estimates and comorbidity flags from ICD-9-CM
codes available in administrative medical datasets. The package supports
the Charlson Comorbidity Index, the Elixhauser Comorbidity
classification, the Revised Cardiac Risk Index, and the Risk Stratification
Index. Methods are table-based, fast, and use the plyr package, so
parallelization is possible for large jobs. Also includes a sample of
real ICD-9 data for 100 patients from a publicly available dataset.

Efficient DBMS extracts using SAS

SAS will try to pass the where clause to Oracle and Teradata
but only th functions below will work.

This message is also on yammer. I tried something new clicking on attach. Hope the linke id below if not this messsage is
in utl_efficient_DBMS_extracts

I like to use the where clause with the set statement dataset optons.

For inner joins the where clause is always
right after the from clause. The order of clauses is

Some(select) French(from) Women(where) Grow(Group By) Hairy(Having) Oranges(Order By)

as a side note the oder of Keep Rename Where statements is
Kissing Ripe Watermellons

Whenever possible, SAS/ACCESS passes WHERE clauses to the DBMS,
because the DBMS processes them more efficiently than SAS does.

SAS translates the WHERE clauses into generated SQL code.

The performance impact can be particularly significant when you are
accessing large DBMS tables. The following section describes how and
when functions are passed to the DBMS. For information about
passing processing to the DBMS when you are using PROC SQL,
see Overview of Optimizing Your SQL Usage.

If you have NULL values in a DBMS column that is used in a WHERE
clause, be aware th
at your results might differ depending on
whether the WHERE clause is processed in SAS or is passed to
the DBMS for processing. This is because DBMSs tend to remove NULL
values from consideration in a WHERE clause, while SAS does not.

With Oracle, you can EXPLAIN PLAN FOR statement with the query in question
to get the information you want.  DB2 has similar functionality with it's
EXPLAIN statement, as well.

Hoping to kick off some conversation (and maybe help out Lisa if she hasn't done this already) - one of the best things I did with my second pregnancy was develop a postpartum plan.  It's kind of like the birth plan that everyone has heard about, only for after you give birth.  Mine had things like phone numbers for care providers, key things that have to get done (like appointments, adding the baby to insurance, getting a copy of the birth certificate, a SSN card), how we were going to feed ourselves, my plan for easing back into work, etc....  It's nothing that was rocket science, it was just really nice to have it all written in one place and shared ahead of time with my husband/support network so we were on the same page.  When my mind went to jello after birth, all I had to do was look at the plan (or get a reminder from my support network.)  What would you put on your postpartum plan?

Attached is an updated flier on pending legislation that impacts federal employees.

As the 114th Congress nears its six-month mark, NTEU is working to stop many anti-fed proposals from ever becoming law, and to advance bills that would benefit federal workers and enhance federal service. As you know, the overall environment for federal employees on Capitol Hill remains challenging. 

This “Bills That Matter” flier attached is designed to highlight key legislation before Congress on federal employee pay and benefits, as well as agency funding and collective bargaining and labor rights that NTEU either supports or opposes.

Visit the NTEU Legislative Action Center at www.nteu.org for custom-written letters and additional information.

Rest assured that NTEU will continue to fight for federal employees.

Fast temporary volatile tables in Oracle and Teradata

It is very handy to use temporary tables when joining a big
Teradata or Oracle table with a smaller SAS finder table.

Oracle seems to support this construct but not Teradata?

Volatile tables populated from SAS datasets are not
supported well enough by SAS/ACCESS to Teradata to be useful.
If you need to push data to
TD for join purposes, you'll need CREATE TABLE permission
to an actual schema to store
that data, and will need to clean that data up manually yourself.

Well, I have already said more than I know  :-),  but, one more suggestion
before I go silent.  The following post from a few days ago concerned a
similar problem on an Oracle installation.  See:

It seems that temp tables are supported in Oracle

https://listserv.uga.edu/cgi-bin/wa?A2=ind1502A&L=SAS-L&P=R6557

I believe SYS.V$XXX is a temp table.

select *
   from connection to oracle
     (select * from SYS.V$XXX)
;

Attemps below

Is it possible that you need to specify an owner (or schema) for the
temporary table?

Unfortunately, not even that works for me:

    100    connect to teradata (&td_goo) ;
    101    create table bloob2 as
    102    select * from connection to teradata
    103    (select u.*
    104      from sb_ghri.utilization as u INNER JOIN
    105            my_cohort as c
    106      on    u.mrn = c.mrn)
    107    ;
      82 1738775679 Main 0 SQL
    TERADATA_16: Prepared: on connection 2 83 1738775679 Main 0 SQL
    select u.* from sb_ghri.utilization as u INNER JOIN my_cohort as c
on u.mrn = c.mrn 84
    1738775679 Main 0 SQL
      85 1738775679 Main 0 SQL
    ERROR: Teradata prepare: Object 'my_cohort' does not exist. SQL
statement was: select u.* from
           sb_ghri.utilization as u INNER JOIN my_cohort as c on u.mrn
= c.mrn.
    NOTE: PROC SQL set option NOEXEC and will continue to check the
syntax of statements.

This, despite the fact that I successfully did a (libname-based)
"select * from temp_td.my_cohort" 2 statements earlier in the same
proc sql block.

Interestingly, if I stick with pass-through the whole way--e.g.:

    execute (CREATE VOLATILE TABLE my_cohort (mrn char(10) ) ON COMMIT
PRESERVE ROWS ) by teradata;
    execute ( COMMIT WORK ) by teradata;
    execute (insert into my_cohort (mrn) values ('roy')) by teradata ;
    create table bloob as
    select * from connection to teradata
    (select u.*
    from sb_ghri.utilization as u INNER JOIN
          my_cohort as c
    on    u.mrn = c.mrn)
    ;

It does work.  But my problem is that my cohort is in a SAS dataset,
and I can't seem to populate a pass-through created volatile dataset

Applying an arbitrary formats to a column of numbers in the program editor

For some reason I could not upload to Yammer so I put this message on google drive.
You should not need a logon id to download this message.

apply format
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByX2ii2B0Rq9OUNlQm1lMzIzdnc/view?usp=sharing

Suppose you have the following column of numbers
in the program editor
and you want the corresponding dates.

1569
2747
2985
2108
1678
1000

18APR1964

* Here is an example of applying arbitrary formats to
  a highlighted column of numbers
  in the SAS display manager program window.
  Typing 'fmth dollar18.' on the command will load formatted values
  in paste buffer. This is just plain old basic SAS code.
  No funny catalog entries or the need to export
  and import with the next version of SAS. However we may need to
  convice SAS not to remove advanced legacy functionality
  in the future.

* There are many more changes you could do on the text
  The text does not have to be a single column
  Changes like change roger to mary in signature.

* we have seen in the past how
  debugh -> will identify the line number in a highlighted
  macro, where the error occurred.

  xlsh ->will open a highlighted SAS dataset in excel.

  frqh name*sex -> gives the frequency of highlighted dataset
  in the output window

* These command macros work best in old text editor
  but should work in the enhanced, but not super-enhanced editors, if
  you substitute "copy" for "store";

* just add these macros to utl_perpac and include the package.

The issue of having to toggle 'ignore blank lines'
to get some legacy support is disappointing.

With all the advances in OO programming you would think
version 5 simple old text editor functionality would
be very inexpensive to maintain.

%macro fmth /cmd parmbuff;
/*-----------------------------------------*\
|  highlight column of numbers and          |
|  type fmth <some_format>                  |
\*-----------------------------------------*/
   %let argx=&syspbuff;
   store;note;notesubmit '%fmtha;';
   run;
%mend fmth;

%macro fmtha;
   filename clp clipbrd;
   filename tmp temp;
   data _null_;
     infile clp;
     file tmp;
     input x;
     put x &argx.;
   run;
   data _null_;
    infile tmp;
    file clp;
    input;
    put _infile_;
   run;
%mend fmtha;

A better way to create powerpoint slides then ods ppt?

Could not upload to Yammer so I put it on google drive

https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByX2ii2B0Rq9a3BjX3Z0TFZTQ1k/view?usp=sharing

A better way to create powerpoint slides then ods ppt?

The method I describe below supports

  1. Using you companies theme (not supported by ods ppt)
  2. Programatically inserting and deleting slides (not supported by ods ppt?)

Process short version (you need a pdf version of slidedeck)

  1. Create a pdf slide deck with room for company theme
  2, Insert pdf slides from other presentations
  3. Use free boxoft utility to copy pdf slides to ppt bitmaps
  4. Use VBA macro below to add your companies theme

It seems to me working from a SAS PDF slidedeck is very flexible.

Drawbacks ( I consider most of these to be strengths)

  1. Slides are bitmap images
  2. You have to create a PDF version of slides first(nice to have)
  3. You need to create a template mostly to save
     white area for your company theme, Need to do minimal calculation for space)
  4. You need the free Boxoft pdf to ppt utility
  5. Tou need ghostscript to programatically insert delete PDF slides
  6. Limited ability to make changes to slides in powerpoint
  7. Boxoft seems to use a DDE like process to pump the pdf slides to powerpoint

Here is the process. I think I have posted the pieces
already. I do have a very flexible text slide macro.

  1. Create pdf title slide and a body slise (ods pdf)


    %Tut_Sly
       (
        stop=21
        ,L7='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct } Potential Data Issues with the February Workbook'
        ,L9='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct } All Records Including US and UK (267|498)'
        ,L11='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Input is Aggregate February Workbook'
        ,L13='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Twelve Months Jan2014-Dec2014'
        ,L20='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Roger Deangelis'
        ,L21='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} 2/23/2015'
       );

   * note courier font;
   %Tut_Sly
       (
        stop=19
         ,L3='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=199pct} Take Care Data is very Skewed. Only need top 25.'
         ,L5='^S={font_size=25pt just=l cellwidth=199pct} Total Premium Amount --  Quantiles'
         ,L7='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} Level           Quantile'
        ,L9 ='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 199% Max     $49,335,663'
        ,L19='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 99%           $2,995,668'
        ,L11='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 95%             $796,552'
        ,L12='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 99%             $379,474'
        ,L13='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 75% Q3           $99,214'
        ,L14='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 59% Median       $11,433   259,363 Mean'
        ,L15='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 25% Q1            $1,988'
        ,L16='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 19%                 $184'
        ,L17='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 5%                    $9'
        ,L18='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 1%                    $9'
        ,L19='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 9% Min                $9'
       );

  2. Use ghostscript to add a pdf slide
  3. Use boxoft to covert pdf slides to powerpoint bitmaps
  4. Use my VBA macro to add your company theme


/* T806850 Adding your company theme to SAS created PPT slides(via Boxoft)

Win 7 32 bit Powerpoint 2010

Once you have created your slides using ODS PDF and converted them to
a ppt using the free BOXOFT PDF2PPT, you probably want to
add a powerpoint theme. Make sure you used a SAS template that
provides whitespace for the banner and slide number footnote.

If you have a company custom template click on it and
select all the slides, shift first slide then last slide,
Then go to design tab then background slides then apply.
All slides will now have then them behind the SAS foreground
bitmaps.

The following VBA macro will make the SAS bitmaps transparent
and the company theme will appear on each slide.

Note SAS does not provide the ability for a them using
the template. Since SAS titles always appear at the top of a
page you can imbed an image in title1. However I wanted the
company powerpoint theme.

Thanks to the Powerpoint Expert Steve Rindsberg for
the macro below

Sub SetXparency()


Dim oSl As Slide

For Each oSl In ActivePresentation.Slides

    With oSl.Shapes(1)

        With .PictureFormat

            .TransparentBackground = msoTrue

            .TransparencyColor = RGB(255, 255, 255)

        End With

    End With

Next

End Sub

C:\Program Files\gs\gs9.06\bin\gswin32c.exe to c:\pdf\gswin32c.exe

x "cd c:\tip";
x "gswin32 -dNOPAUSE -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -sOUTPUTFILE=merge.pdf -dBATCH pdf_1.pdf  pdf_2.pdf";

C:\Program Files\gs\gs9.06\bin\gswin32c.exe to c:\pdf\gswin64c.exe

C:\Program Files\gs\gs9.06\bin\gswin32c.exe to c:\pdf\gsdll64.lib

x "cd c:\pdf";
x "c:\pdf\gswin64c.exe -dNOPAUSE -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -sOUTPUTFILE=merge.pdf -dBATCH roger1.pdf  roger2.pdf";

/* T806880 PDF and RTF to MS Powerpoint

%let pgm=utl_mkeppt;

/* Create a powerpoint presentation from and Adobe PDF file

  Handles text, tables and graphics.

  You do need to download the free PDF to PPT converter at
  http://www.boxoft.com/pdf-to-ppt/
  I installed the package at c:\exe\p2p.
  (efficient code only 5mb 1.5mb executable)

  Note this is version 1.0 and has a simple command interface.
  You also need powerpoint on the desktop.

  I have only tested with MS Powerpoint 2010, but should work
  with  MS Powerpoint 2003 or 2007. I have only
  tested with the command interface.

  Tested under Win Xp with 9.3M1 SAS 32bit and
  Win 7 64bit with SAS 9.3M1 64bit

  Working code
*/

* set up inputs and outputs - need c:\temp;
%let outpdf='c:\temp\stu5th.pdf'; /* ods pdf output */
%let outppt='c:\temp\stu5th.ppt'; /* boxoft output  */

ods listing close;
title;
footnote;

%let title=Fifth Grade Student Height and Sex;

ods escapechar='^';

* see template macro below. May want to increase
  the default fontsize, but I felt users could
  override in code, default is 14pt;

%utl_pptlan100(rules=none);

ods pdf file="&outpdf" style=utl_pptlan100 notoc;

* create text slides up to 24 lines;
* note 100% with for common look
  and feel;

* text slides;
%Tut_Sly
   (
    BokMrk=Title,
    L10=^S={font_size=36pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} &title,
    L14=^S={font_size=36pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} SAS-L List,
    L16=^S={font_size=36pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Hurricane Sandy &sysdate
   );

* sample table;
proc report data=sashelp.class(obs=7) nowd missing
  style(column)={just=center vjust=middle font_size=20pt}  split='#'
  style(header)={font_weight=bold font_size=17pt};
col ("^{style [fontsize=30pt] &title}
  ^{newline 1} ^{nbspace 1}"  name sex height) _row;
%greenbar;
run;quit;

* sample graphic;
goptions reset=all htext=20pt;
proc gchart data=sashelp.class;
note m=(15pct,-12pct) height=4 "&title";
  hbar sex;
run;quit;

ods pdf close;
ods listing;

*convert to ppt;
x 'c:\exe\p2p\pdftopptcmd.exe
  "c:\temp\stu5th.pdf" "c:\temp\stu5th.p

The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act amended section 7 of the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) to require employers to provide reasonable break time for an employee to express breast milk for her nursing child for one year after the child’s birth each time such employee has need to express the milk.

Employers are also required to provide a place, other than a bathroom, that is shielded from view and free from intrusion from coworkers and the public, which may be used by an employee to express breast milk.

The break time requirement became effective when the Affordable Care Act was signed into law on March 23, 2010.

Read on in the PDF attached. It also has links to additional resources.

Please contact me if you have any questions or comments about this important subject.

I recently broadcasted information on the topic of Congress’ interest in federal employees and their overall federal tax compliance.

On March 18th, NTEU testified before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform Subcommittee on Government Operations regarding federal tax compliance of federal workers and contractors. A week later, House Oversight and Government Reform Chairman Jason Chaffetz (R-UT) introduced H.R. 1563, the Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2015, which was subsequently marked up by the Committee the next day. House leadership has now announced that the House will vote on H.R. 1563 this Wednesday, April 15th, in recognition of tax day.

Under H.R. 1563, federal agencies would be required to search public records for federal tax liens against employees and job applicants. If a lien is found, the employee or applicant would be asked to consent to the Treasury Department reviewing their tax information and reporting that information back to the agency.

Seriously delinquent tax debt is defined in the bill as “a Federal tax liability that has been assessed by the Secretary of the Treasury under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and may be collected by the Secretary by levy or by a proceeding in court…” Employees found to meet this definition would have to be fired, and applicants could not be hired unless they qualify for an exception, such as innocent spouse, already being on an installment plan or having their salary levied.

There is no dollar minimum or length of time of delinquency included in the definition. Nor is intent or ability to pay given consideration. The bill does allow for a hardship exemption at the discretion of the agency, but no transparency or standards are included. 

Additionally, H.R. 1563 creates an adverse action with penalties including separation for acts of willful failure to file a required federal tax return and willful understatement of federal tax liability. It is unclear how agencies would get access to this level of confidential tax information and how they would determine an employee’s culpability since these matters require expertise on tax laws, which agency labor and human resources personnel do not have.

While NTEU has stated its strong belief that federal employees should satisfy all of their financial obligations, including their federal taxes, we have opposed the bill’s blanket firing policy and have highlighted the current 97% tax compliancy rate of the federal workforce, as tracked by the IRS as of 2013 under the Federal Employee/Retiree Delinquency Initiative that was established in 1993.

Further, NTEU has educated congressional staff about the current processes in place to ensure tax compliance by federal workers (outside of IRS employees, who are already subject to a higher standard), which includes an Office of Government Ethics regulation, under 5 C.F.R., that allows agencies to take disciplinary action against an employee for failure to satisfy just financial obligations, including federal taxes. 

In addition to having the ability to voluntarily establish installment plans with the IRS, federal employees are subject to the Federal Payment Levy Program, which allows the IRS to continuously levy up to 15% of federal salaries to recoup owed taxes. 

NTEU has also underscored the importance of current hardship exemptions recognized by the IRS, which can include relief for innocent and injured spouses and extreme financial situations where the individual does not currently have the ability to pay what is owed.  
            
Attached is a letter NTEU sent to House members, explaining the reasons for our continued opposition to H.R. 1563. On April 15th 2013, a similar bill, H.R. 249, failed to receive the necessary two-thirds majority on the House Suspension Calendar (250 ayes to 159 nays). 

NTEU is working to educate members about the unfair provisions of this bill, and its assault on federal employees’ privacy and tax rights, as well as its implementation challenges for agencies, in hopes that this bill can be defeated again on the House floor.

Please visit www.nteu.org to see how you can help.

Your original statement saying it's the COR's repsonsibility to maintain the contract file is a big misleading>

Your leading statement that it's the COR's responsibility to maintain the contract file is a big misleading. The official contract file is maintained by the awarding Contracting Officer. The COR's contract file is maintained by the COR, and should mirror the official contract file as required.

Your leading statement that it's the COR's responsibility to maintain the contract file is a bit misleading. It is the responsibility of the awarding and administering CO to maintain the official contract file. The COR can maintain a copy of the official contract file, commonly referred to as the "COR Contract File" (which is a best practice), but it only mirrors the official contract file. Curious how CMS handles this. Do you require your CO's to include this performance requirement of COR's in their COR Appointment Letter?

Medicaid Data Shows One-Percent of Preschool Children Use Psychotropic Medication News Report | April 12, 2015.  

Across 36 state Medicaid programs, about 1.19% of child beneficiaries age five and younger were prescribed one or more psychotropic medications between 2000 and 2003. About 0.61% were prescribed medications that treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD); 0.59% were prescribed medications that treat depression or anxiety; and 0.24% were prescribed medications that treat psychotic illness or bipolar disorder. Psychotropics were prescribed to 0.17% of infants, and 0.34% of children between age one and two years.
https://www.openminds.com/market-intelligence/news/1-19-preschool-children-medicaid-received-least-one-psychotropic-medication.htm/

Technically, you are correct - the FAR does identify that the "official" contract file is the responsibility of the CO; however, the FAR (1.604) also indicates that the COR must also maintain a file for each assigned contract/task order award.  That being said, the standard CMS Delegation Memo does require the COR to maintain a file that contains the majority of the "official" contract file  items identified by the HHSAR.

As you may know, we are working to redesign the Strategic Planning System, the HHS resource that lets you track progress on strategic plan implementation. As part of the redesign we are examining the way in which we categorize, or tag, plans to make them easier to find through search. To help us assure that the categories and tags meet the needs of SPS account holders, we are deploying an online card sort and we would like to invite you to participate. The card sort will be available until Friday, April 24.
 
Thank you in advance for your help.  We appreciate your time! 

The Strategic Planning Team
HHS/ASPE

The union joins the nation in preparing to mark on Sunday the 20th anniversary of the tragic bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building. In honoring the victims and survivors of the attack, NTEU also honors federal workers who carry on their legacy through their dedication to public service. 

“As we remember those who lost their lives, we also remember those who carry on their work," President Colleen M. Kelley said. "After 20 years, federal employees continue to persevere. But we never forget."

The site of the Alfred P. Murrah federal building is hallowed ground where a memorial and museum stand to honor the victims and educate the public.

Chapter 280 Turns Management’s ‘No’ Into ‘Yes’ 

After an agency consolidation required an office move, a number of chapter members were concerned about the lack of certain facilities at the new location. Management deemed the current facilities were sufficient, but the D.C.-based chapter would not take “no” 
for an answer.

Read more after logging into NTEU.org at https://www.nteu.org/UnionOffice/NTEUBulletin/Article.aspx?ID=2765.

Long Essay: Being an Introverted Extrovert on Yammer

When I was in my twenties, I was the leader of an alt rock band. We were pretty sure it was only a matter of time before we'd get picked up by a major label because that's how it works, right? Be creative with your friends and you're sure to get paid. Hey, it seemed reasonable back in the 90’s.

For the most part, we were all quiet people; I was known for leaving shows with my gear the moment we’d finished playing, just to avoid awkwardly talking to people I didn’t know. The problem we discovered early on was that if we didn't make some effort to make connections and engage people, we couldn't land more shows. Over time, I made myself figure out how to strike up conversations with strangers and participate in group discussions at parties, back stage, and in other social settings. This was a profoundly difficult process for me, but motivated by a desire to be successful, I worked on hiding my discomfort.

Many years in my new life a writer and web developer came and went. For my professional development, I've been required to develop my social and speaking skills much further. If you put me in a room with smart people, I would say I'm usually able to keep up with what's being said and I'll understand the gist of what's happening. My introvert tendencies may kick in during meetings, so I may focus on taking in information to process later. The problem I frequently run into happens when I'm put on the spot or unexpectedly need to contribute. There are a couple of issues I won’t go into that get in the way of my full participation. One I’ll share- I find myself unable to recall words or ideas that should be accessible to me at those important moments. Too often, I've found that information I knew only moments ago vanishes on me. 

As a communicator, these issues I've listed can be a challenge, one frequently overcome through experience and training. But there’s another way of communicating that, for me, is particularly empowering.
Social media has changed the meeting dynamic for me in important ways. I'm able to control the flow of dialogue in a way that I find far more natural. There's more information to absorb at my own pace and if I want to share an experience or offer an opinion I have the ability to research my thoughts before speaking my mind. For me, that offers far greater confidence as a communicator with introverted tendencies. On social media and Yammer, I can be an informed extrovert and it's perfectly okay with me!

We all know how our colleagues prefer to communicate; some prefer face-to-face, others like the phone or chat, while some people still like email. For me, an organized discussion thread structured and retrievable by topic offers the greatest potential for growth as a communicator.

I hope others can learn from and enjoy this platform and others like it. We're still in what I view to be the infancy of global, social communications. It's an exciting time for folks like myself. We're finally able to say what we've been thinking all along during those long meetings we stayed silent.

body: The Manual is great - thanks!  It's clear that the PO and GMS need to collaborate regularly to properly monitor a grant portfolio.  How would DGMO feel about requiring the GMS to participate on monitoring calls on a quarterly/monthly basis?

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: Could you address whether staff should be using the GPAM or the AAGAM…or both?  There seems to be a lot of confusion about this.  Thanks!

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: By the end of the calendar year, there will (hopefully) be a complete GPAM. You can refer to an updated GPAM chapter, or otherwise refer to AAGAM. But if you have any questions or are unsure, you can always reach out to Division of Grants Policy. Also, the DGP sharepoint site provides information on this.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
The team approach includes the PO, GMS/GMO, Financial Integrity Analysts, and branch chiefs/managers. These staff should have clear communication channels so that a unified response goes back to the awardee, as well as integrated monitoring activities. 

Risk-based approach includes routine communications and site visits that are designed/in response to identified risks of the specific awardee or program. It can also include managers analyzing/looking at data to identify patterns of risk and finding ways to mitigate these risks.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: In the area of monitoring, how can we diminish risk for grantees in their lack of understanding of civil rights obligations?
This would be relevant for CSR or modified CSR retirees?

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: One has to consider that when FFRs are due for submission.  This is a PA that has the oversight of both Program and DGMO

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: Can you say a few words about how past performance will be considered when evaluating risk?

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Need to consider through communications/reports from an awardee, whether they are struggling. Keeping an eye on that particular awardee. 

Also, looking at data analytics based on past performance to identify "risky" awardees.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Best practices/lessons learned: 

Meet your counterpart GMS or PO and it improved overall communication. 

Focus on the things that are important, use all the available tools, seeking out best practices from mentors, colleagues. 

Value your counterpart's time. 

Be hungry for knowledge. Keep up the curiousity for making things better.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: Thanks!

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: There is a huge value in having a GMS on those calls. However, given the caseload of the GMS this could be difficult. It might be a better approach to think about the level of risk identified for a particular awardee. But please reach out to your GMS counterpart to discuss itwhen it's most appropriate for the GMS on the call (eg topics will include FFR, prior approvals, carry overs).

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: We need to continue to highlight the civil rights obligations in the federal assurances. During the orientation call, POs can spend some extra time on this topic. OFAM can work with program offices on, when appropriate, it can be part of a site visit.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: Timing is an issue. Also, there are other factors, including programmatic issues, which require close collaboration among the program and grants specialists.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: Starting out as a new GMS a couple of years ago at the National Cancer Institute, the most helpful thing to me was the daily 1 on 1 contact with my mentor. Participation in professional organizations was also important as it gave me a better understanding of what was going on in the greater grants world.
We met with the librarians today! We love them!

Its always great to learn from others in your respective field. Are there any organizations in particular that you can recommend?

If the GMS participates in quarterly calls as needed, it may reduce the amount of calls a GMS may receive from grantees.

The objective is to provide real-time access to multiple federal software systems as a data layer on a map.  The user (senior management) could then access their area by clicking on the point/building location.  Right now we're embedding the maps in a SharePoint site....

The Navigator Funding Announcement went out yesterday and can be found at:  http://www.grants.gov, and search for CFDA # 93.332.

The House voted on H.R. 1563, a bill to require that federal employees with tax debt be fired. The bill was brought up under a procedure that requires a two-thirds majority vote. The vote was 266 in favor, 160 against. Failing to receive a two-thirds majority, it was not approved.

It is possible the bill could be brought back for a vote under a different procedure at some future time. NTEU will continue to monitor that possibility and continue to oppose this bill.

I welcome your questions and comments.
That's a pretty slim "victory".  66% is needed for a majority and the percentage in favor was 62%.  I predict grim times ahead for all federal employees.

Although it has been 20 years, the memory of the bombing of the Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City on April 19, 1995, is as fresh as if this horrific tragedy occurred just yesterday. For federal employees, this is an event we will never forget.

We remember the 168 people—federal workers, members of the public and children—who were killed in an act of rage against our government and against those who proudly serve it. But rather than bow to fear as the attackers intended, the federal community banded together and recommitted itself to public service. 

Every day, you serve your fellow Americans in your offices and laboratories, out in the field and at the borders. You honor the victims of Oklahoma City with your commitment to duty, and we thank you for continuing to perform the important work of our nation.

Today, where the federal building once stood, is the Oklahoma City National Memorial and Museum. Each year, millions of visitors pause to reflect at the memorial’s Field of Empty Chairs. Each of the 168 chairs has the name of a victim etched into its glass base, including 19 smaller chairs for the children who perished in the attack. They are poignant reminders of the empty chairs at family dinner tables that can never be filled.

NTEU strives to honor their memories by ending the rhetoric that scapegoats federal employees for the nation’s problems. We honor them by understanding that our country’s greatness comes, in large part, from those who dedicate themselves to its service. 

We will never forget.

No, there has been a delay with AMS integration with CDC SharePoint.  The AMS ADFS solution enables authorized, active HHS staff to authenticate to SharePoint sites within the target SharePoint farm via AMS.  When the AMS SharePoint Adapter was deployed to the target Production SharePoint farm, several third-party products which leverage the People Picker encountered issues.   Deployment of the AMS SharePoint Adapter enhances the Out-of-the Box People Picker tool to access multiple data sources through AMS’s Enterprise Virtual Directory (EVD). This enables multi-directory/data source user searches within the people picker tool of the integrated farm.  The standard People Picker uses only one data source, the CDC SharePoint Configured Active Directory, whereas once the AMS SharePoint Adapter is deployed, a second data source is introduced to connect to external EVD/LDAP, apart from its own Active Directory.   AMS and CDC Technical Teams are reviewing approaches to mitigate/resolve the issue encountered.

Dr. Elaine Newton is Training Manager for the HRSA Learning Institute (HLI) and Supervisor of the Workforce Development Team responsible for the development and delivery of professional, supervisory, and leadership development courses/programs and the administration of the HLI’s open enrollment courses.   

Dr. Newton has worked for the federal government for five years serving in roles of Senior Workforce Planner and Training Specialist. Prior to federal service, she was a consultant specializing in human capital and organizational development; a corporate trainer of leadership programs, Safeco Insurance Company, and adjunct faculty for the University of Phoenix’s business management and MBA programs. In addition Dr. Newton, a decorated US Army veteran with 20 years of service, served in various leadership roles to include Drill Sergeant, Platoon Sergeant, First Sergeant, and Operation Sergeant managing military logistics throughout the country of Korea. 

Dr. Newton has a Doctor of Management degree in Organizational Leadership, University of Phoenix; a MS in Human Resources Management and Development, Chapman University; and BS in Management Studies from the University of Maryland.  She is a Competent Toastmaster, conference speaker, mentor, and Certified Federal Coach and holds numerous training and organizational development certifications. An organizational leadership enthusiast, Dr. Newton is passionate about mobilizing and developing the collective talent, skills, and capabilities of individuals to realize both personal and organizational success.

Shawn: so many great things here: vulnerability/authenticity, relatability, simple, yet something unique to say. In terms of your brain freezes in real life, I just expect that of myself and everyone else, that being "in the zone" is a rare thing and to appreciate it as such. You may perceive this as a weakness of yours, but I see this as just another area of learning, everyone starts off "further behind" where you are now.  Who can give you permission to make mistakes, as part of your learning? My current thought is only you can.  I have found the Nigel Holmes infographic of Carol Dweck's Growth Mindset useful.  Here's to personal growth!

A few weeks ago, NTEU sent out a memo on the House- and Senate-passed budgets.

Late last week, budget conferees were selected from the House and Senate.

Today, NTEU National President Colleen Kelley sent a letter to each conferee reiterating that federal employees have already contributed $159 billion in deficit reduction through reduced pay raises and increased retirement contributions. She pointed out that, if Congress continues to use federal employee pay and benefits as a piggy bank, it will become increasingly difficult to recruit or retain federal employees.

The conferees expect to frame an agreement by early May. NTEU will keep us informed of the conference’s activities.

To learn more, visit nteu.org.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1962: President John F. Kennedy opened the Seattle World’s Fair by telephone from Palm Beach, Florida. He pressed a gold telegraph key which focused an antenna at Andover, Maine and a Navy radio telescope station in Maryland on a star to pick up a 10,000 year-old radio signal. That in turn set in motion various exhibits at the fair.

http://archive2.jfklibrary.org/JFKWHP/1962/Month%2004/Day%2021/JFKWHP-1962-04-21-A/JFKWHP-ST-139-7-62.jpg

Description Generates risk estimates and comorbidity flags from ICD-9-CM
codes available in administrative medical datasets. The package supports
the Charlson Comorbidity Index, the Elixhauser Comorbidity
classification, the Revised Cardiac Risk Index, and the Risk Stratification
Index. Methods are table-based, fast, and use the plyr package, so
parallelization is possible for large jobs. Also includes a sample of
real ICD-9 data for 100 patients from a publicly available dataset.

Description Generates risk estimates and comorbidity flags from ICD-9-CM
 codes available in administrative medical datasets. The package supports
 the Charlson Comorbidity Index, the Elixhauser Comorbidity
 classification, the Revised Cardiac Risk Index, and the Risk Stratification
 Index. Methods are table-based, fast, and use the plyr package, so
 parallelization is possible for large jobs. Also includes a sample of
 real ICD-9 data for 100 patients from a publicly available dataset.
