Hi, everyone,

April is National Poetry Month, and an assortment of .gov social media managers are challenging government social media accounts to post a haiku on Tuesday, April 28. 

The idea is to write a haiku that celebrates something about your agency and the great work that it does/has done, while also showcasing the creativity that lies behind .gov social media. Posts could include infographics, links to resources, submissions from staff, haiku as graphic quotes—whatever your imagination can devise (that’s also approved by the right channels, of course)! 

Be sure to use [Tag:5643325:nationalpoetrymonth] in your posts on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, etc. Submissions from government accounts will be collected after the fact and posted on the National Archives Storify account to bring some attention to your social media accounts, agencies, and government service in general.  
 
No need to advertise publicly, but please share this with government social media managers that may not be on this list. If you have questions or ideas about this event, please send them to me at audrey.wellons@nih.gov.

Most of all, have fun—I'll be excited to see what everyone comes up with!

Candace K. Webb, MPH | Public Health Analyst | Northeast/Central Services Branch | Division of State HIV/AIDS Programs | HIV/AIDS Bureau [cid:image003.png@01CBC38A.1FC70170] | Health Resources and Services Administration | 5600 Fishers Lane | Mail Stop 09SWH03 | Rockville, MD  20857| • Tel: 301-443-9089 | • Email: cwebb@hrsa.gov

On September 22, 2014, NTEU filed an unfair labor practice (ULP) charge against FDA for unilaterally changing its travel procedures without providing notice to NTEU or an opportunity to bargain. NTEU alleges the new policy adversely impacts employees with disabilities because it requires them to apply for a reasonable accommodation through the agency’s EEO office in order to request a travel accommodation under the Federal Travel Regulations. This process is administratively burdensome to employees with disabilities, and their accommodation requests are not being processed in a timely manner.  

On April 14, 2015, the Washington, D.C. Regional Director of the FLRA issued a complaint and notice of a hearing requiring the agency to appear and respond to NTEU’s charges. The hearing is scheduled for June 25, 2015, in Washington, D.C. At the hearing, the FLRA will prosecute the case before an Administrative Law Judge, and NTEU will appear in order to offer supporting evidence and information.  

If you have any questions or comments regarding this matter, please contact me here or privately.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1977: Optical fiber is first used to carry live telephone traffic. Made of extruded glass (silica) or plastic and slightly thicker than a human hair, flexible and transparent optical fibers are used most often as a means to transmit light between the two ends of the fiber. It has wide usage in fiber-optic communications, where they permit transmission over longer distances and at higher bandwidths (data rates) than wire cables.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_fiber#/media/File:Fibreoptic.jpg

body:
What are activity codes and how do I get one?

Activity codes are three character alphanumeric codes that HRSA assigns to classify programs by the main type of activity they conduct.  The codes are used in part to distinguish between the wide variety of programs HRSA supports and serve as a tool in programmatic data management in the EHB.

In general, the first letter of an activity code indicates a program activity.  For example, a program code beginning with a U indicates the grant program is a cooperative agreement.  A code that begins with an R indicates research activities, T for training activities and B for a block grant program.  Examples of program activity codes include the H80 Health Center program, R40 MCHB Research Program and T23 Dental Reimbursement program.

If you need a new activity code, please visit the DGP SharePoint site at https://sharepoint.hrsa.gov/ofam/dgp/Lists/ActivityCodeRequestForm/NewForm.aspx

Distractions:  They’re Everywhere

Many of today's workplaces and households rely heavily on mobile phones for quick and convenient communication.  It seems that we want instantaneous contact.  You hear it every day, "There's no way we can do business without mobile phones."  Chances are there is a mobile phone in your life, used for communicating with the office while you are working in the field or with your children when they arrive home before you in the afternoon.  

As good as mobile phones might be for instant communication, they contribute to bad driving.  It is becoming increasingly clear that talking on a mobile phone distracts a driver from seeing hazards and responding quickly.  
Here are some typical distractions behind the wheel.  Do any of them sound familiar?

• Mobile phone use
• Reading or sending text messages (see Executive Order 13513)
• Trying to eat or drink while making sure nothing spills on you clothing 
• Reaching for a moving object inside the vehicle
• Looking at an object or event outside of the vehicle
• Reading a newspaper, map, or document
• Personal grooming such as applying makeup or shaving
• Focusing on electronic gadgets like the GPS or other devices instead of the road 
• Trying to find a radio station or selecting music on your smart phone 

Here are some reminders for driving safely without distractions:  

• Make sure you, and the workers you supervise, use mobile phones safely.  The safest thing is to make your calls before you set out.  If you receive a mobile phone call while you are driving, let the caller leave a message, pull over, and call that person back.  Reinforce this safety policy by issuing regular reminders and by setting a good example.  
• Be aware that using a hands-free, voice-activated mobile phone also increases driver impairment.  Conference calls while driving and using a hands-free device are still distracting activities. 
• Avoid stressful conversations on the phone or with passengers that can divert the driver's attention from the business of driving. 
• Never read or send text messages while driving.
• Always buckle up. (see Executive Order 13043)
• Keep your hands on the wheel and your eyes on the road.
• Program your GPS and familiarize yourself with the route before you start driving
• A safe driver also stops before checking maps and addresses, looking at paperwork, and dealing with similar distractions.
• Avoid eating or drinking in the car.  Stop and take a break when you want to eat or drink.  The break will also help to make you more alert.

Don’t let yourself get distracted while driving.  Keep your mind on your driving; keep your eyes on the road, and your hands on the wheel!  Your life and the life of other drivers around you may just depend on it.

How to detemine if a SAS local power workstation would benefit you
as a SAS programmer over an EG server.

The first question to ask is how often do you need to access a database schema where one
or more tables are over 1TB. I define big data as computing problems where most
of a users programming involves tables over 1TB. The other place for a large serves is
massive simulations or parallelism over 64 concurrent jobs. Workstations are available
with 64 cores.

Should I use just the server or a sever plus workstation(or power laptop) for my SAS programming.

Systems like Tableau, Oracle, 
Teradata, Midas and the IDR do not run well on a workstation.

This is how IBM used to measure overall mainframe usability.

  1. Reliability - Do you get the answer you expect.
  2. Availability.
  3. Serviciability
  4. Performance
  5. Functionality
  6. Security

I use either excel or SAS running on both platforms for comparisons.

  1. Reliability.
      There was a bug in SAS 9.3 where 'proc distinct' gave the wrong answer for very high
      cardinality.          Workstation: I downloaded the fix from SAS and installed it on my workstation in 30 minutes
         Server:      Reported it a couple of months ago and it is still not fixed

  2. Availability.
      Workstation: 99.9%
      Server:      75% (Mostly due to the fact that you need an internet connection and because of scheduled
      and non scheduled availability

  3. Serviceability:
      Workstation: I added a second esata III SSD to my laptop in 2 minutes
      Server: Generally not possible

  4. Performance
      Workstation: Much more ram,RAID 0 SSD drives and 100% of the multiple quad XEON processors. Very fast response time
                   not like a server dial-up connection
      Server: Little Ram, SAN spinning raid 5 drives

  5. Functionality
      Workstation: You have an operating system, R, Python, Ghostscript, Perl, C, Java...
                   ODBC(excel access...), more disk space(Try getting 5TB ob the server)...
      Server:      Generally locked down most of the above not available.

  6.  Security
        Workstation: Only have a subset of data. Local and disk encryption.
        Server: Has the jewels so obviously a better targer for hackes.

FYI: I jsut saw a 5TB drive for $150 and flash drives less than $800.

The hardware costs are minimal and R and WPS(sas clone) cost
is reasonable.

Hello Everyone! I am really excited to join the MLDP community. I look forward to getting to know everyone. Below is my bio. Cheers!
_____________________________________________________________________________

Dr. Monica A. Evans is a Public Health Analyst at the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), where she manages technical assistance programs and systems. Her work involves myriad activities, including serving as the contract manager for over $19 million worth of technical assistance contracts; developing and implementing a systems training program for federal and contract staff; and providing consultative services to other contract managers throughout HRSA. 
 
Monica started her federal career as part of the Presidential Management Fellows (PMF) Program. As a PMF, Monica worked on behavioral health communications and served as a project officer at the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, which is also part of HHS. She also served as an international health analyst in the HHS Office of Global Affairs, where her portfolio included projects with the Pan-American Health Organization and the Brazilian Ministry of Health. 

Prior to joining the federal government, Monica spent over 12 years in the education field, working as a classroom teacher, school library media specialist, teacher educator, and education researcher. Monica received a BA in Social Relations and a post-baccalaureate teaching certificate from Michigan State University (MSU), as well as a Masters in Library Information Science from Wayne State University. She also received a PhD in Educational Policy from MSU, where she was awarded a Fulbright Fellowship to research social inclusion programs and policies in Brazil.

Greetings 2015 HRSA MLDP Cohort! I'm excited to have the opportunity to join this cohort over the next year to gain experience and networking opportunities through HRSA's formal mid-level leadership training. Please see below my bio. Thanks!

Natassja Manzanero is a Public Health Analyst within HRSA's Federal Office of Rural Health Policy. Since June 2013, she has served as the Program Coordinator for the Rural Health Information Technology (IT) Workforce Program and also a rural health IT policy analyst. She first joined HRSA in November 2010 as a project officer in the Bureau of Primary Health Care for the Health Center Controlled Network Grants, and in 2011 she joined HRSA's Office of Health IT & Quality as a health IT subject matter expert. Prior to working at HRSA, Natassja was a Health Insurance Specialist at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services for 5 years as an account manager for the Medicare Part D Program. Natassja received her Bachelor of Science Degree in Healthcare Management with a minor in Business from Towson University, and Master of Science Degree in Healthcare Administration Informatics from the University of Maryland.  Natassja is a member and student mentor for the Health Information Management Systems Society (HIMSS), and college instructor at Bellevue College in Washington for their "Introduction to Electronic Health Records" course.

Jessica Preusch has served as a Public Health Analyst with the Office of Planning, Analysis, and Evaluation’s Office of Research and Evaluation (OPAE/ORE) for the past 4 years. Jessica conducts research and evaluation studies related to HRSA’s mission and provides technical assistance with survey development for the agency. Her recent projects have included exploring the barriers and facilitators for ACA-related outreach and enrollment efforts, and investigating primary care workforce issues. She is also helping plan the 2015 HRSA Research & Innovation Symposium and has served as the coordinator for HRSA’s Certificates of Confidentiality for the past 3 years. Jessica is passionate about mental health issues and spent 3 years working as a Relief Counselor with adults with schizophrenia for Cornerstone Montgomery. 

Jessica graduated Summa Cum Laude from the University of Maryland with a Bachelor of Arts in Psychology and minors in Leadership Studies and Business Spanish. She is currently pursuing a Master’s in Public Policy with a focus in Health Policy from the University of Maryland.

I agree - it was a lot of work to get my then 18-month old (and all her stuff!) to the beach last summer, but it was so worth it.  She could have sat in/by the little tide pool and played with the water and sand ALL day long!  Tips for long car trips... be organized (make and use a packing list), bring new (or at least new to your kid) toys and books as special "car treats" to dole out along the way, and try to drive as much as possible during naptime/bedtime.

NTEU has filed an Unfair Labor Practice (ULP) charge against HHS after it reversed on a settlement agreement. By way of background, on June 24, 2014, NTEU filed a national grievance against HHS for failure to fairly and equitably distribute performance awards to bargaining unit employees in the office of the Assistant Secretary for Preparedness and Response (ASPR), in violation of the parties’ collective bargaining agreement. Unable to settle the grievance, the parties submitted the case to arbitration and a hearing was held before Arbitrator Robert A. Creo on December 11, 2014.

During the hearing, HHS asked to discuss settlement. NTEU crafted and submitted settlement terms that included time off awards for ASPR employees and attorney fees. The parties reached complete agreement on the terms; however, now the agency is refusing to execute the parties’ written settlement agreement.

NTEU alleges that HHS violated 5 U.S.C. § 7116(a)(5) and (8) when it failed to comply with § 7114(b)(5) by failing to execute the written agreement reached in settling the national grievance involving ASPR awards. NTEU further alleges HHS violated the statute by failing to negotiate in good faith and failing to send a duly authorized representative to the negotiations of the settlement agreement.

NTEU has requests that HHS immediately executes the written settlement and comply with its terms; post a notice to all bargaining unit employees indicating that HHS has violated the statute; and any other appropriate remedies.

As always, I welcome your questions and comments.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 2005: An Afghan hound, credited with being the world's first cloned dog, Snuppy (a portmanteau of "SNU" and "puppy" also known as "doggy") is born. The puppy was created using a cell from an ear from an adult Afghan hound and involved 123 surrogate mothers, of which only three produced pups (Snuppy being the sole survivor). The team of 45 responsible for cloning Snuppy was led by biomedical scientist Hwang Woo-Suk, who was later found to have lied about his research on previous projects, though independent investigators discovered that Snuppy was a true clone. Snuppy has since been used in the first known successful breeding between cloned canines.

http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2005/08/photogalleries/dogclone/images/primary/dog_clone1.jpg

Erica Grover, MPH, is a public health analyst in the Denver Regional Office for the Bureau of Health Workforce.  Erica began working in HRSA’s Denver Region VIII Office in March 2009.  As the Bureau of Health Workforce (BHW) regional liaison for Colorado and North Dakota, Ms. Grover supports the development, growth and improvement of National Health Service Corps and other BHW programs in the region.

From 2007-2009, Ms. Grover worked as a Special Assistant to the Associate Administrator of HRSA’s Bureau of Health Professions, where she supported national efforts to develop, distribute, and retain a diverse, culturally competent health workforce that provides high-quality care.

From 2005-2007, Erica was a member of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Service’s (HHS) Emerging Leader Program.   As an HHS Emerging Leader, she contributed to the success of several initiatives in three HHS agencies including HRSA, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration.  

Prior to joining HHS, Erica worked for the Peace Corps as a Program Coordinator in Washington, DC and as a Volunteer in Agua Clara, Ecuador with the Chachi people.  In Ecuador, she implemented community development programs with a focus on health, nutrition, sanitation, and economic development.   

Ms. Grover earned a Master of Public Health in Health Promotion and Disease Prevention from the George Washington University in Washington, DC.  She holds a BA in Biology from St. Mary's College of Maryland.

Dr. Katherine (Kacey) Morasch is a Social Science Research Analyst in the National Center for Health Workforce Analysis (NCHWA), set within the Bureau of Health Workforce (BHW).  Dr. Morasch is a member of the Performance Metrics and Evaluation Branch and is responsible for developing and implementing performance measurement for grant programs across the various BHW divisions.  She supports internal and external stakeholders through complicated data collection processes, provides guidance in the development of new funding announcements, and generates detailed reports describing programmatic activities and accomplishments.

Prior to joining HRSA in early 2014, Dr. Morasch worked for the United States Army as a Research Psychologist in the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research’s Center for Military Psychiatry and Neuroscience.  As a Principal Investigator, Dr. Morasch designed and executed laboratory studies focused on militarily-relevant topics including cognitive function and resiliency in the context of traumatic brain injury, sleep deprivation, and chemical warfare prophylaxis.

A native of New Jersey, Dr. Morasch earned her Bachelor’s and Master’s degrees from the College of William & Mary in Virginia, concentrating in Behavioral Neuroscience.  She then completed her doctoral studies and a post-doctoral fellowship at Virginia Tech, where her work focused on the psychobiology of cognitive development, specifically, the relationship between brain function and memory development in infancy, toddlerhood, and early childhood.
  
Dr. Morasch enjoys traveling, martial arts training, and spending time with her husband and their two children.  She is thrilled to be a part of this program and looks forward to meeting you all soon!

Malissa Lewis is a Team Lead in the Division of National Health Service Corps Scholarship Branch, in the Bureau of Health Workforce (BHW). Prior to this position, Ms. Lewis worked in the Division of Participant Support and Compliance, where she was fortunate to have held several roles in her young federal career: Public Health Analyst, Quality Assurance and Compliance Management Analyst. These roles were instrumental in structuring her career path.  

Ms. Lewis’ affiliation with the federal government dates back to September 2008 when she was hired as a Paralegal Specialist contractor in BHW’s Legal and Compliance Branch, formerly the Office of Legal and Compliance. She remained a contractor until December 2010. In March 2011; she transitioned to a Public Health Analyst position in the Division of Participant Support and Compliance. Ms. Lewis worked in that division until November 2014 when she transitioned to her current position. 

Malissa Lewis has a Master of Laws (LL.M), from Pace University School of Law. While in Law School she was exposed to Public Health and Social Security Law though an internship. After graduation in May 2007Ms. Lewis joined the Social Security Disability advocate group, Binder and Binder LL.P, where she travelled around the United States to appeal the cases for clients who were denied their social security benefits. Her passion for public health law was the driving force behind her decision to become a public servant. Ms. Lewis volunteers at the Employment Justice Center, Washington DC; and the Conflict Resolution Center of Montgomery Country, Bethesda Maryland.

I've done a lot of airplane rides. My kids usually pass out on the airplane, so I try to schedule the flight close to naptime.  Then I try to get them tired out ("Let's walk to get a bottle of water!"  Let's walk to look at the planes!" etc...) in the boarding area.  Sometimes they're a little cranky during the actual boarding process, but then they've started to mellow by the time we're seated.  And then they've passed out a little after take-off.  Yay!

Will Davis is a Senior Grants Management Specialist in the Office of Federal Assistance Management (OFAM), Division of Grants Management Operations (DGMO), Health Center Branch (HCB). He serves as lead advisor on all issues involving subordinations, transfers, withdrawals and New Market Tax Credits where HRSA holds Federal interest in real property. Also serve as program lead for New Access Point supplemental awards, as well as the National Cooperative Agreement awards.

Prior to federal service, Mr. Davis was a Program Director at the Center for Urban Families in Baltimore, Maryland, where he designed and implemented a relationship skill building program for low-income couples. He also traveled extensively speaking at workforce development conferences and trainings, while simultaneously serving as grants and contracts manager.

Mr. Davis graduated from the Johns Hopkins University in 2004 with a Bachelor of Arts in Psychological and Brain Science. In 2010, he also received a Juris Doctor (J.D.) from the University of Maryland School of Law.

THIS WEEKEND in Tech History

APRIL 25, 1953:  Watson and Crick’s presented their findings on the double helical structure of DNA in the publication Nature. They noted that the structure “suggests a possible copying mechanism for the genetic material.” 50 Years later the Human Genome Project had concluded sequencing the genome and published a follow-on in Nature on their vision for genetic research.

http://www.nature.com/scitable/content/ne0000/ne0000/ne0000/ne0000/104944953/73_1_2.jpg

APRIL 26, 1884: The New York Times reported that “sending mails by electricity” was to be investigated by the Post Office Committee of the U.S. House, by providing for contracts with an existing telegraph company. In late 1971, more than 87 years later, the first e-mail was finally sent.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1981: The first mouse integrated with a personal computer made its appearance with the Xerox Star workstation. A year later Microsoft made the decision to make the MS-DOS program "Microsoft Word" mouse-compatible and developed the first PC-compatible mouse, which shipped in 1983,

Renee Lennox is a Human Resources Specialist in the Office of Human Resources (OHR), Division of HR Policy and Technology.  She has been working at HRSA since June 2010, when beginning her HRSA career as the Worklife Program Manager moving to OHR in September 2012.  She currently works on special projects within OHR such as revamping the New Employee Orientation program, coordinating HR Clinics and HR Learning Sessions. 
 
Renee began her federal career at Naval Air Station Atsugi, Japan where she was stationed with her husband while in the U.S. Navy.  She worked for the Family Support Center as a Family Life Program Manager with her focus on helping young Navy spouses adjust to military life oversees.  Having traveled the world for over 25 years as part of a military family, she gained extensive knowledge from life experiences and meeting people from so many different cultures.  She believes it’s important to take the time to get to know those who have different beliefs from your own.  She has taught her children that learning someone else's life story only makes their life story that much more interesting and fun.

Ms. Lennox graduated from Hofstra University in Long Island, New York with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Psychology.  She is excited to begin this new journey over the next year in the Mid-Level Leadership Development Program.

What toys/activities do you recommend for an active, curious 9 month old?  My little one is crawling and standing looking for new things to explore!

We'd take a shoebox, put kid-safe things inside, and leave it conspicuously out.  Both my kids would go right over, open the box, dump the things out, put them back, dump them out, play, etc....  I think it's the whole "Ooo - things in other things" appeal.

Hello MLDPers! I am excited to be a part of this group, and I look forward to meeting you all on Wednesday. I've added my brief bio below.

Kerri Cornejo is a Public Health Analyst in the Office of Planning, Analysis, and Evaluation's Office of Policy Analysis (OPAE/OPA). In this position, her primary roles include serving as OPAE/OPA's policy liaison to the HIV/AIDS Bureau, reviewing and analyzing policies from across HHS, and provding recommendations and guidance on policy issues, especially those related to the Affordable Care Act (ACA). Kerri has been in this position since June 2013, though she first joined HRSA in December 2012 as a Public Health Analyst in the Office of Special Health Affairs/Office of Health IT and Quality. Kerri began her federal career at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), where she worked to implement accountable care organization programs under the ACA as a Health Insurance Specialist at the CMS Innovation Center.  Prior to joining the federal government, Kerri worked at NORC at the University of Chicago's Bethesda office conducting health policy research and working on teams evaluating various HHS programs. 

Kerri recieved her Master of Public Health (MPH) from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in 2012. She also holds a Bachelor of Science in Economics from Penn State.

Have you visited NHLBI’s Strategic Visioning Forum yet? The deadline for submissions is fast approaching! The forum is the website where you can submit ideas to help NHLBI identify scientific priorities for the next decade. For instructions on how to use the Forum, watch our three short videos outlining how to register, submit ideas and comment on submitted ideas: http://1.usa.gov/1DEudFd

CDR Karen Williams PharmD, MBA, joined HRSA in 2005 as a Commission Corps Officer serving in the Healthcare Systems Bureau as a Program Management Officer in the Office of Pharmacy Affairs. She joined the Division of Injury Compensation Programs in May 2011 as a clinical reviewer. CDR Williams was selected to lead the Medical Claims Review Panel (MCRP) in February 2015 and began serving as team lead for the Vaccine Injury Compensation Programs (VICP) Outreach Program in April 2015.  Her responsibilities include working with internal and external stakeholders on collaborative partnerships that help advance the outreach mission of the VICP and managing the monthly MCRP meetings.

Congratulations, MLDP Teammates! I am so excited to be a part of this program and I look forward to working with all of you. 

Katrina Jones is a IT Specialist in the Division of Business Operations (DBO) in the Bureau of Health Workforce (BHW). She has been working at HRSA and in the federal government since 2010. Currently, she is the contracting officer representative for the BHW Customer Care Center and serves as the BHW Management Information System Solution (BMISS) liaison to the National Health Service Corps and NURSE Corps Loan Repayment Programs. Prior to her government career she worked in a health center in DC. She has master’s in public health and has over ten years of healthcare experience.

Kudos to my fellow MLDP cohort team members!  I am very excited to be part of this group and look forward to meeting all of you.  

Monica-Tia Bullock is a Management Analyst for the Division of National Health Service Corps (DNHSC) Scholarship Program in the Bureau of Health Workforce (BHW).  Monica-Tia currently monitors and provides technical assistance to awardees while in full-time school status and postgraduate training.

Prior to joining HRSA in 2009, Ms. Bullock worked in the healthcare industry managing The Joint Commission evaluation surveys/reports, advisory/committee meetings, and telemedicine grants in D.C. Public Schools.  She attended Temple University before transferring to Howard University and graduating with a Bachelor of Science in Health Management.

Hello Everyone.  I am honored to be included in MLDP with such an esteemed group of people.  Impressive bios!! Congratulations on your entry into the program.  I am excited to meet you.

Amy Richter Griffin, MSW, is a Public Health Analyst in the HIV/AIDS Bureau, Division of State HIV/AIDS Programs (HAB/DSHAP), Northeast Central Services Branch.  Ms. Griffin monitors and provides technical assistance to states administering Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program Part B grants. Ms. Griffin joined the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) in March 2014.  In addition, Ms. Griffin is the co-Chair of the HAB’s Homelessness and Housing Workgroup responsible for fostering federal collaboration and improving Project Officer resources around homelessness and housing instability and represents HAB on the HRSA-wide Homelessness Workgroup.   

Prior to federal service, Ms. Griffin worked as a Project Manager at a nonprofit organization specializing in community and organizational development.  Ms. Griffin provided technical assistance to grantees of the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) in the areas of data collection and HUD reporting systems and integration of health and housing outcomes.  

Ms. Griffin earned a Masters in Social Work from the University of Michigan and a BA from Emory University in Atlanta, GA.  In 1989, Ms. Griffin volunteered as a “buddy” providing support and companionship to persons dying from AIDS. Terri` Richards is a Public Health Analyst in the HIV/AIDS Bureau, Division State HIV/AIDS Programs.  In her current role, Terri` serves as Project Officer in the Western Services Branch, and provides oversight, monitoring, and technical assistance to states administering Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program Part B grants.  Terri` joined HRSA in 2007 as a part of the HRSA Scholar’s Program.

Prior to working at HRSA, Ms. Richards served as a Peace Corps volunteer in Malawi, Africa as a rural health extension worker.  While in Malawi, Terri` mostly worked with people living with HIV, local health extension workers, and community leaders to improve the health outcomes and health infrastructure within the rural community of Mkhuzi Village.  

Terri` received her Master of Public Health (MPH) from Boston University, School of Public Health in 2005. She also holds a Bachelor of Science in Psychology from Xavier University, Louisiana.

Monumental Big Data Problem

I have monumental problem. Total obs are about 108 billion
spread over about 60 datasets of around 300gb each
or 18tb. This is a big data EG sever problem not
doable with my current workstation, I need a couple hundred cores.

The name of the game is one pass through the data.

I was hoping to use the multithreaded proc summary
however I don't need all variables crossed with all types.
I only need a couple of variables crossed with all types.

I only need sums and counts all numeric variables are whole numbers.
I mutiplied monetary values by 100 for accuracy and shorter lengths.

I only need three variables crossed
with the class variables and
no interactionns. ie va1a*varb in the types.
But I need totals for numeric variables.

For efficiency I need to do this in one pass of
the data?


These are the only variables I need with the type statement,
But I do need the () overall sum for all vars

zctuzlmmt
zllowedzmt
stzqdzrdmmt


PROC means DATA = &pgm._ptafinful sum stackodsoutput;
    class
       fff
       trznxfer
       xrvk2
       xrvkimmx
       xtztemrjv
       xrvk1
       hrrkf
       hrrmrjvkf
       klmimzfmxntymekf
       mtntfxkhrgxtuxkf
       frgkf
    ;
    var
      zctuzlmmt
      zllowedzmt
      stzqdzrdmmt
      zded
      zcohqs
      stzyhqd
      stzygrm
      vhshts
      fff
      trzqsfer
      dzys
      zzvereddzys
    ;
    types
       ()
      fff
      trznxfer
      xrvk2
      xrvkimmx
      xtztemrjv
      xrvk1
      hrrkf
      hrrmrjvkf
      klmimzfmxntymekf
      mtntfxkhrgxtuxkf
      frgkf
    ;
run;quit;

Here is a possible solution


 Use a view to get create a single char var  with the totals  you do NOT want crossed with the types.

Since all my numbers are whole numbers. 

My 9 totals(variables) I don't want crossed are put in char var tot

tot=2368@2664@6@12@50@2@0@117@32

Tot is missing for the first 2 billion obs the 2 billionth and one has the cgar string

Then just do the proc means by tot

Only adds three records for the varicble you wanted to cross

        RES                                                VARIABLE               SUM

1324    285380@261776@494@2075@3542@236@7@10475@8383     xxxxxxxxxx          16472.74
1325    285380@261776@494@2075@3542@236@7@10475@8383     yyyyyyyyyyy         17628.74
1326    285380@261776@494@2075@3542@236@7@10475@8383     zzzzzzzzzzzz         9701.32

Off List comment

Summarizing Impossibly Large SAS Data Sets for the Data ...

www.lexjansen.com/nesug/nesug97/advtut/raithel.pdf

Michael A. Raithel,

The trick in this paper is to collapse, by concatenation,
all the class variables into a long text string.

He shows how to expand the class-string afterwards and set the bits in
_type_.

Pretty neat trick.

Off list comment

 I am definately using a large cluster of unix servers and the EG SAS
grid.​ This is not a workstation problem.

 I may run 12 parallel jobs on the 300gb datasets since most daatsets are
sorted and indexed on month. Then sum the sums and counts.

 The sort on the nway string(9 classification variables) and summarization
at most granular level seems like  a possible candidate over my single pass
with a view and then proc means.

 Benchmarking will tell me which is faster.

Sort and Summary/Means are multithreaded although judging by fullstimer
they seem to be using a max of 4 threads, maybe a system setting?

Another off list reply from coleague

This discussion reminded me of a paper of Ed Heatone's where he first needed
to do some data step processing prior to a proc. I just glanced over the
abstract and saw that he does discuss SAS' multithreading and some of its
limitations.


http://www.lexjansen.com/nesug/nesug11/ld/ld03.pdf

As a side not I believe IBM's DFSORT and perhaps SYNCSORT allow the SORT
to do aggregations. In other words if you want input a huge dataset with a
nodupkey you get some simple sums and counts​ at the same time.

Your information will be very helpful. Here’s what I have so far for those areas:

Water and Sewer Infrastructure – HHS issues final recommendation for community water fluoridation, Adjusted level seeks to maintain dental health benefits of fluoride The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services today released the final Public Health Service (PHS) recommendation for the optimal fluoride level in drinking water to prevent tooth decay. The new recommendation is for a single level of 0.7 milligrams of fluoride per liter of water. It updates and replaces the previous recommended range (0.7 to 1.2 milligrams per liter) issued in 1962. Education and Job Training – NIEHS Minority Worker Training Program; The Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA), signed into law on July 22, 2014, provides new opportunities for employment and training activities to be extended to Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) recipients;  The Departments of Labor, Commerce, Education, and Health and Human Services recently published What Works in Job Training: A Synthesis of the Evidence, which includes information about both engaging employers and using labor market information.
Effective Transportation Systems - The Administration for Community Living (ACL), as part of its broader mission to maximize health, well-being, and independence for people with disabilities and older adults, has partnered with theFederal Transit Administration (FTA)<http://www.fta.dot.gov/> to improve and enhance the coordination of Federal resources for human services transportation. The Office on Disability and the Administration on Aging, now both part of ACL, have been active partners with United We Ride<http://www.unitedweride.gov/> since its inception and particularly the National Resource Center for Human Service Transportation Coordination<http://www.acl.gov/Site_Utilities/Standard_External_Disclaimer.aspx?redirection=http://web1.ctaa.org/webmodules/webarticles/anmviewer.asp?a=70&z=39> Quality Workforce Housing – ACF Runaway and Homeless Youth Programs; SAMHSA PATH Program and Services in Supportive Housing Program; HRSA Healthcare for the Homeless program; Community Services Block Grant<http://www.acf.hhs.gov/programs/ocs/programs/csbg> (Administration for Children and Families) The Community Services Block Grant funds a network of community action agencies that provides services and activities to reduce poverty, including services to address employment, education, better use of available income, housing assistance, nutrition, energy, emergency services, health, and substance abuse needs.  Funds are allocated by formula to 50 states and the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, the Northern Marianas, and state and federally-recognized Indian tribes. Emergency Services – ASPR’s Regional Emergency Coordinators (RECs) and OASH’s RHAs; 18 National Disaster Medical System teams; 17 NDMS Federal Coordinating Centers 150 Medical Reserve Corps Units and 47,690 volunteers; Hospital Preparedness Program; ESF8 Unified Planning Coalition; NPA and NPS HHS Medical Reserve Corps,

I have to have at least three month's of monthly newsletters in play on any given day. For example, I'm trying to get the March-April expanded edition finished and uploaded. The May rough draft is with the first major editor for review. I'm working on the June articles now, and I'm trying to line up stories for July and August.  Each newsletter has at least 6-12 stories. Many come from our federal office here in DC and the regional offices around the country (there are 10). Others come from state-local-tribal child support agencies and nonprofits galore. I use an Excel spreadsheet to keep track of article titles, potential authors, federal gov't POCs if the story is not from us, whether i have supporting graphics, and what state the story is in (tentative, draft, draft returned, approved, etc.).
Definitely!

Hi Arlene, Attached is a request form for external networks and some information about external networks.  The limit is 100 non HHS members, and you can have as many HHS members as you want.  If you choose to have more than 100 non -HHS members there is a fee of $2.40 per person per month.  
If you have questions we can chat.

You guys don't use smartphones to note words and photo slides?

First reaction...Oh Kim...How do you bear it?! Second reaction...I doubt it's official Gov't but Trello's free and can be quite useful in tracking things that move - it's kind of like being able to have on call a bunch of white boards on which you track whatever topics you want on them - for instance, I'm not intimately familiar with your work but you are - With Trello, you could set up a board maybe for newsletters and then set up topics (which will serve as column heads to what follows) such as "with first editor,' ''need to find graphics,' etc.  And then UNDER each of those you'd create sort of an electronic index card, for instance, for a 'story on Yammer' which you could easily drag and drop from column to column as you move it from idea to final complete story ready to use.  And THEN on each of those 'cards' - viewable when you click on them - you could add checklists of references, or whatever, other notes, AND color tags for instance to indicate your source or whatever. Nothing top secret, mind you.  I've been using it the last 18 months or so just to keep a sense of higher-level 'stuff' I'm dealing with, gradually needing to use paper lists less though when feeling a bit out of sorts, I still do make those lists sometimes - but now they're shorter and more focused because I can scan my boards for the must-dos..Am using in tandem with OneNote (where mostly I plunk emails, misc. notes that I might need later), since it's on the puter now.  .I'm finding these things helps me keep (some) sanity since we are all often asked to put something down, then pick it up a while later.  YOU certainly do. @@!
Thanks! I'll have to check it out!

No, you do not need to accept membership to a private group.  An administrator of the private group might have added you to the group.

As Announced in this group, last July, Yammer will no longer support Internet Explorer 9, and yammer.com will cease to work reliably in that browser.
A warning banner will be enabled for users who connect to Yammer with Internet Explorer 9. The banner will say:   "As of May 1st 2015, Yammer no longer supports Internet Explorer 9 and will no longer work reliably in this browser. To continue using Yammer, you must upgrade your browser. For supported versions, please see the Office 365 System Requirements (https://technet.microsoft.com/library/office-365-system-requirements.aspx).  You can also access Yammer by downloading our mobile apps (https://about.yammer.com/product/mobile/ios/)."

Please start using Firefox, Chrome, or an upgraded Internet Explorer 10 browser to access Yammer.  Contatc your OpDiv helpdesk to assist in the upgrade or adding Chrome or Firfox to your computer or tablet devices.

Lennwood Green, BS MBA is a public health analyst for HIV/AIDS Bureau, Division of Metropolitan HIV/AIDS Programs, Western Branch. He has also provided consultation on strategic and programmatic planning, evaluation and implementation of HIV/AIDS clinical and program service delivery. He has assisted communities receiving grants from the Ryan White Treatment Modernization Act to address knowledge and service gaps around supportive services for people living with HIV/AIDS. He has experience in academic research serving as the program director for the National Peer HIV Treatment Education Program based at Howard University, research coordinator at the Johns Hopkins University, Bloomberg School of Public Health and Johns Hopkins Medical Institute. Mr. Green is currently completing final for a Masters in Healthcare Administration.

Hello, Everyone! I’ve enjoyed reading all of your bios and am looking forward to meeting each of you.  I’m excited to be a part of the 2015 MLDP Cohort and to join the HRSA MLDP community! Please find my bio below. - Candace 
_________________________________________________________
Candace Webb, MPH is a Public Health Analyst in the HIV/AIDS Bureau’s Division of State HIV/AIDS Programs (HAB/DSHAP). In this position, she serves as a Project Officer in the Northeastern/Central Services Branch where she monitors and provides oversight  and technical assistance to state health and human services departments receiving over $60 million of federal assistance to administer Ryan White HIV/AIDS Program Part B and AIDS Drug Assistance Program grants. In addition to her role as a Project Officer, Candace serves as a Federal Liaison to the Strategic Leadership Council of the National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day (NBHAAD), providing advisory services to the development of programmatic activities for NBHAAD. She also serves as the HRSA representative on a Trans-HHS (CDC, HRSA, SAMHSA) Secretary’s Minority AIDS Initiative Fund Demonstration Project, providing national leadership and federal oversight to a high-profile public health demonstration project designed to reduce racial and ethnic HIV-related health disparities.  In addition, Candace co-facilitates the HRSA/CDC Integrated HIV Planning Workgroup responsible for developing the first joint HRSA/CDC guidance for state and local health departments to develop integrated HIV prevention and care plans. 

Prior to joining HRSA in November 2012, Candace worked for the National Institutes of Health as a Scientific Program Analyst in the National Institute on Drug Abuse’s Division of Epidemiology, Services, and Prevention Research. She also served as a Minority AIDS Initiative Training and Technical Assistance Liaison for SAMHSA’s Center for Substance Abuse Prevention, a Civilian Research Associate with the Department of Defense’s Military Health System, and as an Outreach Manager for Health and Reproductive Rights at the National Women’s Law Center. 

A Florida native, Candace became a Certified Health Education Specialist upon earning her Bachelor of Science degree in Health Science Education and Anthropology from the University of Florida. She also received a Master of Public Health degree in Maternal and Child Health and an Interdisciplinary Women’s Health graduate certificate from the University of South Florida, where she was awarded scholarships to study abroad at the University of Cape Town in South Africa to research child-headed households and social policies and programs for vulnerable children and youth affected by HIV/AIDS in Southern Africa.

Hello and congratulations to all my fellow MLDP colleagues. I am honored to be part of such an amazing group of people and I am very excited to be a member of this program.

Amelia Khalil has served as a Public Health Analyst with the HIV/AIDS Bureau, Division of Metropolitan HIV/AIDS Programs, Southern Services Branch since 2012.  In her role as a project officer, Amelia provides support and technical assistance to HIV/AIDS programs in Louisiana and Tennessee. In total these programs provide over twenty million dollars in medical care and treatment for people living with HIV in the South. In addition, Ms. Khalil participates in the HRSA Community Health Worker workgroup which strives to support the role of community health workers across the nation and within various bureaus of HRSA. Amelia is also a facilitator of the HRSA/CDC Integrated HIV Planning Workgroup whose charge is to develop guidance for integrated HIV prevention and care plans that meet the goals of the National HIV/AIDS Strategy. She is an advocate for change and has been an active participant on a number of improvement projects at HRSA including the HRSA Modernization Change Team.   

Before coming to HRSA, Amelia worked as a Quality Manager and Senior Contract Officer for HIV/AIDS programs in Northern Virginia.  In this position, she developed a national curriculum to train patients to be active members of quality management teams in healthcare settings and she developed community health worker programs which focused on improving health outcomes for people living with HIV. Ms. Khalil also served as a clinical trainer for the AIDS Educational Training Centers specializing in medical case management, pediatric HIV/AIDS care, and quality management.  For a large part of her career, she has provided mental health and substance abuse treatment to the most vulnerable communities. 
 
Amelia Khalil has a Master’s degree in Counseling from Slippery Rock University of Pennsylvania and a Bachelor’s degree in Political Science and Government Administration.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1882: Ernst Werner von Siemens presented his “trackless trolley” called the Elektromote in Halensee, a Berlin suburb. The world's first vehicle run like a trolleybus, it pulled electricity from overhead wires, but used road wheels instead of tracks. The Elektromote was a converted four-wheel landau carriage, equipped with two 2.2 kW electric motors transmitting the power using a chain drive to the rear wheels. It operated from April 29 to June 13, 1882, on a 540 m (591 yard) trail-track using 550 V DC voltage.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/60/First_Trolleybuss_of_Siemens_in_Berlin_1882.gif

The Fight to Protect COLAs

NTEU constantly fights to retain annual cost-of-living adjustments (COLAs) for federal retirees. Over the years, there have been calls to change the way COLAs are calculated. Some officials have advocated using a so-called “chained CPI,” which assumes that when the price of one item goes up, consumers then switch to a lower cost item to replace it.

The very point of COLAs is to protect pensions against inflation, and the chained CPI would not do that. Read the latest column at NTEU’s retirement issues page.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Scenario: You are at a conference and a grantee that you know well hands you a document with a new proposal for funding.  
What do you do?
A. Tell them it's a great idea and you will try your best to see that it is funded.
B Tell them that we do not accept unsolicited proposals and that they have to wait for a FOA to compete for funding
C. Ask them to send it to you in writing and that you will enter it into the Agency process for consideration
D. Tell them that you are not the right person to accept it and you do not know who is
* Look for an update to this post for an answer from DGP soon! *

Description Generates risk estimates and comorbidity flags from ICD-9-CM
 codes available in administrative medical datasets. The package supports
 the Charlson Comorbidity Index, the Elixhauser Comorbidity
 classification, the Revised Cardiac Risk Index, and the Risk Stratification
 Index. Methods are table-based, fast, and use the plyr package, so
 parallelization is possible for large jobs. Also includes a sample of
 real ICD-9 data for 100 patients from a publicly available dataset.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1939: RCA began regularly scheduled television service in New York City, with a telecast of President Franklin D. Roosevelt opening the New York World’s Fair. Programs were transmitted from mobile camera trucks to the main transmitter, which was connected to an aerial atop the Empire State Building. The broadcasting division of RCA was called the National Broadcasting Corporation (NBC). It was seen only in New York City and the immediate vicinity, since NBC television had only one station at the time, W2XBS Channel 1, now WNBC Channel 4. The broadcast was seen by an estimated 1,000 viewers from the roughly 200 televisions sets which existed in the New York City area at the time.

http://photo.sf.co.ua/g/286/9.jpg

Hi everyone,

Please find the following announcement on the new HHS Environmental Justice Course now posted on the HHS Learning Management System Portal. Please feel free to share with your HHS employee networks. Thanks. 

Announcement of the Newly Released HHS Environmental Justice Course
 
The HHS Environmental Justice Working Group is pleased to announce the release of an Environmental Justice (EJ) Training Course for HHS employees that is now available on the HHS Learning Management System (LMS) Portal. The EJ Training Course is a deliverable under the 2012 HHS EJ Strategy and Implementation Plan. 
 
Course Description: 
The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) Environmental Justice Course is designed to educate, provide insight, and assist HHS employees in applying EJ principles to their work. It also provides tools and resources that can help HHS employees improve the effectiveness of HHS programs, policies, and activities that impact and that serve minority, low-income, and Tribal communities that may suffer disproportionately high and adverse environmental exposures.  The course was developed by the HHS Environmental Justice Working Group.
 
Access Information:  
The HHS Learning Portal can be accessed at http://hhsu.learning.hhs.gov/. To log in, use the Windows Explorer browser along with your PIV/CAC card and passcode or your username and password. Once logged in, you can easily access the course by typing in the course name—Environmental Justice—into the LMS Portal search box. 
 
Additional info: 
•	Course Offering ID: 00111471
 
The HHS Environmental Justice Working Group is encouraging HHS employees to take the EJ Training Course and provide any comments or suggestions that the Working Group may consider to improve the training course.

Federally Employed Women is an Employee Resource Group that works to end sex and gender discrimination, encourage diversity for inclusion and equality in the workplace and for the advancement of professional growth of women in federal service.

The Parklawn chapter is a very active chapter.  We meet on the third Thursday of each month (except July when we have our National Training Program) and August because people are not usually around.  We have speakers at most of our meetings.  The speakers’ topics vary:  financial planning/retirement, personal development, professional development, workplace issues facing women, and more.  Our chapter is spread out in many Agencies in Montgomery County so we use call in and Adobe Connect so that anyone and everyone can participate.

If you are interested in joining or need more information, please call me at the number below or you can find more information at www.few.org<http://www.few.org>, click on “About Us” or “Join Now.”

Thanks for asking and don’t hesitate to let me know if you need more information.

Joy Lazaroff
Office of Communication and Education
Center for Devices and Radiological Health
Food and Drug Administration

I broadcast this representational information in compliance with CBA Article 9 Section 7 B:

Legislation to Eliminate Upcoming Tax on Health Insurance Plans

Representative Joe Courtney (D-CT) has introduced H.R. 2050, a bill that would eliminate an excise tax on health insurance plans that is currently scheduled to go into effect in calendar year 2018. Under the Affordable Care Act, a 40 percent tax will be applied to health insurance plans that exceed certain annual limits—$10,200 for those with self-coverage and $27,500 for any type of family coverage (including self plus one). The health plan excise tax was originally scheduled to take effect in 2013, but was delayed by five years over widespread concerns of its impact on health plans and enrollees.

Depending on the exact type of employer-sponsored health insurance, either the health issuer or employer must pay a tax of 40 percent of any dollar amount beyond the annual dollar caps—as an example, if the health plan’s total value exceeds the annual limit by $2,000, then the issuer or the employer must pay a tax of $800. The dollar limits are linked to inflation, and for years 2018 and 2019, are indexed to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) plus one percent. Starting in 2020, the annual caps are indexed only to the CPI, which rises more slowly than medical inflation.   

While individuals will not be directly taxed, the concern is that employers and issuers will respond to the tax by raising the enrollee share of premiums, and by scaling back plan benefits, as well as increasing deductibles, copays, and other enrollee out-of-pocket costs. 

Additionally, since the excise tax is determined solely by premium cost, and not the quality or actuarial value of a plan’s benefits, it will disproportionately impact plans that cover higher numbers of older individuals, sicker individuals, women, and those living in higher-cost areas and working in high-risk occupations.  

Like other health plans, the FEHBP will not be immune from the excise tax, or from its effects on enrollees. NTEU supports H.R. 2050, and other efforts to stop this tax.

Please visit NTEU’s web site at www.nteu.org to see what you can do.

I broadcast this representational information in compliance with CBA Article 9 Section 7 B:

The House and Senate Budget Conferees issued a Conference Agreement setting an outline for the FY 2016 budget.

The Conference Agreement keeps domestic spending at the insufficient sequestration levels for FY 2016.  As NTEU wrote to Congress earlier this month, these funding levels will make it impossible for federal employees to deliver on their agencies’ missions.

There are no reconciliation instructions to the House Oversight and Senate Governmental Affairs Committees which have jurisdiction over federal benefits such as retirement and FEHBP. That means those committees are not charged with reporting legislation that provides a certain amount of savings by July. Only a handful of committees were given reconciliation instructions, and all are charged with doing it by repealing the Affordable Care Act.

Even though the committees have not been directed by reconciliation to come up with particular savings, they may decide to consider legislation to cut federal employee benefits anyway. Any changes in legislation will have to proceed in regular order and will not have the advantage of expedited passage through reconciliation. NTEU will be watching and prepared to fight any changes.

I will keep you up-to-date on our efforts to hold-harmless federal employee compensation and end sequestration.

As always, I welcome your feedback.
Hello!  Have we met?
All SAS Tips files are still available

The Office of Personnel Management (OPM) will begin the administration of the Federal Employee Viewpoint Survey (FEVS) this week and next week. NTEU is asking employees to take the survey and respond frankly about the challenges they face.

Between late April and June, OPM will conduct the 2015 Federal Employee Viewpoint Survey.

The survey asks employees for our views on our jobs, our agency, our managers and senior leaders.

NTEU is urging all of us to take the survey and respond frankly about the impact of inadequate pay raises, budget cuts, training reductions, increased workloads, and management actions on your work life.

I understand that some of us are skeptical about the value of taking the survey. In most of our work units, we have seen little action on many of the critical areas where we have outlined need for change. In some cases when efforts are made to address survey results, front-line employees are not adequately represented on groups. Despite that, I believe it is important that bargaining unit employees take this opportunity to outline the positive and the negative and ensure agencies have the facts from the front line.

Here is why. If there are issues that need to be addressed, we need to keep the pressure on. Management cannot get a pass. We need to keep telling management where the problems are, and if there are improvements year over year, we need to tell them that, too.

Other reasons I encourage you to take the survey include:

• OPM is required by law to administer the survey
• The current administration is encouraging agencies to actively address survey results
• The results are shared with Congress and are often the subject of congressional hearings
• If frontline employees do not complete the survey, the results will be skewed toward management
• The results are used to compile the annual “Best Places to Work” ratings, which attract significant media coverage
• The results can be helpful to NTEU at the bargaining table and will help us in our ongoing work with the agency in Labor-Management Forums.

The survey is voluntary and takes approximately 25 minutes to complete. Questions may be skipped and responses may be saved so you can finish at a later time. Responses are confidential.

As always, I welcome your feedback.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1964: The BASIC program language was officially launched when two programs written in BASIC ran simultaneously on the Dartmouth Time-Sharing System. Both the language and the system were created by John G. Kemeny, chairman of the Mathematics department, and Professor Thomas Kurtz. They created BASIC so students could write programs to run on the General Electric GE-225 mainframe that was the heart of the system. Ten years later, a version of BASIC written by Bill Gates and Paul Allen was included on the Altair, the first personal computer.

http://archive.wired.com/images/article/full/2008/05/kemeny_and_kurtz_250px.jpg

This upcoming presentation might be of interest to some. Happy Friday! 

The Performance Improvement Council (PIC) hosts a bi-weekly Speaker Series at GSA where they bring someone from either within or external to government to share their experience or learning about something performance related. 

For their next session, the PIC will host Ron Sanders (bio below).  Ron will be discussing his findings from a paper he co-authored “‘I Won’t Back Down?’ Complexity and Courage in Federal Decision-Making." Good decision-making skills are a fundamental component of successful leadership. Discerning which decisions require the implementation of particular decision-making processes, however, is part of what makes a truly outstanding leader. In his presentation, Ron will discuss what makes a good leader and how they make decisions - especially when facing difficult trade-offs. 

The event will be held on Wednesday, May 6, from 9:30 - 10:30am either at 1800 F Street NW or via phone. RSVP to Melanie.burton@pic.gov for details.

Ron Sander's Bio: A VP and Fellow with the consulting firm Booz Allen, Ron served almost four decades in Federal service, including over two decades in senior human capital positions in the Air Force, DOD (as Director of Civilian Personnel), the IRS (as CHCO), OPM (as Associate Director for Strategy and Policy), and the Intelligence Community (as its CHCO). A NAPA Fellow, he received three Presidential Rank Awards from three of those agencies, as well as an Innovations in American Government award from Harvard University.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) estimate that about 3 million people in the United States are living with chronic hepatitis C.  Hepatitis C is a serious liver disease and a leading cause of liver transplantation in the United States.  CDC estimates most people are unaware of their infection.  When people remain unaware of their infection, they may transmit the virus to others and miss opportunities for curative treatment and other lifestyle changes that can prevent additional liver damage. 
Both the CDC and the US Preventive Services Task Force recommend hepatitis C screening for all people born between 1945 and 1965, regardless of any risk factors.  To get additional information about the risk for viral hepatitis, go to CDC’s risk assessment tool: http://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis/RiskAssessment/. You’ll receive a confidential personalized report that you can discuss with your health care provider. 
To learn more about Hepatitis Awareness Month, visit: http://www.cdc.gov/hepatitis/HepAwarenessMonth.htm 
To learn more about the National Viral Hepatitis Action Plan and what HHS is doing about viral hepatitis, visit: www.AIDS.gov/hepatitis

Hi Folks.. Since I am the Newbie to this group I have a ton of questions.  Like is there a program that is effective in getting Veterans on Board?  Not only from the outside but the Inside.   You see  I worked for 13 years in a postition and providing extraordinary accomplishments.  When my boss left and i applied for the job a "Veterans Certificate" was issued.. I thanked the Good Lord, thinking I had a chance.. my score was 106, not bad.. but as you know I did not get this position in fact a much less qualified person was selected(or at least in my opinion)  so of course I searched and obtain another position of lesser grade.  
My point is this ... There must be someway to correct the system, Yes there may have been someone better suited for the position, but it should have been a Veteran, any veteran..  So if our certificates have little to no bearing how do we change that.....  I know they are few and far between but if loop holes allow us to be not selected then there is a problem.    I have never stopped moving onward and upward in my career but this was a real blow to me,...  there is more to this but I won't bore you to death with it..  probably many of you have experienced this...  so What Can We Do??

Legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives to reform prescription drug pricing and contracting within the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program

Established in 1960, the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP) is the nation’s largest employer-sponsored health program covering 8.2 million federal employees, retirees, and eligible family members, and provides approximately $48 billion in health care benefits annually. Spending on prescription drugs accounts for approximately 30% of all FEHBP costs—roughly $15 billion annually.

Under current law, FEHBP health plans contract directly with pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) who operate as middlemen to negotiate prescription drug prices with drug companies and pharmacies on behalf of individual FEHBP plans. While the initial purpose of FEHBP plans contracting with PBMs was to control drug costs; there is little evidence that this has been effective.

Representative Stephen Lynch (D-MA) introduced in the House of Representatives NTEU-supported legislation that would reform FEHBP drug pricing and contracting requirements, resulting in reduced FEHBP costs and lower premiums for enrollees. H.R. 2175, the FEHBP Prescription Drug Oversight & Cost Savings Act, would provide the Office of Personnel Management enhanced oversight and contracting authority to ensure that FEHBP participants are receiving the best possible drug prices. Under the bill, PBMs would be required to return any rebates, incentives, and other price discounts obtained from drug manufacturers to FEHBP, and to adopt new transparency and disclosure policies.

The President’s FY 2016 budget to Congress proposes similar FEHBP PBM contracting reforms, estimated to save $1.5 billion over ten years. Because FEHBP is not permitted to purchase drugs off the Federal Supply Schedule and therefore pays between 15 to 45% more for drugs than other government health care programs currently do (Veterans Administration, Defense, Medicare), NTEU views this legislation as a needed step in the right direction to better control prescription drug spending in FEHBP, and to reduce costs for federal employees and retirees.

body: Here are some great ideas to make OMHA a better place.

Representative Hice (R-GA) introduced a floor amendment to the Military Construction and Veterans Affairs Appropriations Act that would have eliminated official time for agencies funded under the Act, which failed to advance
 
The House of Representatives began floor consideration of several annual appropriations bills this week including the Military Construction and Veterans Affairs Appropriations Act, which funds the Department of Veterans Affairs and many military housing and base facility construction projects.     

Congressman Jody Hice (R-GA) offered an amendment that would eliminate official time at agencies funded under this appropriations bill. While NTEU does not represent any employees at any of these specific agencies, we oppose any legislative effort to abolish or limit the use of official time.  
 
NTEU sent the attached letter to all House members, urging them to vote no on the Hice amendment, and worked with other federal unions to defeat it.  

I am pleased to report that the Hice Amendment failed on the House floor in a bipartisan vote of 190-232. One hundred eighty-three (183) Democratic members (all present) and 49 Republicans joined in voting to reject this anti-labor amendment. It is unclear whether attempts will be made to restrict the use of official time for employees funded by other appropriations bills when they are considered by the House and Senate.

NTEU will continue to oppose any legislative attempts to restrict official time going forward.

PUBLIC SERVICE RECOGNITION WEEK – MAY 3- 9 2015
Before they were famous: Celebrities who were once Federal Workers

During Public Service Recognition Week (May 3 - 9), it's important to think about the proud legacy of America's federal workforce. With the exception of astronauts and the intelligence team that caught Osama bin Laden, there aren't many federal employees whose work is heralded in newspaper headlines, yet they do a million things a day that deserve to be recognized.
Whether it's their role to inspect spinach for traces of salmonella, sound the alarm when a tornado is looming, open new international trade routes for U.S. companies to sell their products, patrol America's borders, care for our veterans or acquire the best equipment for our soldiers, federal employees' satisfaction comes from the knowledge that America is safer and stronger because they did their jobs.
Even though you don't hear about their work every day, that's not to say you've never heard of some of America's federal employees! I guarantee you have. Who are these famous former feds?
Dr. Seuss - Fifteen years before publishing The Cat in the Hat, Theodor Seuss Geisel worked as an illustrator for the U.S. Department of the Treasury in 1942.
Walt Disney - Before changing movies forever, Walt Disney delivered mail to the residents of Chicago, IL.
Walt Whitman - The American poet Walt Whitman was once a writer for the federal government, serving in the Bureau of Indian Affairs and the Attorney General's office. At the AG's office, Whitman wrote orders to investigate and prosecute a new group called the Ku Klux Klan.
Clara Barton - Before founding the American Red Cross, Clara Barton helped other Americans get their ideas off the ground during her service at the U.S. Patent Office.
Steve Carell - We all know and love Steve Carell for his antics on The Office. Before television, Steve had a different job -- as a letter carrier with the federal government.
Julia Child - During World War II, Julia Child worked as a top secret researcher for the Office of Strategic Services, a U.S. intelligence agency. For her service, she received an award that cited her "drive and inherent cheerfulness."
Ina Garten (the Barefoot Contessa) - Another federal worker turned celebrity chef, Ina Garten worked at the U.S. Office of Management and Budget as a top economist during the 1970s.
Kal Penn - The rare person who was famous first and then became a federal worker, Kal Penn worked for the Obama administration after starring in roles in the Harold & Kumar movies and television's House.
Source:  Joseph A. Beaudoin – National President, National Active and Retired Federal Employees Association (NARFE)
Quotes
Through my years in government, I have been privileged to know and work with extraordinary men and women…Day in and day out, in a variety of settings and at every level of government, these quiet heroes work to give their fellow citizens the tools and opportunities to make the most of their lives. -President Bill Clinton
Employees who use imagination, initiative and bold vision will be able to benefit in ways that they could never do before. Those who believe in government the most and who dedicate their careers to lives of public service have the greatest stake in making it work. -President Jimmy Carter
Any free government certainly needs a vast corps of well-trained, dedicated, intelligent, long service people who can take care of all the intricate jobs of operating the many and manifold activates that governments these days are compelled to carry on. – President Dwight D. Eisenhower
In the spirit of Public Service Recognition Week, I figured I’d list some thoughts to ponder. Feel free to share your views. Happy Public Service Recognition Week!: The government is us; we are the government, you and I. – President Theodore Roosevelt

SAS Innovation Writing Proc Report code faster - Little known proc report options        
                                                                          
If you submit the following code SAS will generate the column and         
define statements for an easily customisable proc report                  
                                                                          
proc report data=sashelp.class nowd named list wrap;                      
  columns _all_;                                                          
run;quit;                                                                 
                                                                          
Here is what is in the log                                                
                                                                          
proc report data=sashelp.class ls=171 ps=58 split="/" wrap named center ; 
column ( name sex age height weight );                                    
define name / display format= $8. width=8 spacing=2 left "name" ;         
define sex / display format= $1. width=1 spacing=2 left "sex" ;           
define age / sum format= best9. width=9 spacing=2 right "age" ;           
define height / sum format= best9. width=9 spacing=2 right "height" ;     
define weight / sum format= best9. width=9 spacing=2 right "weight" ;     
run;

THIS WEEKEND in Tech History

MAY 2, 2000: The United States government shut off Selective Access of the GPS system. That meant accurate positioning was no longer restricted to the U.S. military. Positioning accuracy on the first day without Selective Access went from a 45-meter radius to a 6-meter radius.

MAY 3, 1978: Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) sent the first unsolicited mass commercial email to 600 west coast ARPANET users. The message informed users of DEC’s new computer and operating system with ARPANET support, the DECSYSTEM-2020 and TOPS-20. Spam before it was spam!

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1675: King Charles II of England commissions the construction of the Royal Greenwich Observatory, which was proposed in 1674 by Sir Jonas Moore, Surveyor General at the Ordnance Office. The RGO has played a major role in the history of astronomy and navigation, and is best known as the location of the prime meridian. It is situated on a hill in Greenwich Park, overlooking the River Thames.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/Royal_Greenwich_Observatory_Postcard_c1902.jpg

Thanks Sandra.  Happy Cinco de Mayo!
Wilson : )

Cinco de Mayo: An often misunderstood holiday 
 
Cinco de Mayo is more of a California Latino tradition then a Mexican one. It was created in the 19th century to celebrate freedom. Today it’s often promoted in the U.S. as an occasion to drink.


History
During the French-Mexican War, a poorly supplied and outnumbered Mexican army under General Ignacio Zaragoza defeats a French army attempting to capture Puebla de Los Angeles, a small town in east-central Mexico. Victory at the Battle of Puebla represented a great moral victory for the Mexican government, symbolizing the country’s ability to defend its sovereignty against threat by a powerful foreign nation.
In 1861, the liberal Mexican Benito Juarez became president of a country in financial ruin, and he was forced to default on his debts to European governments. In response, France, Britain, and Spain sent naval forces to Veracruz to demand reimbursement. Britain and Spain negotiated with Mexico and withdrew, but France, ruled by Napoleon III, decided to use the opportunity to carve a dependent empire out of Mexican territory. Late in 1861, a well-armed French fleet stormed Veracruz, landing a large French force and driving President Juarez and his government into retreat.
Certain that French victory would come swiftly in Mexico, 6,000 French troops under General Charles Latrille de Lorencez set out to attack Puebla de Los Angeles. From his new headquarters in the north, Juarez rounded up a rag-tag force of loyal men and sent them to Puebla. Led by Texas-born General Zaragoza, the 2,000 Mexicans fortified the town and prepared for the French assault. On the fifth of May, 1862, Lorencez drew his army, well-provisioned and supported by heavy artillery, before the city of Puebla and began their assault from the north. The battle lasted from daybreak to early evening, and when the French finally retreated they had lost nearly 500 soldiers to the fewer than 100 Mexicans killed.
Although not a major strategic victory in the overall war against the French, Zaragoza’s victory at Puebla tightened Mexican resistance, and six years later France withdrew. The same year, Austrian Archduke Ferdinand Maximilian, who had been installed as emperor of Mexico by Napoleon in 1864, was captured and executed by Juarez’ forces. Puebla de Los Angeles, the site of Zaragoza’s historic victory, was renamed Puebla de Zaragoza in honor of the general. Today, Mexicans celebrate the anniversary of the Battle of Puebla as Cinco de Mayo, a national holiday in Mexico.
RELATED VIDEOS 

http://www.history.com/topics/holidays/cinco-de-mayo/videos/cinco-de-mayo?m=528e394da93ae&s=undefined&f=1&free=false

Clarification: Cinco de Mayo is not Mexican’s Independence Day. Mexico  actually celebrates his independence on September 16.
Instead, cinco de mayo commemorates an event that happened 50 years after Mexico wants his Independence.
It is still a great day to eat Tacos and Burritos :)
