Hi [User:1536616558:josepheakle].  We do not have anything quantitative, however the external network administrators tell me that the networks have helped in connecting public stakeholders who share common goals and increasing public service communication and collaboration with our external stakeholders.  [User:1492963206:kimdanek] [User:1490557492:audreybabkirk] - Do you have anything to add?
Thanks ☺

We use it to connect state child support contacts with each other. Child support cases often cross state lines so offices have to work together. Military/Veteran child support cases can often involve 2-3 different state/county-level child support offices. We've developed a Veterans and Military Liaison Network group externally on Yammer to assist. 

We have had a liaison in TX reach out for help in WI because the local TX office was having trouble reaching the appropriate local WI official. We connected the state liaisons with each other who helped get local contacts. 

They also ask for advice of each other when they have particularly difficult situations that the military is not being helpful with, like serving court papers to a parent on base.
We also do the same with our International Liaisons external network, though I'm less familiar with that one.

I would agree with Sandra's statement about increasing communication and collaboration with external stakeholders. 

Our experience has been that Yammer Networks are most useful when they are used by a pre-existing group that has a common task (planning a meeting, for example) or needs a place to store and access collaborative documents. Yammer has replaced Sharepoint as our go-to for collaborating with outside partners.

We had one experience of trying to build a community from scratch using a Yammer Network (intended to be a discussion forum), and we quickly found out how resource intensive that was. Actually, it really gave us an appreciation for what Sandra and the other managers do!

Now that I and my program staff have a better sense of the most effective uses for Yammer (at least among our employees and partners), I think the impact will be easier to define/measure.
The first week of May is Public Service Recognition Week.  Thank you to all my collegues for the great honorable work you all do.

A message from [User:1523797504:kateappel] 
Hello there! I’d like to ask for your help in developing an ideation project (that is launching very soon)! AIDS.gov is seeking public input on ideas/suggestions for the updated National HIV/AIDS Strategy and plans to use UserVoice to do so.

Specifically, I would like to hear your input on the following...  

1) If you have conducted an ideation project (using UserVoice, Ideascale, or similar tool), can you share your content developed for the policy areas -- moderation policies, privacy policies, about this project, and other similar sections? 

2) If you have used UserVoice for an ideation project (seeking ideas from the public on a topic), what was your experience?  What worked well?   How was the support from UserVoice helpful in implementing the tool?

3) Any lessons learned that you can share?

Very much appreciate your help and feedback!  We want it to be a great success and solicit great ideas, so we appreciate any counsel you can provide.

cc: [User:1489574182:torigarten-guest]

Not done such a project myself, but my general thought is I recommend thinking about scale. How many responses are you expecting - hundreds, thousands, more?  Do you have text analysis software? It can be very time consuming to read thousands of responses and shrink them down to common points. Also, set realistic expectations for respondents up front, about whether anyone will get back to them, etc.  How willl you fulfill human subjects research requirements? Not trying to put you off, just control the beast that can consume!
Yes!  Thank you!, Desha.  :-)

It’s the first week of May, which means Public Service Recognition Week (PSRW) is here!

Celebrated since 1985, PSRW has been designated by the president and Congress to honor you—the men and women who serve our nation as government employees and ensure that our government is the best in the world.

NTEU is proud to once again join in the celebration. After all, one of the union’s top priorities is to educate the public about how important federal workers are to the well-being of our country (watch how we do this year-round). With federal employees performing such a wide range of jobs—and often highly-specialized ones—PSRW could be celebrated year-round.

The job responsibilities of the 150,000 NTEU-represented employees at 31 agencies is so exhaustive and far-reaching, it would take weeks to acknowledge all of your accomplishments. You are law enforcement officers, scientists, attorneys and cyber-security experts. You are revenue officers, food inspectors, bank examiners, and the list goes on. Each federal worker plays an important role in keeping the country running and prospering. That’s why the theme of this year’s PSRW celebration—Government Works—is so fitting.

And thanks to you, government still works even in the face of considerable challenges. You’ve been forced to do more with less at work, and you’ve seen relentless attacks on your livelihood. PSRW is a chance to tell your story and show your pride.

This week and year-round, NTEU thanks you for your contributions that we all enjoy and rely on every day.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1949: The EDSAC (Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator), the first practical stored program computer, ran its first programs, calculating a table of squares and a list of prime numbers. It operated at a speed of 714 operations per second; putting that speed in perspective, a personal computer in 2015 with an Intel Core i7 5960X processor is rated at a peak performance of 298,190 MILLION instructions per second (MIPS) at 3.0 GHz!

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/22/EDSAC_%2819%29.jpg

body:
From our Division Director, [User:1489868145:kellytaylor]:

Good morning everybody:

Last week our 2013 DEHS Annual Report was published. We only ordered 50 copies so we could minimize waste but still have hard copies available for some of our stakeholders. Hard copies were hand-delivered to DEHS Directors in our Director Meeting last week in Oklahoma City and mailed to OEHE and Area Directors.  The PDF version of the report is now available on the DEHS website under the “Featured” section on the right-hand side.  Please feel free to print and distribute as many as you want.  

http://www.ihs.gov/dehs/ 

Our 2014 Annual Report is already going through the publication process so it won’t be long before we are finally caught up.  

If you have any ideas for improving our Annual Report, please let me know.  Enjoy reading about the great environmental health work everybody is doing across the country.

Hi All,

I wanted to share this learning opportunity with you all:

Federal Innovation: Doing It Better
Digital Viewcast
May 8th, 2015
2PM to 3PM ET

REGISTER TODAY
http://link.govexec.com/542dc26f3b35d0e53a9a949c2kqpm.2cn/VTlPbkmO7V_SeDeqB11ed

Persistent. Common Good-Focused. Willing Deviation from the Norm.

These are characteristics of a successful government innovator identified by a pool of respondents in a 2015 Government Business Council report. Why is Innovation critical to the future success of federal agencies? The report found that Innovation is necessary within federal agencies to offset tighter budgets and prevent deviation from mission goals.

So what’s hindering Innovation in federal agencies? Leadership. Sixty percent of federal employees cite lack of leadership within their agency as the main deterrence in adopting new ideas. This viewcast will provide you with the tools to become a successful federal Innovator by focusing on:

Inhibitors of Innovation and how to overcome Best Practices of Innovation to cultivate creativity Culture and Leadership of Innovation and how it can either help or hinder Structure of Innovation to ensure new ideas thrive

Panel Includes:
Dan Doney, Chief Innovation Officer, Defense Intelligence Agency Barbara Lopresti, Chief of the Technologies Management Office, Census Bureau Roger Baker, Former Assistant Secretary and CIO, Veterans Affairs Tim Hoechst, Chief Technology Officer, Agilex Technologies

REGISTER TODAY
http://link.govexec.com/542dc26f3b35d0e53a9a949c2kqpm.2cn/VTlPbkmO7V_SeDeqC9992
Welcome [User:1542464339:caprimcduffie] !
Welcome [User:1542462407:robertrixham] !
Welcome [User:1542451875:nandakandala] !

Hello ladies,

I hope your week is going well. I just wanted to touch base and see how you were doing with regards to MLDP work. I have been looking though the Passport to Health packet and have even come up with three health goals. I think I will type them up nicely and then post them in my office and at home as motivation. What tips do you have for keeping track with your goals?

Don't feel pressured to share your goals, but I will share mine! Health and fitness is a real passion of mine, and I am always open to discuss ways to get and stay well!

My goals:

1. Run at least 10 miles a week most weeks, and between 15-20 miles a week when training for a half-marathon (I have halfs scheduled for September and November).

2. Go to bed by 11 pm so that I can get up by 5 am during the week for morning workouts.

3. Keep the kitchen stocked with healthy food (fruit, veggies, healthy dips, lean protein) so that I don't feel "compelled" to binge on junk.

I think that if I can commit to these goals, I will go a long way to staying healthy.

Hold me accountable please!

Take care,

Monica

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1952: British radar engineer Geoffrey Dummer introduced the concept of the integrated circuit at the Symposium on Progress in Quality Electronic Components in Washington, D.C. The integrated circuit brings together components with different functions and puts them in a compact miniature board. It changed computing and ushered in the digital era, much as the steam engine helped usher in the Industrial Revolution.

Someone told me once that politics is relationships. Being politically savvy and socially intelligent are paramount for leadership. These skills are essential to gain the respect and cooperation we need to get things done across organizations. As leaders, we need to enhance the skills necessary to get people to cooperate with us, socialize our ideas and build bridges. 

What are your thoughts?

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1790: The French National Assembly acted on a motion from Bishop Charles Maurice de Talleyrand to create a simple and stable decimal system of measurement units. The earliest metre unit chosen was the length of a pendulum with a half-period of a second. The system, also supported by Great Britain and the newly independent United States, slowly evolved and was ultimately introduced by the French First Republic in 1799 as the Metric System.

http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Talleyrand-perigord.jpg

I attended a webinar entitled "Communicating Effectively: Making Requests, Offers, and Promises" hosted by OPM. I have attached a copy of the slides for the group. The presenters discussed the elements of making effective requests, which include: 1) a committed speaker; 2) a committed listener; 3) specification of future actions and conditions of satisfaction; 4) time frame; 5) mood of the request; and 6) context. The elements of an offer should follow the same six categories. 

My question for the group is: How do you follow up with someone who has made a promise to accomplish a task but has not followed through on the date that they agreed to finish the task?
Is it possible for you to share a link to the video?

The 4% rule. Interesting article in the NYT. Hoever, I learn as much from the comments to the article, as the article. http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/09/your-money/some-new-math-for-the-4-percent-retirement-rule.html?emc=eta1&_r=0

This from a commenter: It's really too bad that the reporter failed even to mention the existence -- for about 15 years! -- of sophisticated software that calculates how much one can spend per year over a lifetime. The user inputs key assumptions about longevity, rates of return, inflation, changing standards of living over time, desired estate, replacement of cars, change of home, etc. etc. The package I've used for nine years is called ESPlanner (about $150, with a basic version free online). It was developed by Boston Univ. economist and retirement planning expert Lawrence Kotlikoff. 

I have no financial interest in Kotlikoff's product, but year in and year out, I have found ESPlanner to be an essential tool for addressing the knotty calculations this article struggles to grapple with. If you're comfortable with financial matters, you can run it yourself, and you'll develop a deep understanding of the multiple choices and variables that are driving your retirement lifestyle. Otherwise, find one of the many financial planners who have integrated ESPlanner into their practice.

Jessica,
That is the million dollar question. In my experience, I was better able to handle the situation when its someone I do not have a relationship with or who is a close colleague. I feel very comfortable calling, emailing or speaking with the individual in person to give a gentle push or inquire why they have missed the deadline. In the past, when this happened to someone I felt close too, I took it personally and was very disappointed.  I felt since this person was a friend, my request should have been a priority. I quickly realized that was not the case in our work environment and many people have competing prioties. With this awareness about myself, I had to de-personalize things and treat every situation the same. This means gentle pushes for everyone, and maybe some not-so-gentle pushes for people I am closer too- if I can get away with it. 
I'm very interested to read about other experiences.
The new EVS is out.  I encourage everyone to participate :)

I think gentle reminders are a good thing.  Sometimes things just slip through the cracks and getting a reminder will help.  Usually when I miss a deadline its because too many things are happening at one time.  I think a couple pointers:  
1.  Always be kind and objective in your communication.  If you are annoyed or have pre-judeged why someone was late with a deadline, it may show in your communication.
2.  Especially as a supervisor, you need to be consistent.  If one week, you are sending reminders and then you let deadlines pass the next week, its hard for the people you supervise to be consistent.
3.  Not everyone uses the same technology to communictate.  Some people like phone, some email, and some face-to-face contact.  If you have tried one modality and it did not work, try a different one.
Lol! That's funny. And no worries. I actually don't mind people asking at all. At the very least it often serves as a good ice breaker/ conversation starter. :-)

(Insurance Specialist) has [Tag:80903:joined] the U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services (HHS) network. Take a moment to welcome Sherlene.

This is an excellent and very practical question, Jessica.  I’ve experienced this scenario and have learned that different strategies work and motivate people differently. One strategy that worked effectively for me with a person in a “senior” position that missed a deadline for a workgroup assignment was that I sent them a follow-up Outlook calendar appointment after they’d missed their deadline to establish a 1-1 working meeting to facilitate their completing the time-sensitive task.  Since this person was in a “senior” position and had a full schedule I had to be flexible and conduct the follow-up appointment via Lync since we were both working remotely and the task needed to get done. We used the Lync screen share and call functions so I could provide this person real-time support to help them complete their assignment.  I learned this person had many questions that had delayed their finishing the assignment in the first place, but didn’t have time to reach out for support and this had ultimately been the cause of their missed deadline. Using collaboration technology, such as Lync, and being flexible, especially with a person in a “senior” position, helped me help this person get their task completed.

New blog post from the HHS IDEA Lab -- "FDA’s New Innovation Suite - The Transformative Potential of Space"  http://www.hhs.gov/idealab/blog/

Date:  Tuesday, May 12, 2015   
Time:  11 a.m. – 12:00 p.m. EST

Place: Fernwood, 3E02

Topic: Agile, Hybrid projects and Risk Management
Speaker: Mark Tolbert, PMP; Best Practices Team, LLC.

Overview:  The presentation will cover a number of reasons why organizations today need to be up-to-date with Agile methodologies. No one process or methodology fits all situations: Agile is not a panacea for all projects. The speaker will discuss what types of projects are best suited for a more traditional project management approach. Most projects today really require a “hybrid” approach, and many “Agile projects” do evolve into “hybrid projects,” and the key people involved in project management – (the scrum master and product owner) – will also need to be well versed in Agile, as well as traditional project management methods. Since Risk management is a key part of successful project management the presentation will also explore how Agile methodologies provide different approaches for protecting the project from uncertainty than do the traditional methods.

To attend the meeting through Adobe Connect: 
1.      Enter Connect at the URL provided above.
2.  Login as a Guest using the format <Full Name, IC>. Please do not enter only first names or nicknames. If requesting PDU, use the format <Full Name, IC, PDU>.  
3. Once you’re in the meeting room, you will get a prompt to join the audio conference. In the “ Join Audio Conference” dialog box , please choose  the first option “Dial-out (Receive a call from the meeting).” 
4.  Enter a number where the system will call you (e.g. a desk number).
5. If you don’t see the “Join Audio Conference” dialog box  when you enter the meeting room, please click the telephone button on the main menu bar on the top and the dialog box will open up.
6. If you have not attended an Adobe Connect meeting before test your connection: https://webmeeting.nih.gov/common/help/en/support/meeting_test.htm

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1936: University of Washington education professor August Dvorak, along with his brother-in-law, Dr. William Dealey, received a patent for his new more efficient keyboard layout. Dvorak and Dealey's objective was to scientifically design a keyboard to decrease typing errors, speed up typing, and lessen typist fatigue. They engaged in extensive research while designing their keyboard layout. In 1914 and 1915,Dealey attended seminars on the science of motion and later reviewed slow-motion films of typists with Dvorak. Dvorak and Dealey meticulously studied the English language, researching the most used letters and letter combinations. They also studied the physiology of the hand. The result in 1932 was the Dvorak Simplified Keyboard. While widely recognized as superior to the QWERTY layout, the Dvorak keyboard is not widely used.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dvorak_Simplified_Keyboard#/media/File:KB_DSKpatent.svg
This is quite novel.  I love it!

The differences between IDIQ and BPA are very clear in the FAR, however, the interpretation can sometimes perplex even the most seasoned acquisition specialist.

BPA (FAR 8.405-3)
-fill repetitive needs for supplies or services
-requested services are of a very specific nature
-may not require SOW.
-BPA is NOT a contract

IDIQ (FAR 16.5)
-applies to specific areas of support, but not definitive
-vendors have a minimum and maximum order amount
-require SOW. and requirements must align with IDIQ scope
-contracts are issued as Task Orders (non-construction) or Job Orders (construction)

These are just some key points, but there is much more to it.  I would recommend reading the identified sections in the FAR for the definitive explanation.

Some folks have asked for an overview of what an IDIQ is all about.  Here is an excellent piece from the International Stability Operations Association that may provide some perspective.  Let me know what you think. [Tag:5847819:thecorner] [Tag:5847820:idiq]

In response to a great question posed to [User:1489919384:donnaberry] on the differences between BPA and IDIQ, I found this article that provides a good overview of an IDIQ.  I will continue to look for resources that better explains the BPA as well.

This can be a very precarious situation, especially in the workplace.  I have experienced this and found it partifularly difficult when I had no formal authority over colleagues who have committed to both the task and the timeline.

In this situation, I sent an email to the individual reminding them of the deadline and asking if there were any questions regarding the task.  I received no response.  When the task still wasn't completed when our group met, I asked the individual if they would like to go work on the task while the group reviewed other sections.  It was a very direct request, and not a very comfortable ask, but it was unfair to slow down the progress of the entire group.

Just sharing info below...

Help Others in Your Community With an MA in Counseling

The field of clinical mental health counseling is growing each year, presenting many exciting opportunities for individuals interested in a career in human services.
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, between 2012 and 2022, employment of mental health counselors will grow by approximately 29 percent.	 
 

This expansion will result in approximately 165,100 jobs for counselors. 
This job growth can be attributed to recent changes in health care regulations, which mandate that insurance companies cover mental health issues the same as they would other chronic diseases.
 
 
Therefore, mental health centers, treatment, and counseling facilities will need to hire more counselors to meet this demand.
Counseling@Northwestern, the Master of Arts in Counseling Program delivered online from The Family Institute at Northwestern University, will prepare you to provide the highest quality mental health services to those in need as a clinical mental health counselor.

Through comprehensive clinical training and weekly meetings with a dedicated group supervisor, you will develop an in-depth understanding of the psychodynamic perspective and effectively use this advanced model to help individuals and families lead stronger, healthier lives.
This message has been generously sponsored by Northwestern University.

 
Request Information at: https://requestinfo.counseling.northwestern.edu/index1.html?s=volmatchflatemail&l=may12_2015&utm_source=volmatchflatemail&utm_campaign=may12_2015&utm_medium=email&sendid=00000430

Thanks for posting Jessica! I too, believe that the nature of your working relationship helps determine the best route for follow-up. If I am not familiar with a colleague who committed to a task, and did not follow through by the deadline-I kindly, reply to the email (if one exists) that states the colleague's commitment to their responsibility, and ask when I can expect their deliverable, task, etc. As Amelia mentioned, a colleague with whom I have a better working relationship with, I would take a more informal approach; this could be via a chat in the hall or a quick phone call. If after follow up., I have still received no feedback or response to the task, if I am in the capacity to complete the task on my own, I will opt to do this to avoid further conflict.

§46.101 To what does this policy apply?

(1) Research that is conducted or supported by a federal department or agency, whether or not it is regulated as defined in §46.102, must comply with all sections of this policy.

(5) Research and demonstration projects which are conducted by or subject to the approval of department or agency heads, and which are designed to study, evaluate, or otherwise examine:
(i) Public benefit or service programs; (ii) procedures for obtaining benefits or services under those programs; (iii) possible changes in or alternatives to those programs or procedures; or (iv) possible changes in methods or levels of payment for benefits or services under those programs.
http://www.hhs.gov/ohrp/humansubjects/guidance/45cfr46.html

This is what another commenter had to say (about 600+ comments). I am interested in checking ES Planner out. The News Hour interviews  Lawrence Kotlikoff all the time, I posted a link earlier this year. " The model proposed by Prof Laurence Kotlikoff at Boston University takes into account that spending is not uniform in retirement. His models do "smoothing" of withdrawls over short periods of time, and calculate the impact on long term asset preservation. The models use a technique known as "dynamic programming" (used in engineering) in addition to monte-carlo simulation of market returns to update the spending plan every year. Early in retirement you may still have a mortgage so your spending may decline in later years. In later years medical costs will increase. It helps to see into the financial future as much as you can.

I'm not an attorney, and clearly Kate should consult with one, but crowd-sourcing ideas from an online community (if that's what UserVoice is) just doesnt sound like formal "research" to me: respondents are not being selected for a study on the basis of characteristics related to the testing, they are submitting info voluntarily, and the "data" are  ideas and advice, and not PII. Kate is exploring, not evaluaing or testing with a methodology consistent across subjects.

This is good stuff but I am still missing out on how/why I should choose one over the other.  My analogy is that I need a place to live.  So, I can rent or I can buy.  If I buy, I "own" the place, if I rent the landlord does but both result in a place to live.  The kinds of things I need to think through to make a decision include: how much money I have, how long I plan to stay, the kind of place I can afford with each choice (and that alone probably requires a lot of decisions about trade offs), what is available where I want to live and expected ROI.  

So, it appears to me that either an IDIQ or a MAS BPA will give me a group of vendors from which to compete individual task orders (a place to live). What are the business needs that each choice addresses?  For example, what should make me care that one is a contract and the other isn't?  How big of a deal is it that IDIQ TOs cannot be competed?  What are the issues with determining the min and the max?  How does vehicle set up differ?  (I am getting the sense that an IDIQ takes more work to set up, less to maintain).  Our systems can't handle different line items for a BPA so that impacts the administration costs.  What are the costs/benefits of going through FedBizOpps vs. selecting a number of vendors from the FSS and requesting they respond?

Another set of questions exist around potential vendors.  Does the choice of vehicle impact who responds? 

I hope this helps clarify my question.

Thank you!!

Hi [User:1542464339:caprimcduffie] The Social Media, Web-Based Interactive Technologies, and the Paperwork Reduction Act  Memorandum explains that "Feedback requests. Under existing OMB policy, agency uses of general or undifferentiated “suggestion boxes” are not covered by the PRA. Similarly, an agency does not trigger the PRA’s requirements when it posts its email address or uses an application for brainstorming or idea-generating on its website to enable the public to submit feedback. However, if an agency requests information from respondents beyond name and email or mailing address (e.g., age, sex, race/ethnicity, employment, or citizenship status), this request is covered by the PRA because it seeks information beyond what is “necessary” for self-identification of the respondent. 
If an agency asks the public to respond to a series of specific questions or a series of specific prompts that gather information (e.g., for purposes of aggregation or survey) about whether, for example, a particular program is or is not effective, the collection of information is subject to the PRA. However, the PRA does not apply to posts that allow members of the public to provide general or unstructured feedback about a program (such as a standard Federal Register notice, a request for comments on a report or proposed initiative, or a request for ideas, comments, suggestions, or anything else that might improve the program)."  

Thus, I believe that the intent of AIDS.gov to seek public input on ideas/suggestions for the updated National HIV/AIDS Strategy is in line with current regulations and practices.  

In fact many government agencies are encouraged to reach out to the public using Ideation platforms like "UserVoice" to get ideas and suggestions for their programs and strategic plans.  Digital.gov has an article on government crowdsourcing.  https://www.digitalgov.gov/2014/12/30/opening-government-through-federal-crowdsourcing/

SAS Innovation: Instantaneous formula evaluation in old text editor

Ignore if you do not use the old text editor. The one
that supports prefix commands and clean command line.

see for clean version
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/35648330

* suppose you have formula below in the old text program
  editor.

  2*constant('PI')**2

  If you highlight the formula and type
  'evl' on the old editor clean command line.
  Or highlight and hit cntl-e

  You will see this in the log
  RESULT=19.739208802

  note if you use sysevalf you would need to remove
  the quotes, add sysevalf and sysfunc. This
  destroys the text. Reverse changes to get text back.

  %put result=%sysevalf(2*%sysfunc(constant(PI))**2);

  result=19.7392088021786

  You could eliminate typing evl by placing

  store;note;notesubmit '%evla';

  on a cntl-e function key

Note SAS removed the 'store' command from the enhanced editor a long time ago. Others are gone or do not work well recently.

* turn on command macros;
options cmdmac;

* place these two macros in autocall
  member evl;

%macro evl / cmd;
   store;note;notesubmit '%evla;';
   run;
%mend evl;

%macro evla;
   %symdel __evl;
   filename clp clipbrd ;
   data _null_;
     infile clp;
     input;
     put _infile_;
     call symputx('__evl',_infile_);
   run;quit;
   data _null_;
     result=&__evl;
     put result=;
   run;quit;
%mend evla;


* if you want to use this in the
  enhanced editor you need to highlight
  formula -> hit cntl-c -> type evl on
  command line. You may need to remove
  the 'store' command.

Most of the commands below do not work well in the enhanced editor and
fail miserably in all the super enhanced editors like EG;


 USEFUL EDITIING COMMANDS IN THE SIMPLE KEYBOARD CENTRIC OLD TEXT EDITOR
 ******************************************************************
  The prefix area  Many of these commands can be put on function keys using a ':', ie :ts.
  SAS is slowly removing some of these functions from the old simple text editor.

  D        Delete current line
  I        Insert a line here
  C        Copy current line
  D99----  Delete next 99 lines (also could cut with mouse)
  I999---  Insert 999 blank lines useful when autoadd is set
  IB55---  Insert 55 lines before
  C3-----  Copy next three lines to some target
  A000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy after)
  B000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy before)
  M------  Move this line somewhere
  M3-----  Move next 3 lines somewhere
  O3-----  Move source lines over these lines
  R3-----  Replicate the next 3 lines

  DD00103  Block delete   CC00103  Block Copy    MM00103  Block Move
  0000104                 0000104                0000104
  DD-----                 CC-----                MM-----

  OO00103  Target Over    RR3----  Block Replicate
  0000104                 0000104
  OO-----                 RR-----

  (4-----  Shift left first 4 columns into bit bucket (distructive shift)
  )4-----  Shift right first 4 columns (distructive shift)
  >5-----  Nondistructive shift right
  <5-----  Nondistructive shift left
  >>5----  Non distructive shift right of a block of commands
  0000101
  0000102
  >>-----
  <<,)),(( Similar to single character versions
  UC----- Upper case line  - more useful on function key as :UC
  UC26--- Upper case next 26 lines
  LC----- Lower case line
  LC26    Lower case next 26 lines
  LLC---- Block of lines -lower caSE
  UUC
  TF----- Text flow lines until blank line
  TS----- Text split at cursor better on function key as :tf
  MASK - BUILD TEMPLATE FOR ENTERING DATA


   no need to look up a P-Value
   put this on any command line
   %put %sysfunc(probnorm(1.96)); /* try this on command line */

   ?          - previous command history
   subtop     - submit top line of editor
   icon
   rchange    - change on function key hit
   rfind      - find on function key hit
   save  prg       /# save program in your profile  ie pgm.source #/
   copy  prg       /# recalls program from your profile #/
   change     - c today yesterday ic all   ( ignore case all)
   cols
   reset
   keys
   top
   bot
   n           - go to line n
   left  n
   right  n
   spell all - check spelling of all words in editor
   autoadd   - add aline at a time to editor ( usewith mask and bounds )
   vscroll 25 - set scroll amounts for forward and backward
   hscroll 10
   backward max n
   forward max  n
   bounds
   mask
   copy
   paste
   find - f 'data' first last next prev prefix suffix word
   find 'Mac' prefix
   change - c todat yesterday ic all
   rchange - change on function key hit
   rfind   - find on function key hit
   mark - highlight string, lines for submit or edit
   mark block - highlight rectangle within editor
                does not have to be full lines
   store
   zoom z
   up 2
   down 4
   CAPS on/off
   home
   cursor
   nums on/off
   %let
   vt
   pmenu off /# functon key #/
   pmenu on
   end
   print
   submit
   unmark unmark all
   tabs
   redo
   nums on/off
   fse
   fsv
   fsb
   libn
   filen
   fslist
   vt
   print

   Example 1 -- Just a dumb script
   --------------------------------

   1;F ' ';MARK;HOME;2;HOME;MARK;HOME;STORE;HOME;UNMARK;

   If the first line in active editor contains

   000001 %Macro MyLongMacroName

   This script will put MyLongMacroName into the paste buffer.
   You can then paste MyLongMacroName anywhere you want.
   (This only works on windows). Try it, just copy
   the one line script to the command line.

The PDF Portfolio feature is quite useful to package and organize large sets of files.  My largest PDF Portfolio is 70 files.  It sounds daunting, but the key is having a clear idea of how you want to organize the files before creating the Portfolio.  I learned by making a lot of mistakes at first, and sometimes it was easier to start from scratch than trying to reorganize or fix the problem, particularly in the previous version of Adobe Professional.   I generally create a table of contents with page view links that go to each file when clicked.  I have also added a button on every page within each file to return to the table of contents.  Updating revised files and inserting new files is relatively easy.

General Programming: A lexicon for programmers. Kingdom, Phylum, Class and Order.

see for cleaner version
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/35683346

Build yourself a dictionary of TLAs(triple letter
acronyms) and use when appropriate.. This will
make your programs more understandable by you and others.
Allow many exceptions where appropriate.

Also think Kingdom, Phylum, Class and Order hierarchy.

Suppose you have six blood pressure measuements

BpdSit     diastolic sitting
BpdLay     diastolic Supine
BpdTal     diastolic Standing

BpsSit     systolic sitting
BpsLay
BpsTal

If you do this the ':' operator and arrays are your friend.

Now suppose you want some averages

  mean(of bpd:) Diastolic mean
  mean(of bps:) Systolic  mean

  mean(of bp:)  Overall mean

/* why say the same thing six different ways note Aev instead of ae */
/* Three letter boundaries are also your frien.

AESPDT         AevDteEnd
AESTPDT        AevDteEnd
AEEND          AevDteEnd
AEENDT         AevDteEnd
AEENDATE       AevDteEnd
AEFINALDT      AevDteEnd

I use dataset prefixes

proc sort data=TrtAll out=TrtAllSrt; * note Srt for sort

proc transpose data=TrtAll out=TrtAllXpo; * note Xpo for transpose;

data TrtAllNrm; * Note nrm for normalize;
  array trt[*]  Trt:;
  array yer[2010:2015] yr1-yr15;
  array val[6]  salary1-salary3;
  array nam[6]  ('Doctor' 'Nurse', 'PA');
  set TrtFat;
  do i= to 3;
    hsp_salary=val[i];
    hsp_occupation=nam[i];
    output;
  end;
  keep hsp_:;
run;quit;

data TrtNrmRpt * dataset for a report;

data TrtNrmFin * final dataset;

Now suppose you want to delete all the Trt datasets in work

proc datasets;
  delete Trt:;
run;quit;

* input the Trt Datasets;
data TrtAddDsn;
  set Trt: indsname=dsn;;
  datasetname=dsn;
run;quit;

Other uses of colon with hierarchies

* names that start with J;
proc print data=sashelp.class(where=( name =: 'J'));
run;quit;

/*
Obs    NAME       SEX    AGE    HEIGHT    WEIGHT

  6    James       M      12     57.3       83.0
  7    Jane        F      12     59.8       84.5
  8    Janet       F      15     62.5      112.5
  9    Jeffrey     M      13     62.5       84.0
 10    John        M      12     59.0       99.5
 11    Joyce       F      11     51.3       50.5
 12    Judy        F      14     64.3       90.0
*/

* names with first letter after R;
proc print data=sashelp.class(where=( name >: 'R'));
run;quit;

/*
Obs     NAME      SEX    AGE    HEIGHT    WEIGHT

 18    Thomas      M      11     57.5        85
 19    William     M      15     66.5       112
*/


* names beween Je and Jo;
proc print data=sashelp.class(where=('Je'<=:name<=:'Jo'));
run;quit;

/*
Obs    NAME       SEX    AGE    HEIGHT    WEIGHT

  9    Jeffrey     M      13     62.5      84.0
 10    John        M      12     59.0      99.5
 11    Joyce       F      11     51.3      50.5
*/


There are letters in english that sound the same. These are useful for
   building unique TLAs

     y and i
     d and e, t, z, v and p

     there are many combinations of letters that can be replaced with
     one letter ie zro and zero

   Three letter variable names

   Pid Study + Patient
   Pat Patient
   Sty Study
   Cnr Center

   Itt Intend to Treat
   Saf Safety Set

   Xpo Transpose
   Srt Sort
   Nrm Normalize (make long and skinny)
   Fat Denormalize

   Hgt Height
   Wgt Weight

   Syt Site
   Tym Time
   Nyn Nine

   Die Died or Death

   Zro Zero

   Beg Begin or Start
   End Stop or End

   Bas Base AgeBas for baseline age

   Min Minimum
   Max Maximum
   Avg
   Sum
   Std
   Sde Standard Error
   Q02 Q3
   Q03 Q4
   P95
   P05

   1st First (almost allways a suffix )
   2nd
   3rd
   4th
   5th


   Dte Date (Not DT)
   Bf4 Before
   Aft After

   Exp - Exposure
   Lab - Laboratory
   Eos - End of Studt
   Eot - End of Treatment
   Dem - Demographics


    Why I coded 'BpsSitDte' instead of 'SPBDATESIT'
   (Think of  Kingdom, Phylum, Class and Order hierarchy)

     BpsSitDte  ( not SPBDATESIT  )

        Bp    Blood Pressure                  Kingdom
         s    s - systolic, d-diastolic       Phylum
       Sit    Lay - Supine, Sit - Sitting     Class
       Dte    Dte, WekAve, WekMax DteMax ..   Order

     Some Possble BP names using TLA building blocks)

         BpdLayDte
         BpdLayWekAve  ( same number of lettters as SPBDATESUPN )

         BpsLayDte
         BpsLayDteMax

         BpdSitDte
         BpdSitWekMin

         BpsSitDte
         BpsSitMthMax

Reminder in case you don’t have this on your calendar yet! Today is the HHS Digital Media Round Table Call - where we discuss timely topics, questions, share news and learn from each other’s experience –

Once a month a group of people jump on an old media technology (the telephone) to talk about new media issues (not the telephone). If you have a question or topic that you’d like to throw out to the group, you can send it ahead of time, or just plan on bringing it up yourself. Or just jump in other people’s topics. Or just silently, lurkingly, listen in…

Join us!

2nd Wednesday of the Month
2:00 PM

Dial +1 (312) 878-3070

Access Code: 435-425-958

body:
From our Division Director [User:1489868145:kellytaylor] :
It is my pleasure to officially announce the selection of the Indian Health Service Environmental Health Specialist of 2014. Congratulations to Landon Wiggins from the Phoenix Area! Landon was recognized as being instrumental in improving the lives of American Indians through model public health practices, not only by his colleagues in Phoenix Area, but by the Environmental Health Services Directors from all the Areas. 

You can  read Landon’s award nomination on the DEHS website.  For those few EH staff that don’t have the DEHS website as their internet start page, follow this link to get to the DEHS website:  www.ihs.gov/dehs.

Seven Areas submitted their Environmental Health Specialists of 2014 as nominees for the national Indian Health Service award.  

You can see pictures of all the Area and the National Environmental Health Specialists of 2014 on the DEHS website too.

It is clear Environmental Health staff are doing innovative work in their communities to improve the lives of American Indians and Alaska Natives. 

Congratulate the national and Area winners next time you see them working hard in their communities:

(National) Phoenix – Landon Wiggins 

•	Alaska Area, Jennifer Skarada
•	Albuquerque Area, Molly Madson
•	Bemidji Area, Connie Giroux
•	Great Plains Area, Tim Balderrama
•	Oklahoma City Area, Calvin Underwood
•	Portland Area, Matthew Ellis

Great job everyone!

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body:
Although rare, HRSA does accept unsolicited proposals.  The Agency receives between 15-25 a year.  An unsolicited request for funding is a written proposal generated solely on an organization’s own initiative and not in response to any formal solicitation by HRSA or an informal solicitation by HRSA staff.  If you receive one, send it to the DGP General Box: DGP@hrsa.gov. You do not need to review the proposal at this time; simply send it to DGP upon receipt, without action.

DGP will immediately conduct a preliminary screening to determine if it falls within HRSA’s mission, and if it does, determine the potential award instrument.  DGP will then route it to the appropriate program office for a formal determination to be made on whether or not it should be considered for funding.  Because an unsolicited proposal is a form of single-source award and an exception to maximum competition, the controlled process will ensure that such exceptions are limited.  For an unsolicited request to be considered for funding it must, at a minimum, be for a project that 1) is truly unsolicited; 2) falls within HRSA’s mission; and 3) is not within the scope of any current, pending or planned funding opportunity.  In cases where the three criteria above are met, funds are available, and the PO pursues a single-source award for the unsolicited request for funding, the PO must seek their Associate Administrator and follow all governing policies and procedure for requesting a single-source award as delineated GPAM Chapter 502.4.5.

If your program is not going to pursue funding the unsolicited proposal, simply respond to DGP within the time specified and DGP will prepare a response to the requester.

For more information visit the HRSA SOP on Unsolicited Proposals.
https://sharepoint.hrsa.gov/ofam/SOPs/Unsolicited%20Request%20for%20Funding%20proposal%20August%202014.pdf

It is productized in that the parameters are pre-defined (what work will be performed, how it will be performed and any outcomes/output)  and you can simply say “I want one of those.”  The vendor will understand exactly what they need to do without a SOW.

body:
The Federal Consulting Group (FCG), which is part of the Department of Interior, will be hosting a Federal Organizational Development Community of Practice (OD CoP) meeting on June 2nd from 9-noon.  The meeting will be held at the U.S. Government Accountability Office, 441 G Street, NW, Washington, DC 20548.  

It is our hope that we can help each other, as Federal OD practitioners, to better meet the OD challenges being faced by Federal Agencies. This session is open ONLY to current Federal employees who are OD practitioners (whether as a formal or informal role) or supervising OD efforts.  Contractors may NOT attend.  

Due to Federal building security requirements, you will need to register by Friday May 29th at the following link: http://www.fcg.gov/DC_ODCoP . 

Please be sure to have your Federal ID to go through security at the meeting site.

For questions on the Federal OD CoP sessions, please contact Dr. Steve Frieman (303-317-7386; Steven_Frieman@ios.doi.gov )

Mission: This group is dedicated to the important next step after Big Data has been compiled: extracting business and mission value, and devising better ways of explaining that value to executives who control decisions, budgets, and futures.
Subject matter: Big Data, smart analytics, business intelligence, reporting systems, communication strategies for informing decision-making.
Mantras: (1) It’s not about the computing toys, stacks, clusters, or glitz: it’s about what you do with it. (2) Be good to your statistically significant other. (3) If you really must innovate at least do it disruptively, because if it’s not disruptive it’s not an innovation.

Nineteenth century London, England, was one of the world's largest and most densely-populated cities in the world at the time, but crucially it lacked both piped drinking water to residences and a disposal system to take human waste from them. Water was manually fetched daily from street corner pumps, while waste was shoveled monthly out of basements into tanks on horse-drawn carts - a situation ripe for spread of disease. In 1854, at the height of one of three great cholera epidemics that claimed 50,000-70,000 lives each time, the medical establishment blamed cholera on “miasma” (meaning "something in the air") and on the working class's over-consumption of gin (gin parlors being the marijuana dispensaries of their day). One independent medical thinker, Dr. John Snow, thought otherwise: he mapped cholera deaths in Soho with a street bar-chart, and related house-level mortality rates to distance from the Broad Street public water pump. His use of real data proved the water-borne nature of the disease's transmission, led to the pump being closed, and ushered in the era of great Victorian urban public health improvements.

In America today,the federal government is the world's largest collector of data, but probably does little with the majority of it. We can use today’s “Big Data” approaches to extract value from health data for systems and decisions that ultimately affect the health and well-being of millions of Americans. Yet we still need to overcome several barriers: (1) The mystification and hyping of Big Data. (2) The lack of new Big Statistics with which to investigate Big Data. (3) The tendency to rush to display just because we can, rather than in response to a critical business need or question. (4) The need for intelligent interpretation of results to senior executives who may not instinctively think analytically. So if you think you can help out with any of these challenges, you are welcome and PLEASE DO! Record your experiences, victories, setbacks, and questions here for the benefit of your fellow data warriors facing similar issues in other divisions.

Community Collaborations: 6 Areas of Focus for Hospital and Federally Qualified Health Center Partnerships

Community health centers (CHCs) are uniquely positioned to be an important partner for hospital systems as healthcare delivery systems seek out new methods to improve health outcomes. It is imperative for hospitals and health centers to understand how to form collaborations, the role they should play in these collaborations and what is needed to maximize the benefits of collaborating with federally qualified health centers (FQHCs) to create integrated delivery models of care that provide a coordinated continuum of services to targeted patient populations.

Here are some interesting (if slightly old) statistics. I think it's interesting that of the cities with the highest number of veterans, only one city is in one of the top three states with the highest veteran populations. Thanks, Jessica and all that have provided input.  There are some great suggestions out there!  I just wanted to add another perspective.  As much as possible, I think it's best to set people up for success.  For example, when leading a team or even just taking notes at a meeting, I try to end each meeting or session with an action item list with a deadline and a name next to each item.  When the expectation is public, people are more inclined to follow through.  Especially when they need to report out on their progress at the next meeting.  If they've missed a deadline, I agree with the other responses, a friendly reminder along with a "status update" request (and attaching a copy of the original action item list) is usually helpful.  People have all kinds of reasons for missing deadlines, so it's best to always give them the benefit of the doubt.  If they are non responsive after several attempts, I might cc their boss or if they are senior, go to my boss for a suggestion (she will often reach out on my behalf).

Here's a good, quick read on teams and employee satisfaction.  I think they hit on a bunch of great points.  I've found that working on teams helps me to get to know my co-workers on a deeper level and boosts my productivity and creativity (of course it has to be the "right" team :-) 
http://www.virgin.com/disruptors/how-does-a-good-team-impact-employee-happiness

THIS WEEKEND in Tech History

MAY 16, 1960: Physicist Theodore Maiman, while, working at the Hughes Research Laboratories of the Hughes Aircraft company in Malibu, California, used an artificial ruby to create the first working laser. That achievement earned him the moniker “father of the electro-optics industry.” Maiman succeeded in producing a short burst of coherent light from his humble device – not a continuous concentrated beam of light, and far less powerful than many lasers today, but nonetheless, it was a working laser.

http://ethw.org/images/2/2a/Maiman1.jpg 


MAY 17, 1943: The U.S. Army signed a contract with the University of Pennsylvania’s Moore School of Electrical Engineering to develop a computer for its Ballistics Research Library. Known as the Electronic Numerical Integrator And Computer (ENIAC), its creation marked a major step in modern computing. Calculations that once took mathematicians three months to perform could now be completed in mere seconds.

http://internetlooks.com/eniac.jpg

Detail Opportunity: Open Data Evangelist for HHS


For those among you who are open data enthusiasts and visionaries...

The HHS Demand-Driven Open Data (DDOD) project is seeking an “Open Data Evangelist” detailee to take this initiative to the next level.  

DDOD reimagines the way HHS agencies (including CMS, FDA, NIH, CDC, AHRQ, ACF and others) deliver value with open data, in the process maximizing economic and public health impact.  At its core, DDOD is a framework of tools and methods to provide a systematic, ongoing and transparent mechanism for industry and researchers to tell HHS what data they need in the form of “use cases”.  With DDOD, open data efforts are managed in terms of "use cases", enabling better allocation of limited resources and ensuring that each release has real and immediate value.  

As Evangelist, you’ll have an opportunity to closely interact with program owners across HHS’s 11 agencies in order to execute on the DDOD use cases.  Your duties will include:
  •   Plan out and manage each use case as an independent project, while looking for efficiencies to improve DDOD scalability.  
  •   Give presentations on the benefits and logistics around DDOD to wide audiences in an effort to built the brand, gain support from program owners and generate new use cases from user communities.
  •   Work with external organizations to understand their requests, set up collaborations on solution implementations, and ensure their needs are being addressed.  
  •   Work with program owners to find incentives for them to actively participate in DDOD, ensure they understand how to work through their use case, and help them arrange collaborations with data requesters.
  •   Document solutions identified in DDOD’s public knowledge base -- both short term workarounds and long term implementations.
  •   Make arrangements for systems implementation, data hosting, additional indexing on HealthData.gov, and validation testing.  

You’ll work out of the HHS IDEA Lab for a period of 6-12 months.  This is an ideal opportunity for an individual with a desire and ability to quickly learn topics in the areas of healthcare and social services.  You’ll return to your home agency with a deeper understanding of processes for leveraging data assets, as well as the experience in working across many agencies to maximize the value of these assets.

Logistics:
  •   Location of detail: HHS IDEA Lab offices (Washington, DC), with telecommute possible
  •   Duration: 6-12 months, but negotiable
  •   Reimbursement: Would need to come from offering agency
  •   Applying: Contact me by June 30 indicating your interest.  Feel free to review the project website at http://ddod.us and contact me with questions.

David  |  HHS IDEA Lab Entrepreneur-in-Residence  |  m: 312.401.0309  |  e: david.portnoy@hhs.gov  |  g: portnoy.david@gmail.com

I think you've hit exactly what I DON'T want to see happen.  Almost as bad, though, is someone who is so deeply steeped in our culture and work that they offer nothing fresh--they tout old ways, cling to entrenched biases, and essentially leave everyone with that sinking feeling of "Yupper--I work in the bowls of the federal bureaucracy!" 

Also, I think we need to take care to make sure that we don't end up with a "hand waver"--someone who can opine on what "should be" or "ideally is" but has no real, practical grounding or experience.

FYI:

It looks like the CCW has gone the the virtualization root, I am not fan of virtualization  for two reasons:

1. Virtualization is always slower than native processing, especially for users who understand the differences in loosely coupled boxes(12gbs between boxes). Although the degradation can be quite small.

2. Understanding how close the data is the the boxes can be very handy. Although single RAID 5 SANs are not  bad for read dominant processing. Not sure what really happens with a mix of intel and sun hardware. Hope to do some benchmarks.

Benchmarks before and after EG Upgrade
compared with same benchmarks on my 2008 Workstation
all results in seconds seconds

                                                        $600(odd lease)
                                                        2008 Dell T7400
                            EG Before       EG After    Workstation
                            ========       ========     ===========
 Create data (22gb)               265           351           129
 Sort data                        305           333           181
 Index data                       227           152           111
 sql query (with index)          7.35          9.71          3.78
 sql query (without index)      32.34         27.13         10.59

 SASFILE
 SQL query (no index)             N/A**         N/A**        4.30

 SPDE(free with base sas)
 SDS not available in EG
 SQL query (with index)           N/A*          N/A*         0.45(partitioned with parallel indexes)

 GRID
 Job (4 tasks)*                   231           Problems***   114
                                                with upgrade


** - only 2gb memory in EG (22gb dataset)
*  - parallel indexing and partioned data not supported in EG
     DPDE is free in workstation SAS

*** Grid is not working for me after upgrade.



Note only 10 grided jobs are allowed by my EG grid manager. A Workstation Dell dual XEON or I7 should
support seven.

Note Dell I7 Laptops support 32gb ram and 4 sata3 ports, DVD, C drive, esata on laptop and
esata on docking station.

*My workstation is an T7400(circa 2008) with 64gb ram(DDR2) and two raid 0 SSDs(sata II) arrays
of 4 disks each. You can get these off lease for about $500.

SPDE is so fast because it uses all three indexes, without SPDE SAS chooses just one index
the one with the highest cardinality. Note indexes can be slower than a table scan.
Don't use an index if pulling 15% or more from the slow EG drives.

Workstation gridding og the sums of squares for regression analysis can be extremely fast.
This is why ordinary least squares is so fast in Teradate.
Might be interesting to compare regression on workstation and Teradata.

EG is a good data farm for extrating data for the workstation to analyze.
Generally datasets <1TB can easily and inexpensively be handled on the desktop.
EG is also good as a learning tool for non-programmers.

options fullstimer;

* 22gb dataset;
* create main dataset for use with spde, sasfile, ssd and spinning disks;
data gig23ful_main;
  array num[50] n1-n50;
  do seq=1 to 50000000;
    bene_id=int(uniform(-1)*1e12);
    do idx=31 to 80;
      num[idx-30]=uniform(-1);
    end;
    idx1=int(50*uniform(-1));
    idx2=int(25*uniform(-1));
    idx3=int(12*uniform(-1));
    output;
  end;
run;quit;

proc sort data=gig23ful_main noequals;
by idx1 idx2 idx3;
run;quit;

proc datasets lib=work;
   modify gig23ful_main;
      index create idx1 idx2 idx3;
quit;

proc sql;
    create
      table modbene_idx as
    select
     count(*) as cnt
     ,sum(n1) as sum_n1
     ,sum(n2) as sum_n2
     ,sum(n3) as sum_n3
     ,sum(n4) as sum_n4
     ,sum(n5) as sum_n5
     ,sum(n6) as sum_n6
   from
     gig23ful_main
   where
     idx1<25 and idx2<12 and idx3=3
;quit;

Serious issue with proc summary and proc means with normalized output(stackodsoutput)?

    see
    https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/35992796

    proc summary and proc means are two SAS jewels and this is core functionality not window dressing

    If you have missing class levels then it is impossible to add the type variable to the normalized
    proc summary output. This renders proc summary normalized output useless?

    Normailzed proc summarry output enables a wider range of algorithms. This is because
    the fat structure often requires progamming chages to handle the extra variables.


    %let class=age sex;
    %let numcls=%sysfunc(countw(&class));
    %put &=numcls;

    options missing='.';
    ods select none;
    proc means data=sashelp.class sum  stackodsoutput printalltypes chartype missing;
       class &class;
       var height weight;
       ods output summary=stack;
       output out= type (drop=dummy _freq_ index=(class=(&class)))  n=dummy / levels;
       types ( ) sex age ;
       output out=tst sum=;
       run;
       quit;
    ods select all;


    /*

Some observations about Yammer?

1. When I upload a microsoft docx file with a fixed font, ie courier new' ,Yammer seems to change the font to a proportional font. This destroys 'txt' tables.

2. I installed chrome without admin authority and I can now see the tools wheel, paper clip... But when I use the paperclip to embed a link in my conversation it does nothing. I do not use the paper clip to upload the file, I use the second bullet item 'add a yammer file'

3. When at work sometimes I get a message that 'single logon not supported', however if I retry later it seems to work.  Seems to work much better from home. I have put in a request for Chrome or Firefox. Microsoft will be discontinuing IE next year?

4. As noted before Yammer conversations do not support a fixed font or htm.

5. I could turn docx into png or pdf but that is too draconian for me.

6. It appears that Yammer only supports a single layer in pdfs.

7. I only need a 4 or 5 fonts, ie times, symbol, tacoma(web), italic and courier.

Detail Opportunity: Open Data Evangelist for HHS


For those among you who are open data enthusiasts and visionaries...

The HHS Demand-Driven Open Data (DDOD) project is seeking an “Open Data Evangelist” detailee to take this initiative to the next level. 

DDOD reimagines the way HHS agencies (including CMS, FDA, NIH, CDC, AHRQ, ACF and others) deliver value with open data, in the process maximizing economic and public health impact. At its core, DDOD is a framework of tools and methods to provide a systematic, ongoing and transparent mechanism for industry and researchers to tell HHS what data they need in the form of “use cases”. With DDOD, open data efforts are managed in terms of "use cases", enabling better allocation of limited resources and ensuring that each release has real and immediate value. 

As Evangelist, you’ll have an opportunity to closely interact with program owners across HHS’s 11 agencies in order to execute on the DDOD use cases. Your duties will include:
• Plan out and manage each use case as an independent project, while looking for efficiencies to improve DDOD scalability. 
• Give presentations on the benefits and logistics around DDOD to wide audiences in an effort to built the brand, gain support from program owners and generate new use cases from user communities.
• Work with external organizations to understand their requests, set up collaborations on solution implementations, and ensure their needs are being addressed. 
• Work with program owners to find incentives for them to actively participate in DDOD, ensure they understand how to work through their use case, and help them arrange collaborations with data requesters.
• Document solutions identified in DDOD’s public knowledge base -- both short term workarounds and long term implementations.
• Make arrangements for systems implementation, data hosting, additional indexing on HealthData.gov, and validation testing. 

You’ll work out of the HHS IDEA Lab for a period of 6-12 months. This is an ideal opportunity for an individual with a desire and ability to quickly learn topics in the areas of healthcare and social services. You’ll return to your home agency with a deeper understanding of processes for leveraging data assets, as well as the experience in working across many agencies to maximize the value of these assets.

Logistics:
• Location of detail: HHS IDEA Lab offices (Washington, DC), with telecommute possible
• Duration: 6-12 months, but negotiable
• Reimbursement: Would need to come from offering agency
• Applying: Contact me by June 30 indicating your interest. Feel free to review the project website at http://ddod.us and contact me with questions.

David | HHS IDEA Lab Entrepreneur-in-Residence | m: 312.401.0309 | e: david.portnoy@hhs.gov | g: portnoy.david@gmail.com

Last night's 'Federal Big Data Working Group' meetup featured Brand Niemann of EPA/SemanticCommunity outlining how he made a "MOOC" (a massively open online course) out of federal Big Data.  (Essentially, in this meeting model volunteers swoop down on an agency's public use files, and give them a data-makeover.) Brand imported, categorized, and linked, several hundred USDA public data sets using Tibco Spotfire, and made them into this: http://semanticommunity.info/Data_Science/USDA_Data_Science_MOOWatch out for July 20th's meetup, when it will be healthcare.gov PUFs' turn to be swooped down on and given their makeover!

"Health Datapalooza 2015" is fast coming up. This annual conference brings together data experts, technology developers, entrepreneurs, policy makers, health care system leaders, and community advocates to present and digest developments in open health data, as well as to strut and view new apps. Keynote speakers will include Steven Brill (Founder, Court TV), Bruce Broussard (CEO of Humana), our very own Sylvia Mathews Burwell and Andy Slavitt, Esther Dyson (Founder, HICCup), Glyn Elwyn (Physician & Researcher, The Dartmouth Institute for Health Policy and Clinical Practice, Aaron Levie (CEO and Co-Founder, Box), Dr. DJ Patil (Chief Data Scientist and Dep. CTO for Data Policy, White House Office of Science and Technology Policy). Health Datapalooza runs from May 31-June 3 at the Marriott Wardman Park here in DC (so you can always slip across the road to the National Zoo to see Big Beasts if four days of Big Data gets to be too much). Registration is here:  http://healthdatapalooza.org/registration-2/ and costs $495 for we feds up to May 30. E-brochure with more details is here: http://healthdatapalooza.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Health-Datapalooza-2015-eBrochure.pdf

The New York Sun described that as the women "looked through the hole they saw the picture of a man. It was a most marvelous picture. It bowed and smiled and waved its hands and took off its hat with the most perfect naturalness and grace. Every motion was perfect..."

More on CCW EG Upgrade

Some good news and some not so good news.

The COMMON SAS folder is back and you can now store files and SAS datasets in your personal files area.

I do suggest users log completely log off EG and the virtual desktop at least twice a day.

However the PDAG folder is not back and I am only able to open one EG session.

The CCW will have been down (not really functional) for a week by 5pm tomorrow,  Because we were told it was functional Monday at 8am, I have wasted the better part two days trying to work around issues, some of which were fixed 'last night'. If 500 users are having similar problems this is a very expensive upgrade.

My $600 2008 Dell SAS 64gb workstation did not miss a beat. My workstation is roughly 5 times faster than the CCW on tables less than 1TB.  I added 2 SSD RAID 0 arrays on separate channels and SAS SPDE for data partitioning and parallel index processing. Total cost less than $1000.

SAS ghostscript Boxoft Innovation: A better way to create powerpoint slides than SAS 9.4 ods ppt?

The method I describe below supports

  1. Using you companies theme (not supported by ods ppt)
  2. Programatically inserting and deleting slides (not supported by ods ppt?)
  3. You need to create PDF version of your slides first(nice to have)


     * Documentation and self contained SAS/Boxoft/Ghostscript code
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076671

     * ODS PDF output slides to be coverted to PDF;
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076674

     Boxoft package to convert pdf to ppt
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36077420

     * Powerpoint slides without company theme
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076680

     * Powerpoint slides with company theme
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076684


Process short version (you need a pdf version of slidedeck)

  1. Create a pdf slide deck with room for company theme
  2, Insert pdf slides from other presentations(using ghostscript)
  3. Use free boxoft utility to copy pdf slides to ppt bitmaps
  4. Use VBA macro below to add your companies theme

Working from a SAS PDF slidedeck is very flexible.

Drawbacks ( I consider most of these to be strengths)

  1. Slides are bitmap images
  2. You have to create a PDF version of slides first(nice to have)
  3. You need to create a template mostly to save
     white area for your company theme, Need to do minimal calculation for space)
  4. You need the free Boxoft pdf to ppt utility
  5. Tou need ghostscript to programatically insert delete PDF slides
  6. Limited ability to make changes to slides in powerpoint
  7. Boxoft seems to use a DDE like process to pump the pdf slides to powerpoint

Here is the process. I think I have posted the pieces
already. I do have a very flexible text slide macro.

  1. Create pdf title slide and a body slise (ods pdf) - macro below.


    %Tut_Sly
       (
        stop=21
        ,L7='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct } Potential Data Issues with the February Workbook'
        ,L9='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct } All Records Including US and UK (267|498)'
        ,L11='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Input is Aggregate February Workbook'
        ,L13='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Twelve Months Jan2014-Dec2014'
        ,L20='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Roger Deangelis'
        ,L21='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} 2/23/2015'
       );

   * note courier font;
   %Tut_Sly
       (
        stop=19
         ,L3='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=199pct} Take Care Data is very Skewed. Only need top 25.'
         ,L5='^S={font_size=25pt just=l cellwidth=199pct} Total Premium Amount --  Quantiles'
         ,L7='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} Level           Quantile'
        ,L9 ='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 199% Max     $49,335,663'
        ,L19='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 99%           $2,995,668'
        ,L11='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 95%             $796,552'
        ,L12='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 99%             $379,474'
        ,L13='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 75% Q3           $99,214'
        ,L14='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 59% Median       $11,433   259,363 Mean'
        ,L15='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 25% Q1            $1,988'
        ,L16='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 19%                 $184'
        ,L17='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 5%                    $9'
        ,L18='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 1%                    $9'
        ,L19='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 9% Min                $9'
       );

  2. Use ghostscript to add a pdf slide
  3. Use boxoft to covert pdf slides to powerpoint bitmaps
  4. Use my VBA macro to add your company theme


/* T806850 Adding your company theme to SAS created PPT slides(via Boxoft)

Win 7 32 bit Powerpoint 2010

Once you have created your slides using ODS PDF and converted them to
a ppt using the free BOXOFT PDF2PPT, you probably want to
add a powerpoint theme. Make sure you used a SAS template that
provides whitespace for the banner and slide number footnote.

If you have a company custom template click on it and
select all the slides, shift first slide then last slide,
Then go to design tab and chose tour compant theme then apply.
All slides will now have your theme and SAS foreground
bitmaps. Note you can move the both the theme and/or
the SAS image around

The following VBA macro will make the SAS bitmaps transparent
and the company theme will appear on each slide.

Note SAS does not provide the ability for a them using
the template. Since SAS titles always appear at the top of a
page you can imbed an image in title1. However I wanted the
company powerpoint theme.

Thanks to the Powerpoint Expert Steve Rindsberg for
the macro below

Sub SetXparency()
Dim oSl As Slide
For Each oSl In ActivePresentation.Slides
    With oSl.Shapes(1)
        With .PictureFormat
            .TransparentBackground = msoTrue
            .TransparencyColor = RGB(255, 255, 255)
        End With
    End With
Next
End Sub


/* T6006880 Editing PDFs using ghostscript

Win 7 32bit SAS 9.3

Download and install 9.06 Ghostscipt

Scan the download

http://www.ghostscript.com/download/

I copied the executable gswin32c.exe to my c:\pdf folder

C:\Program Files\gs\gs9.06\bin\gswin32c.exe to c:\pdf\gswin32c.exe

x "cd c:\tip";
x "gswin32 -dNOPAUSE -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -sOUTPUTFILE=merge.pdf -dBATCH pdf_1.pdf  pdf_2.pdf";


64 bit
* if you cannot install ghostscript then do the following to merge pdfs;

C:\Program Files\gs\gs9.06\bin\gswin32c.exe to c:\pdf\gswin64c.exe

* create text slides
This method can be used to convert any set of pdf pages to powerpoint slides.

SAS ghostscript Boxoft Innovation: A better way to create powerpoint slides then SAS ods ppt?

The method I describe below supports

  1. Using you companies theme (not supported by ods ppt)
  2. Programatically inserting and deleting slides (not supported by ods ppt?)
  3. You need to create PDF version of your slides first(nice to have)


     * Documentation and self contained SAS/Boxoft/Ghostscript code
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076671

     * ODS PDF output slides to be coverted to PDF;
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076674

     Boxoft package to convert pdf to ppt
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36077420

     * Powerpoint slides without company theme
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076680

     * Powerpoint slides with company theme
     https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36076684


Process short version (you need a pdf version of slidedeck)

  1. Create a pdf slide deck with room for company theme
  2, Insert pdf slides from other presentations(using ghostscript)
  3. Use free boxoft utility to copy pdf slides to ppt bitmaps
  4. Use VBA macro below to add your companies theme

Working from a SAS PDF slidedeck is very flexible.

Drawbacks ( I consider most of these to be strengths)

  1. Slides are bitmap images
  2. You have to create a PDF version of slides first(nice to have)
  3. You need to create a template mostly to save
     white area for your company theme, Need to do minimal calculation for space)
  4. You need the free Boxoft pdf to ppt utility
  5. Tou need ghostscript to programatically insert delete PDF slides
  6. Limited ability to make changes to slides in powerpoint
  7. Boxoft seems to use a DDE like process to pump the pdf slides to powerpoint

Here is the process. I think I have posted the pieces
already. I do have a very flexible text slide macro.

  1. Create pdf title slide and a body slise (ods pdf) - macro below.


    %Tut_Sly
       (
        stop=21
        ,L7='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct } Potential Data Issues with the February Workbook'
        ,L9='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct } All Records Including US and UK (267|498)'
        ,L11='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Input is Aggregate February Workbook'
        ,L13='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Twelve Months Jan2014-Dec2014'
        ,L20='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} Roger Deangelis'
        ,L21='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=100pct} 2/23/2015'
       );

   * note courier font;
   %Tut_Sly
       (
        stop=19
         ,L3='^S={font_size=25pt just=c cellwidth=199pct} Take Care Data is very Skewed. Only need top 25.'
         ,L5='^S={font_size=25pt just=l cellwidth=199pct} Total Premium Amount --  Quantiles'
         ,L7='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} Level           Quantile'
        ,L9 ='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 199% Max     $49,335,663'
        ,L19='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 99%           $2,995,668'
        ,L11='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 95%             $796,552'
        ,L12='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 99%             $379,474'
        ,L13='^S={font_size=19pt just=l cellwidth=199pct font=("Courier New")} 75% Q3           $99,214'

       );

  2. Use ghostscript to add a pdf slide
  3. Use boxoft to covert pdf slides to powerpoint bitmaps
  4. Use my VBA macro to add your company theme


/* T806850 Adding your company theme to SAS created PPT slides(via Boxoft)

Win 7 32 bit Powerpoint 2010

Once you have created your slides using ODS PDF and converted them to
a ppt using the free BOXOFT PDF2PPT, you probably want to
add a powerpoint theme. Make sure you used a SAS template that
provides whitespace for the banner and slide number footnote.

If you have a company custom template click on it and
select all the slides, shift first slide then last slide,
Then go to design tab and chose tour compant theme then apply.
All slides will now have your theme and SAS foreground
bitmaps. Note you can move the both the theme and/or
the SAS image around

The following VBA macro will make the SAS bitmaps transparent
and the company theme will appear on each slide.

Note SAS does not provide the ability for a them using
the template. Since SAS titles always appear at the top of a
page you can imbed an image in title1. However I wanted the
company powerpoint theme.

Thanks to the Powerpoint Expert Steve Rindsberg for
the macro below

Sub SetXparency()
Dim oSl As Slide
For Each oSl In ActivePresentation.Slides
    With oSl.Shapes(1)
        With .PictureFormat
            .TransparentBackground = msoTrue
            .TransparencyColor = RGB(255, 255, 255)
        End With
    End With
Next
End Sub
