CareFirst Health Plan Cyber Breach

CareFirst, an affiliate of the Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurance company, announced it has recently learned it was the target of a cyber attack in June 2014, resulting in unauthorized access to a CareFirst database. Personally-identifiable information, including names, birthdays, e-mail addresses, and member-created user names and health plan identification numbers were compromised for current and former CareFirst enrollees who registered to use CareFirst's web site and online services prior to June 20, 2014.  The company has confirmed that approximately 1.1 million individuals are affected. Some federal employees and retirees are enrolled in CareFirst Blue Cross Blue Shield health plans that are offered under the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program.

CareFirst's President and CEO stated that no member-created passwords were compromised, as the targeted database did not contain password information, and further that no enrollee Social Security numbers, medical claims, employment information, credit card numbers or other financial information were accessed or in any way compromised. However, CareFirst will block access to all impacted enrollee accounts and will require affected enrollees to create new user names and passwords.

Additionally, CareFirst has announced that it will provide credit monitoring and identity theft protection services free of charge for two years to impacted individuals.  All affected individuals will receive a mailed letter from CareFirst, which will include needed information to enroll in these protection services. Members should also be aware that fraudsters have used prior announcements of health plan cyber attacks as a way to further prey on potential victims, and remember that CareFirst will not be contacting any individuals by phone or e-mail.  CareFirst has posted information about this cyber attack at http://www.carefirstanswers.com/.

I also recommend visiting the Federal Trade Commission's web site that provides guidance for what to do in these types of situations. Please visit http://www.consumer.ftc.gov/features/feature-0014-identity-theft.

This should be the grand finale - the great last impression.  Therefore, I also don't want to experience "death by PowerPoint". I don't want the audience to distracted and uninspired, hoping for the session to be over after a long day. I don't want to feel that I am hearing and experiencing what I already heard in previous sessions and  I don't want the experience to be cliché or to be able to predict the outcome. I don't want a speaker or panel members that lack innovative thinking and an engaging presence. Also, I don't want the topic/purpose/explanation of the session to be so boring or confusing so that it causes low attendance.

THIS WEEKEND in Tech History

MAY 23, 1825: British scientist William Sturgeon, who had invented the electromagnet in 1824, exhibited the electromagnet in a practical form for the first time on this date. The exhibition accompanied the reading of a paper, recorded in the Transactions of the Society of Arts for 1825 (Vol xliii, p.38). His first electromagnet was a horseshoe-shaped piece of iron that was wrapped with about 18 turns of bare copper wire (insulated wire didn't exist yet). The iron was varnished to insulate it from the windings. When a current was passed through the coil, the iron became magnetized and attracted other pieces of iron; when the current was stopped, it lost magnetization. Sturgeon displayed its power by showing that although it only weighed seven ounces (roughly 200 grams), it could lift nine pounds (roughly 4 kilos) when the current of a single-cell battery was applied.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnet#/media/File:Sturgeon_electromagnet.png


MAY 24, 1844: Samuel Morse sent the message “What hath God wrought” from the Old Supreme Court Chamber in the United States Capitol to the Mount Clair train depot in Baltimore, Maryland. It was the first public demonstration of the telegraph.


MAY 25, 1989: The first Magellan GPS NAV 1000s were shipped to retailers. They ran for a few hours on six AA batteries, and sold for $3,000.

http://rack.0.mshcdn.com/media/ZgkyMDE0LzA1LzI1LzRhL21hZ2VsbGFubmF2LmY4ZTg4LmpwZwpwCXRodW1iCTk1MHg1MzQjCmUJanBn/ba210f21/dcc/magellan-nav-1000.jpg

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1969:  Apollo 10 returned to Earth after a successful eight-day test of all the components needed for the manned moon landing.

http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/images/338794main_10-lg.jpg

group_name: US Department of Health & Human Services
body:
Detail Opportunity: Open Data Evangelist for HHS


For those among you who are open data enthusiasts and visionaries...

The HHS Demand-Driven Open Data (DDOD) project is seeking an “Open Data Evangelist” detailee to take this initiative to the next level.  

DDOD reimagines the way HHS agencies (including CMS, FDA, NIH, CDC, AHRQ, ACF and others) deliver value with open data, in the process maximizing economic and public health impact.  At its core, DDOD is a framework of tools and methods to provide a systematic, ongoing and transparent mechanism for industry and researchers to tell HHS what data they need in the form of “use cases”.  With DDOD, open data efforts are managed in terms of "use cases", enabling better allocation of limited resources and ensuring that each release has real and immediate value.  

As Evangelist, you’ll have an opportunity to closely interact with program owners across HHS’s 11 agencies in order to execute on the DDOD use cases.  Your duties will include:
  •   Plan out and manage each use case as an independent project, while looking for efficiencies to improve DDOD scalability.  
  •   Give presentations on the benefits and logistics around DDOD to wide audiences in an effort to built the brand, gain support from program owners and generate new use cases from user communities.
  •   Work with external organizations to understand their requests, set up collaborations on solution implementations, and ensure their needs are being addressed.  
  •   Work with program owners to find incentives for them to actively participate in DDOD, ensure they understand how to work through their use case, and help them arrange collaborations with data requesters.
  •   Document solutions identified in DDOD’s public knowledge base -- both short term workarounds and long term implementations.
  •   Make arrangements for systems implementation, data hosting, additional indexing on HealthData.gov, and validation testing.  

You’ll work out of the HHS IDEA Lab for a period of 6-12 months.  This is an ideal opportunity for an individual with a desire and ability to quickly learn topics in the areas of healthcare and social services.  You’ll return to your home agency with a deeper understanding of processes for leveraging data assets, as well as the experience in working across many agencies to maximize the value of these assets.

Logistics:
  •   Location of detail: HHS IDEA Lab offices (Washington, DC), with telecommute possible
  •   Duration: 6-12 months, but negotiable
  •   Reimbursement: Would need to come from offering agency
  •   Applying: Contact me by June 30 indicating your interest.  Feel free to review the project website at http://ddod.us and contact me with questions.

David  |  HHS IDEA Lab Entrepreneur-in-Residence  |  m: 312.401.0309  |  e: david.portnoy@hhs.gov  |  g: portnoy.david@gmail.com

body: Orientation Call with the Grantee:  The HRSA Federal Award Oversight Manual provides a description of topics to discuss during the initial orientation call with the grantee (p. 32-33), such as the roles of the PO and GMS, the prior approval process, the NOA (including terms and conditions) and reporting requirements. What else do you discuss with the grantee during that first call? What are some best practices and lessons learned? Have you had a pre-brief with your counterpart in program/grants, and if so, how was that helpful?

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1931: Auguste Piccard and Charles Knipfer took the first manned trip into the stratosphere when they rode in a pressurized cabin attached to a balloon to an altitude of 51,800 feet. During this flight, Piccard was able to gather substantial data on the upper atmosphere, as well as measure cosmic rays.

body: Hello Everyone, I have started our team's Yammer group. Please respond to confirm that you can see the group...and Welcome!!!
Thank you [[user:1539745737]]

How are your goals going? [[user:1540480238]] , how was your trip? [[user:1489738719]] , did you get your exercise in?

I am currently doing a summer streak...running at least a mile every day from Memorial Day to the Fourth of July. That means I have to get up really early some days. Still trying to balance this with the tiredness that occurs mid-day. I'm struggling to get to bed on time, but I know its important.

How is the work with your teams going? My team is meeting weekly, during the lunch hour, which is the only time that was consistently open for us. We also set up our own Yammer group to organize ourselves. Our project is going to be massive, but I think our team make-up with be a benefit.

I am off to Florida tomorrow, so if I don't hear from you before then,, have a great weekend!!

We've wanted to do a survey of our readership for a long time, but with the government restriction on surveys, we haven't wanted to tackle it yet.
Here is an interesting article from the U.K. Government Communication Service.  https://gcn.civilservice.gov.uk/blog/2015/05/01/7-trends-in-creating-leading-edge-communications/

It's going to be a tough road. It's like the picture you take of a street scene and then realize that someone in the picture is doing something silly or stupid and the person gets angry because you posted the picture. You have no reasonable assumption of privacy in that respect. But if you share a private picture with a friend who then shares it further, then what? I wish I had the answer.
Great question. I hope you find an anwer!

For anyone who still reads, and remembers when the IOB ("Internet of Books") was called a "library", BigDataMadeSimple has published its list of Top 20 Business Intelligence books. You may disagree with what is included but it's useful to have them in one place, even if some of them are a bit pricey (David Moraschi's "Business Intelligence with MicroStrategy Cookbook" costs a whopping $3,391.15 -- and that's just the paperback, though why you need the extra 15 cents when the book already pulls in over 3k is beyond me -- while Eric Siegel's "Predictive Analytics" weighs in at a mere $882, both on Amazon.com. ). At my GS level, I'll stick with "Business Intelligence for Dummies" at a more affordable $23.97. Check out the one healthcare book on the list, though:  Laura Madsen's "Healthcare Business Intelligence". See the full Top 20 list here:  http://bigdata-madesimple.com/what-is-bi-best-books-on-business-intelligence/

Hello HHS New Media Community! I'm sure many of you are on the listservs I emailed yesterday, but I'm on a mission to spread the word. On Monday, October 19, NIH will host a digital summit focused on science and health titled: Optimizing Digital to Reach Scientists, Clinicians, Patients, and the Public. We invite speakers from HHS and other agencies with science/health missions to submit a presentation abstract by Friday, June 19. For more information on this summit, including guidelines for abstract submissions, visit: http://www.nih.gov/news/events/digital-summit.htm. This is a free event, but registration will be required and will open soon. We're looking forward to reading all about your great work! And please feel free to share this info with your colleagues. Thanks!

Useful Windows search command

  Suppose you have a directory full of SAS/R/WPS/Python.. programs and you want to find all programs that contain the string 'prxchange'.

1. Open a command window ie start button then type 'cmd' in search window.

2, Change the directory to where your programs are. ie 
    cd  c:\mysasprograms

3. Type   
    findstr "prxchange" *.sas

As simple as that. There are many options for findstr just google windows findstr.

According to the HHS-NTEU CBA Article 20, Section 4.C., each employee may provide acceptable written justification to management that a reasonable effort was made to get to work, and management’s decision must be fair and equitable.
 
What exactly is ‘acceptable’ is unclear. But a justification that the roads immediately surrounding the employee’s residence (or the office) are flooded; or that there is no mass transit option in lieu of driving (maybe the buses/trains are shut down, or maybe the residence and/or office isn’t near mass transit); and add that the mayor declared a state of emergency or at least suggested that people stay home. Include news reports and photography (if available) as evidence of the conditions.
 
Please do this on a case-by-case basis, since only certain parts of the Houston area flooded and others did not due to drainage, elevation, proximity to Buffalo Bayou, etc. I ask you to be completely honest in your request to avoid negative repercussions.
 
If management denies granting excused absence or administrative leave to an employee, he or she has 30 days from the date when management communicates his or her decision to the employee to file a grievance.
 
Please share this info with other employees affected by this week’s flooding and keep me posted.

group_name: HRSA PO and OFAM Forum: Working Across and Within Bureaus and Offices
body: As you may know, HHS is replacing its grants manual, the AAGAM with a new manual, the GPAM.   The GPAM will incorporate the changes in federal grants due to the new Uniform Guidance.  This is scheduled to occur by the end of this calendar year.  OFAM will soon be receiving draft sections of the GPAM, and we will get that material out to all of HRSA for review and comment.  This will occur in mid-June for the first batch, and then in mid-August for the second batch of chapters.   I am just curious, how many current HRSA employees were here when HHS rolled out the AAGAM?  How did that rollout impact HRSA?  Any suggestions based on that experience?   Thanks for your input.

http://www.google.com/trends/explore#q=%2Fm%2F09g7pqs

New Gov Laptops and Windows 8

I don't have the details but I got a glowing review via email that we were will be getting 'enhanced' laptops.

My major concern is the ability of Windows 8 to bypass local processing and boot to a server.

I can't imagine EXCEL/SAS/WPS/R/Python/Perl programmers losing local processing?

Here is my ideal laptop for parallel SAS processing

1.  5th generation I7 with 32gb ram

2.  Three 500gb SSD drives 2 on RAID 0, Dell I7 with docking station supports 3 SSD drives. One external and one in the CDROM tray. All esata 6gbs. Dell BIOS supports RAID 0.

3. SAS  SPDE(Scalable Performance Data Environment) free with base.
Partitioned data and parallel processing on indexes.

4. It is very easy to grid 8 jobs on a laptop with SAS. I think I have a posting on this.

This setup is probably and order of magnitude faster than servers for tables up to 500gb. My personal workstation, 2008 dell T7400 supports tables up to 1tb.

THIS WEEKEND in Tech History

MAY 30, 1966: NASA launched Surveyor 1. It achieved the first soft landing on the moon by the United States and demonstrated the technology necessary to achieve landing and operations on the lunar surface for the manned missions to follow.

http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/image/spacecraft/surveyor_beach.jpg

MAY 31, 1941: Electric eye detectors were first used to measure high-jumping height. A track meet of the Schenectady, NY, Patrolmen’s Association used equipment designed by General Electric, comprising of a movable light source and four electric eyes.

http://todayinsci.com/Events/Technology/HighJumpDetectorEyes1941-500px.jpg

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1890: The U.S. Census Bureau began using Herman Hollerith’s tabulating machine for the first time. The 1880 Census had taken 8 years to complete; using Hollerith's Tabulator, it took the Bureau only one year to complete the 1890 Census. This gave Hollerith the basis to later found his Tabulating Machine Company, which was one of four companies that merged to form IBM.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herman_Hollerith#/media/File:HollerithMachine.CHM.jpg

Sometimes we do have a tendency to gravitate towards those who we see or think we may have something in common with however I'm thinking of how much you could learn from someone who you have nothing in common with.

Great interview.  I've been watching a lot of Super Soul Sunday lately. I so appreciate Oprah's mission of helping others to fully see their purpose in life.  She brings out some really great truths and nuggets of wisdom in this interview.  Some of my favorites (in no particular order):  

1) Luck is being prepared in the moment of opportunity.
2) There is no DOING without BEING.
3) All people seek validation first.  They want to know if you are fully here with them: did you hear me? did you see me? did you understand me? -we can't lead people without recognizing this important fact.
4) When trying to make a change in the world, you must recognize that the person must first change how they think and how they see themself.
5) Her quote from "Seed of the Soul" - "When the personality comes to serve the energy of your soul -that is authentic empowerment."
6) Our number one job is to find our purpose (Why are we here?) and align our personality, gifts and talents with that purpose.
7) Failure is there to point you in a different direction.  When you find yourself in this space, get still and ask what is the next right move?
8) You cannot help others if you do not keep yourself full.  

Thanks so much for posting, Andrea!  :-)

R Innovation: Installing R without Admin Privileges on  Win 7 64bit Desktop

1. Download R from

   https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36792999

2, Unzip to C drive. You should get folder  R-3.1.2.

3. You can now run R from the command line

   Open a DOS command window ie START->CMD
   'cd C:\R-3.1.2\bin'
   enter 'R'

   You can istall packages from here

4. I use SAS as a editor for R but you have to invoke
   SAS with the -RLANG option

   Here is my sas invocation (you don't need all this stuff)
   My init folder is c:\utl

    c:\xxxxxxx\SASFoundation\9.4\sas.exe
    -work c:\wrk
    -sasuser c:\etc
    -RLANG
    -autoexec c:\oto\autoexec.sas
    -sasinitialfolder  .
    -nosplash
    -autosaveloc c:\ver\pgm.sas
    -config c:\cfg\config.cfg
    -nodmsexp
    -sasautos c:\oto
    -awscontrol notitle
    -emailsys SMTP
    -nodmsexp
    -awscontrol notitle

  You also need this line in your SAS config

    -SET R_HOME "C:\R-3.1.2\"

  If you have an I5 with 8gb you may want these lines in your SAS config

   -BUFSIZE 64K
   -UBUFSIZE 64K
   -IBUFSIZE 32767
   -BUFNO 10
   -IBUFNO 10
   -UBUFNO 10

   -NOPRNGETLIST

   -MEMSIZE 7.2g
   -SORTSIZE 2g
   -realmemsize 8g
   -MEMMAXSZ 8g

   -SUMSIZE 7.2G

body:
Hi All,

I had posted this overview of the literature I found in the "Notes" area on Monday, but realize that it should probably go here instead.  The attachments were posted in the "Files" section.  Thanks:
-------------------------------
Good Morning All,

Just wanted to share what I've found so far to get us primed for our meeting with Des in a few weeks.  I've posted a few documents/pdfs, each providing some new information about the purpose, form, and function of structured governance plans.

1.  "Overview".pdf- This is essentially a brochure for Deloitte execs and management teams reviewing the purpose, components, and benefits of developing a governance structure. 

2.  "Chapter".pdf- Provides expanded definintions and guidance on the components of a governenance plan, including how to identify and organize the framework (presented with an IT governance example).

3.  "Template".doc- A comprehensive template for a potential governance plan, includes specific guidance for each bullet, but no sample content.

4.  "Example HHS Governance Plan".pdf- Provides a completed governance plan developed for the HHS Enterprise Architecture system.  Identies rolees, responsibility, strucure, and processes.  Very technical document.  I found it interesting to compare the actual governance plan (internal, living, detailed product) against the organization's webpage, which provides a great (brief) overview of the structure for the public and stakeholders: http://www.hhs.gov/ocio/ea/architecture/.

Hope you find some of this useful as start moving forward.

Best,
Kacey

HOLA FDA

SAS/WPS Innovation: Very Fast Big Data Summarization with ‘Do Over’ Algorithm 

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36954634                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                   
/*                                                                                                                                                                 
This is what you want                                                                                                                                              
                                                                                                                                                                   
Up to 40 obs WORK.FENMALPCT total obs=2                                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                                   
Obs    SEX     AVGHGT     AVGWGT     AVGAGE                                                                                                                        
                                                                                                                                                                   
 1      F     60.5889     90.111    13.2222                                                                                                                        
 2      M     62.3368    100.026    13.3158                                                                                                                        
*/                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                   
* DOW LOOP requires tha data be sorted;                                                                                                                            
proc sort data=sashelp.class out=class;                                                                                                                            
  by sex;                                                                                                                                                          
run;quit;                                                                                                                                                          
                                                                                                                                                                   
/*                                                                                                                                                                 
 WORK.CLASS total obs=19                                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                   
 NAME       SEX    AGE    HEIGHT    WEIGHT                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                   
 Alice       F      13     56.5       84.0                                                                                                                         
 Barbara     F      13     65.3       98.0                                                                                                                         
 Carol       F      14     62.8      102.5                                                                                                                         
 Jane        F      12     59.8       84.5                                                                                                                         
 Janet       F      15     62.5      112.5                                                                                                                         
 Joyce       F      11     51.3       50.5                                                                                                                         
 Judy        F      14     64.3       90.0                                                                                                                         
 Louise      F      12     56.3       77.0                                                                                                                         
 Mary        F      15     66.5      112.0                                                                                                                         
 Alfred      M      14     69.0      112.5                                                                                                                         
 Henry       M      14     63.5      102.5                                                                                                                         
 James       M      12     57.3       83.0                                                                                                                         
 Jeffrey     M      13     62.5       84.0                                                                                                                         
 John        M      12     59.0       99.5                                                                                                                         
 Philip      M      16     72.0      150.0                                                                                                                         
 Robert      M      12     64.8      128.0                                                                                                                         
 Ronald      M      15     67.0      133.0                                                                                                                         
 Thomas      M      11     57.5       85.0                                                                                                                         
 William     M      15     66.5      112.0                                                                                                                         
*/                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                   
data FenMalPct;                                                                                                                                                    
 retain                                                                                                                                                            
    CntSex                                                                                                                                                         
    SumHgt                                                                                                                                                         
    SumWgt                                                                                                                                                         
    SumAge                                                                                                                                                         
    0                                                                                                                                                              
 ;                                                                                                                                                                 
 * cycle through obs creating sums;                                                                                                                                
 Do until (last.sex);                                                                                                                                              
    set class;                                                                                                                                                     
    by sex;                                                                                                                                                        
    CntSex=CntSex+1;                                                                                                                                               
    SumHgt=Sum(SumHgt,Height);                                                                                                                                     
    SumWgt=Sum(SumWgt,Weight);                                                                                                                                     
    SumAge=Sum(SumAge,Age);                                                                                                                                        
 end;

How to determine if a SAS local power workstation would benefit a
SAS programmer with or without a locked down EG server?

I define big data as computing problems where most
of a users programming involves tables over 1TB. The other place for larger servers is
massive simulations or parallelism over 64 concurrent jobs. Workstations are available
with 64 cores. Even fifth generation multi-threaded  I7 processors can handle 16
parallel jobs.

Should I use just the server or a sever plus workstation(or power laptop) for my SAS programming.
Systems like Tableau, Oracle, Teradata, Midas and the IDR do not run well on a workstation.

This is how IBM used to measure overall mainframe usability.

  1. Reliability -   Do you get the answer you expect.
  2. Availability.   
  3. Serviciability
  4. Performance
  5. Functionality
  6. Security

I use either excel or SAS running on both platforms for comparisons.

  1. Reliability ( Do I get the result I expect?)
      There was a bug in SAS 9.3 where 'proc sql distinct' gave the wrong answer for very high
      carinality.
         Workstation: I downloaded the fix from SAS and installed it on my workstation in 30 minutes
         Server:      Reported it a couple of months ago and it is still not fixed

  2. Availability.
      Workstation: 99.9%
      Server:      75% (Mostly due to the fact that you need an internet connection and scheduled
      and non scheduled availability. 

  3. Serviceability:
      Workstation: I added a second esata III SSD to my laptop in 5 minutes
      Server: Generally not possible

  4. Performance
      Workstation: Much more ram,RAID 0 SSD drives and 100% of the XEONs. Very fast response time
                   not like a server dial-up connection. RAID 0 is ok because server has backup.
                   Dell laptop BIOS supports RAID 0/
      Server: Little Ram, SAN spinning raid 5 drives

  5. Functionality
      Workstation: You have an operating system, R, Python, Ghostscript, Perl, C, Java...
                   ODBC(excel access...), more disk space(Try getting 5TB ob the server)...
      Server:      Generally locked down most of the above not available.

  6.  Security
        Workstation: Only have a subset of data. Local and disk encryption.
        Server: Has the jewels so obviously a better targer for hackes.

FYI: I jsut saw a 5TB drive for $150 and very fast flash drives less than $800.

SAS/WPS Innovation: Verification and Validation of SAS Data

see

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36974958   (final analysis of sashelp.xipcode)
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36975113   (all output)
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36974966   (SAS code with zipcode invocation)

I ran the Verification and Validation macro on  SASHELP.ZIPCODES

Here are some of the interesting discoveries

1.  NO need for PONAME and CITY - They are exact duplicates? (note same number unique vals is also a tipoff)
2.  ZIP is a primary key
3.  Using optimum lengths reduces the size of the dataset by 72 bytes (fat variables should be codes)
4.  Longitude is very strongly related to numeric zipcode spearman cor of 0.96
5.  Greenwich meantime is related to zipcode, since it is a measure of longitude?
6.  Outlier analysis through univariate
7   One to One      GMTOFFSET to TIMEZONE
8   One to One      STATE to STATECODE
9   One to One      STATE to STATENAME
10  The strongest association between unordered catagorical variabkes is STATE * STATECODE
11  The weakest is Rand_A * Rand_B (random numbers)

Incidentally I am adding code to compute the cardinality relationship between two variables

Frequency of these relationships

1:1
1:N
N:1
N:N

Also adding a summarization of the cataegorical relationships

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1833: Ada Gordon, daughter of Lord Byron met Charles Babbage for the first time. Babbage was known for his designs of early calculating machines, the "Difference Engine" (1823) and "Analytical Engine" (1834). Although he never completed the machines, Babbage became a father of computing after his close friend Ada published a description of his work. She understood the plans for the device as well as Babbage but was better at articulating its promise. Although Babbage and his assistants had sketched out programs for his engines before, Lovelace’s are the most elaborate and complete, and the first to be published; so she is often referred to as “the first computer programmer.”

http://history-computer.com/ModernComputer/thinkers/images/ada-lovelace2.jpg

SAS Innovation: Editor command macros for fast programming

Here is an example of a command macro                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                        
Highlight

  2*3**4*exp(4)

Then type evl on the command line and the result will be in your log.

This only works in the old text editor because SAS script commands are
disabled in all other SAS editors, ie 'STORE' command is disabled.

Even though it takes two macros to execute evl just put both of them
in evl.sas in your autocall library.

Note you use function keys or mouse actions to execute these macros, see below.
Will show you how to map 20 of these command macros to mouse actions later.
Logitech MX310 with 64bit driver 

See

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/37056227  (package)
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/37056272  (message)
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36954328  (MX310 64bit mouse driver)


%macro evl / cmd;
   store;note;notesubmit '%evla;';
   run;
%mend evl;

%macro evla;
   %symdel __evl;
   filename clp clipbrd ;
   data _null_;
     infile clp;
     input;
     put _infile_;
     call symputx('__evl',_infile_);
   run;quit;
   data _null_;
     result=&__evl;
     put result=;
   run;quit;
%mend evla;
                                                                                                                                       
This type of 'fast' programming is only supported by the old text editor with the simple                                                
clean command line and prefix area on all windows.  
                                                                                                    
How to map macros to mouse actions to follow.

This only works in the old editor because powerfull script commands like 'STORE'
are disabled in all other SAS editors,                                                             
                                                                                                                                        
Here is what is in the package  (* most used or most critical)                                                                          
You can build on these macros they are just minimal SAS code.                                                                           
                                                                                                                                        
  avgh     proc means last dataset                                                                                                      
  cnt      cnt name*sex - last dataset number unique combinations                                                                       
  cnth     cnt name*sex - hi-lited dataset                                                                                              
  cntv     cnt hi-lited variable last dataset                                                                                           
  con      contents last dataset                                                                                                        
  conh     contents hi-lited dataset                                                                                                    
 *debugh   macro debug hi-lited                                                                                                         
 *dmp      contents with sample data                                                                                                    
 *dmph     contents with sample data hi-lited dataset                                                                                   
 *frq      freq sex*age last dataset                                                                                                    
 *frqh     freq sex*age hi-lited dataset                                                                                                
  frqv     freq hilited variable last dataset                                                                                           
  iota     column of consecutive integers                                                                                               
 *ls40     40 obs last dataset                                                                                                          
 *ls40h    40 obs hi-lited dataset                                                                                                      
  lsal     all obs last dataset                                                                                                         
  parh     does hi-lited code have matched paraentheses                                                                                 
  proch    syntax for the proc - hi-lite 'proc reg' and get syntax with example                                                         
 *prtw     prtw 'sex="M"' - last dataset subset printed                                                                                 
 *prtwh    prtw 'sex="M"' - hi-lited dataset subset printed                                                                             
  sumh     statistics on hi-lited column of numbers                                                                                     
  sumv     statistics on hi-lited variable last dataset                                                                                 
  unv      proc univariate on variable in last dataset                                                                                  
  vu       viewtable last dataset                                                                                                       
  vuh      viewtable hi-lited dataset                                                                                                   
 *xlsh     view and edit hi-lited dataset in excel (may need a sleep w slow systems)                                                    
 *xplo     xplo SUBaSUM put exploded chars in past buffer                                                                               
                                                                                                                                        
/*                                                                                                                                      
* you can use the code below to list function keys                                                                                      
                                                                                                                                        
  proc cimport infile="c:\utl\profile.cpt" cat=work.profile;                                                                            
  run;quit;                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                        
  filename key catalog "sasuser.profile.dmkeys.keys";                                                                                   
   data key;                                                                                                                            
     infile key ;                                                                                                                       
     if _n_=1 then input;                                                                                                               
     input key $8. len ib4. ;                                                                                                           
     if len > 0 then input val $varying132. len;                                                                                        
   run;                                                                                                                                 
   proc print width=min;                                                                                                                
   run;                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                        
Obs    KEY        LEN    VAL                                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                        
  1    F1          71    pgm;file &pgm..sas;file c:\ver\&pgm.&_q..sas;%let _q=%eval(0&_q +1);                                           
  2    F2          30    store;note;notesubmit '%avgha'                                                                                 
  3    F3           6    left 3                                                                                                         
  4    F4           7    right 3                                                                                                        
  5    F5          30    store;note;notesubmit '%dmpa;'                                                                                 
  6    F6          31    store;note;notesubmit '%dmpha;'                                                                                
  7    F7          67    log;file "./&pgm..log";note zx;notesubmit "%utl_logcurchk(./&pgm);"                                            
  8    F8           5    rfind

SAS Innovation: Old Text Editor Prefix area actions and SAS command macros

 USEFUL EDITIING COMMANDS IN THE SIMPLE KEYBOARD CENTRIC OLD TEXT EDITOR

 ******************************************************************

  The prefix area  Many of these commands can be put on function keys using a ':', ie :ts.
  SAS is slowly removing some of these functions from the old simple text editor.

  D        Delete current line
  I        Insert a line here
  C        Copy current line
  D99----  Delete next 99 lines (also could cut with mouse)
  I999---  Insert 999 blank lines useful when autoadd is set
  IB55---  Insert 55 lines before
  C3-----  Copy next three lines to some target
  A000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy after)
  B000102  Target for line copy or include file (copy before)
  M------  Move this line somewhere
  M3-----  Move next 3 lines somewhere
  O3-----  Move source lines over these lines
  R3-----  Replicate the next 3 lines

  DD00103  Block delete   CC00103  Block Copy    MM00103  Block Move
  0000104                 0000104                0000104
  DD-----                 CC-----                MM-----

  OO00103  Target Over    RR3----  Block Replicate
  0000104                 0000104
  OO-----                 RR-----

  (4-----  Shift left first 4 columns into bit bucket (distructive shift)
  )4-----  Shift right first 4 columns (distructive shift)
  >5-----  Nondistructive shift right
  <5-----  Nondistructive shift left
  >>5----  Non distructive shift right of a block of commands
  0000101
  0000102
  >>-----
  <<,)),(( Similar to single character versions
  UC----- Upper case line  - more useful on function key as :UC
  UC26--- Upper case next 26 lines
  LC----- Lower case line
  LC26    Lower case next 26 lines
  LLC---- Block of lines -lower caSE
  UUC
  TF----- Text flow lines until blank line
  TS----- Text split at cursor better on function key as :tf
  MASK - BUILD TEMPLATE FOR ENTERING DATA


   no need to look up a P-Value
   put this on any command line
   %put %sysfunc(probnorm(1.96)); /* try this on command line */

   ?          - previous command history
   subtop     - submit top line of editor
   icon
   rchange    - change on function key hit
   rfind      - find on function key hit
   save  prg       /# save program in your profile  ie pgm.source #/
   copy  prg       /# recalls program from your profile #/
   change     - c today yesterday ic all   ( ignore case all)
   cols
   reset
   keys
   top
   bot
   n           - go to line n
   left  n
   right  n
   spell all - check spelling of all words in editor
   autoadd   - add aline at a time to editor ( usewith mask and bounds )
   vscroll 25 - set scroll amounts for forward and backward
   hscroll 10
   backward max n
   forward max  n
   bounds
   mask
   copy
   paste
   find - f 'data' first last next prev prefix suffix word
   find 'Mac' prefix
   change - c todat yesterday ic all
   rchange - change on function key hit
   rfind   - find on function key hit
   mark - highlight string, lines for submit or edit
   mark block - highlight rectangle within editor
                does not have to be full lines
   store
   zoom z
   up 2
   down 4
   CAPS on/off
   home
   cursor
   nums on/off
   %let
   vt
   pmenu off /# functon key #/
   pmenu on
   end
   print
   submit
   unmark unmark all
   tabs
   redo
   nums on/off
   fse
   fsv
   fsb
   libn
   filen
   fslist
   vt
   print
   dir

   Example 1 -- Just a dumb script
   --------------------------------

   1;F ' ';MARK;HOME;2;HOME;MARK;HOME;STORE;HOME;UNMARK;

   If the first line in active editor contains

   000001 %Macro MyLongMacroName

   This script will put MyLongMacroName into the paste buffer.
   You can then paste MyLongMacroName anywhere you want.
   (This only works on windows). Try it, just copy
   the one line script to the command line.

SAS Innovation: Suggested Profile, Autoexec, Config, mouse mappings and keyboard tips.

see
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/37056989

Note save your sasuser.profile and export mine to tour sasuser profile if you want to see my setup.

If you can't export my profile you might want to change you settings using


   1. Turn off enhanced editor by view->program editor. I also like to mnimize the enhanced editor so that if it pops up it will look like a postage stamp.

   2. -awscontrol notitle​ on SAS invocation (wtattention on function key - removes blue banner)

   3. tools>options>preferences 
         general tab -- 30 entries (able to undo last 30 changes)
         view tab -- turn off horizontal/scroll vertical scroll/screen tips (f3-f4 lrft right)
         turn on command line
         edit tab -- autosave every minute
         results tab -- turn on create listing (all else off - less is more)
         advanced tab -- turn on hide cursor and disable scroll bar focus

   4. tools>cutomize
          toolbar -- turn all four boxes off
When editor comes up you should see a clean single command line on all windows.

The command bar and line below command line should be gone
on the command line type nums on (turn on prefix area)

THIS WEEKEND in Tech History

June 6, 1933: The world’s first drive-in movie theater opened in Camden, New Jersey. Richard Hollingshead, Jr. had developed the system by experimenting with a 1928 Kodak projector mounted on the hood of his car and aimed at a screen pinned to some trees. The first film shown at the Park-In Theatre was the Adolphe Menjou film "Wife Beware."

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/18/First_drive-in_theater_Camden_NJ_1933.jpg

-----------------------------------------------------------------

June 7, 1980: The first US solar power plant was dedicated at the Natural Bridge National Monument, Utah.

http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2a/Natural_Bridges_Solar_Power_System.jpg

REGISTER for Webinar: Harnessing Precision Medicine to Reduce Smoking, June 15
Please join us, June 15 at 2 pm for our ongoing webinar series: 

OBSSR Webinar Series: 
Advances in GxE Research in the Behavioral and Social Sciences

TITLE: Harnessing Precision Medicine to Reduce Smoking
PRESENTER: Laura Jean Bierut, M.D., Washington University School of Medicine 
DATE/TIME: Monday, June 15, 2015 - 2:00 pm to 3:00 pm EDT
SPONSOR: NIH Office of Behavioral Health and Social Sciences (OBSSR)

REGISTER FOR DIAL IN INSTRUCTIONS
http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07eb3u174m98ee1461&llr=vykrlptab 

Overview
Smoking is the largest cause of preventable mortality in the U.S. and the world, and over 40 million Americans are current cigarette smokers. Despite strong adverse consequences of smoking, cessation remains a difficult goal, and over half of current smokers report making a quit attempt in the previous year.  Clear evidence now shows that heaviness of smoking is driven by genetic variation in cholinergic nicotinic receptor subunit genes and nicotine metabolizing genes.  These same variants predict failed smoking cessation and are the strongest genetic risk factors for lung cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Importantly, there is evidence of a complex interplay between environments, pharmacologic treatment, and genes in the prediction successful smoking cessation. This body of work illustrates an example in achieving our goal of precision medicine: using genetic information to differentiate people who are likely to respond to pharmacologic treatment for smoking cessation from those who will likely receive little benefit.

Presenter’s Bio and more information: http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07eb3u174m98ee1461&llr=vykrlptab

Ok, thanks Tori! And it turns out, while I would have liked to have the group congregating on Yammer, it seems like discussing via email has won over our internal social network. Go figure ;) I will check with Sandy though should this shift.

We're looking at moving towards a 'microservices' software architecture, using the "Netflix model", http://www.slideshare.net/adrianco/netflix-global-cloud. Which meant we really needed feature parity with AWS, such as Autoscaling Groups, networking services (DNS, Load-Balancers). Those elements did not exist or did not work well enough for us to confidently use. 

As for Swift, it was configured, but never tested heavily. So I can't comment on if it was production worthy. Object-store is a paradigm we haven't embraced, not even S3 on AWS.

NTEU received an additional briefing this afternoon on the federal employee data breach with officials from both the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and the Office of Personnel Management (OPM).

As shared with you earlier, OPM announced last week that a database breach has compromised Personal Identifiable Information for approximately four million current and former federal employees. 

OPM’s Chief Information Officer has now confirmed that the compromised employee personnel records contained names, Social Security numbers, place and date of birth, and addresses.

On a rolling basis starting today through Friday, June 19, OPM is notifying affected individuals by email or mailed letter through the U.S. Postal Service, and will provide credit monitoring and identity theft protection services from CSID, a company that specializes in identity theft and fraud protection.

According to OPM, individual notification emails will be sent from opmcio@csid.com. The e-mail and letters will contain needed instructions and PIN codes in order to access the CSID identity protection services provided by OPM. 

Once an affected individual has received the needed instructions and PIN, they can visit the CSID website at http://www.csid.com/opm/ in order to enroll in the protection services.  

Please note, individuals can also directly call CSID toll-free at 844-222-2743 (international callers 512-327-0700 collect) to verify whether they are affected and to enroll in these services. 

NTEU shared our members’ valid concerns over the need to properly safeguard employee data, and they are working to better understand what exact types of data have been compromised, as well as additional details on the notification process itself.

I will keep you updated.

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 2002: The first direct electronic communication experiment between the nervous systems of two humans is carried out by Professor Kevin Warwick in the United Kingdom. under the heading "Project Cyborg," Warwick had an array of 100 electrodes fired into his nervous system in order to link it to the internet. Then he successfully carried out a series of experiments including extending his nervous system over the internet to control a robotic hand, a loudspeaker, amplifier and to communicate with his wife.

http://www.kevinwarwick.com/index.2.jpg

Mouse Innovation: How to program 20 actions on the  Logitech MX310 mouse under Win 7 64bit and SAS 64bit

These techniques should work with other languages

see
https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/36954328
Driver for mouse

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/37056989
Function keys, autoexec, sas invocation...

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/37056227
Additional documentation (also in zip file)

https://www.yammer.com/hhs.gov/uploaded_files/37310917
Using the prefix area

ps You an have multiple old text editors using the cntl-h function key or
typing note g.g on the command line. Putting 'notesubmit' on a function key allows
execution of program in a note editor.

There are later logitech drivers that work with the MX310 even though Logitech says
no software is available. Just Google around.

You do need admin rights to install this mouse, but I
was easily able to get permission from my Gov IT group

I have twenty actions assigned tot he mouse. the picture
of the mouse during install may be greyed out but this is just because it failed to display.
It has no effect on functionality. Not sure why some are having fifficulty.

There is a map of the mouse actions within the ut_perpac_setup/utl_PerPacLft.jpg.

If you use my function keys, command macros and my autoexec(only needed for versioning) you will need to
assign the following keystrokes to the mouse.

You will see 6 possible assigments in the select button option

1  Left mouse button just use SAS function settings as shown in utl_perpackey.txt.
2  Right mouse button just use SAS function settings as shown in utl_perpackey.txt.

Keystroke assigments
3 assign F1    - Scroll wheel Middle mouse button
4 assign F11   - Left side mouse button
5 assign F12   - Right side mouse button
6 assign F2    - Seond middle mouse button

You get twenty actions out of these settings because SAS function keys allow combination
keystrokes, ie shift-f1 lists forty obs from last table created.

Note you do not have to enter all those function keys and you can save your keys or backup
your whole profile before switching to my keys. You can have several sets of keys and swap them
without leaving SAS. Keys can be assigned to different SAS windows.

To try my keys, copy profile.sasbcat to some directory. Then type keys and on the keys
command line type copy myfolder.profile.dmkeys.keys.


Also you may want to try my invocation and profile.sas7bcat. The CPT file can be used for 23bit, however it does completly set up the environment

Settings I like

You can save these settings and I guarantee you can just plot your profile.sas7bdat into the
next version of SAS and all your function keys and command macros will work.

I gave up with EG, I lose my settings several times a year and have neven been able to migrate them.

1. Turn off enhanced editor go to view->program editor. I also like to minimize the enhanced editor
so that if it pops up it will look like a postage stamp.

2. -awscontrol notitle? on SAS invocation ( removes blue banner -need wtattention on function key -
cntl_alt_delete for more stuborn freezes. This will attempt to bring up the SAS termination menue.
SAS has not made all processes interruptible)

3. tools>options>preferences

general tab -- 30 entries (able to undo last 30 changes)

view tab -- turn off horizontal/scroll vertical scroll/screen tips (f3-f4 lrft right)
There is a bug when removing the verrticle scrool bar in the old text editor. It disables
mouse scroll wheel and limits what you can highlight.  F1 and F2 to scroll left and right)

turn on command line
make sure command bar is off.

edit tab -- autosave every minute

results tab -- turn on create listing (all else off - less is more) and other automatic
output. You decide when you want to see something with functions keys,

advanced tab -- turn on hide cursor and disable scroll bar focus

4. tools>cutomize
toolbar -- turn all four boxes off
When editor comes up you should see a clean single command line on all windows.

The command bar and line below command line should be gone
on the command line type nums on (turn on prefix area) « collapse

Today is the HHS Digital Media Round Table Call - where we discuss timely topics, questions, share news and learn from each other’s experience –

Once a month a group of people jump on an old media technology (the telephone) to talk about new media issues (not the telephone). If you have a question or topic that you’d like to throw out to the group, you can send it ahead of time, or just plan on bringing it up yourself. Or just jump in other people’s topics. Or just silently, lurkingly, listen in…

Join us!

2nd Wednesday of the Month
2:00 PM

Dial +1 (312) 878-3070

Access Code: 435-425-958

Thanks to Nicholas Garlow for facilitating today!

What happened?

Within the last year, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) has undertaken an aggressive effort to update its cybersecurity posture, adding numerous tools and capabilities to its various networks. As a result, in April 2015, OPM became aware of a cybersecurity intrusion affecting its information technology (IT) systems and data. 

Since the incident was identified, OPM has partnered with the U.S. Department of Homeland Security U.S. Cyber Incident Response Team (US-CERT), and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to determine the impact current and former to Federal personnel.  OPM immediately implemented additional security measures and will continue to improve the security for the sensitive information it manages. The FBI has opened an investigation in order to identify and hold accountable the person(s) responsible for this incident.

OPM will send notifications to approximately 4 million individuals whose PII may have been compromised.  Since the investigation is on-going, additional PII exposures may come to light; in that case, OPM will conduct additional notifications as necessary. In order to mitigate the risk of fraud and identity theft, OPM will offer credit report access, credit monitoring and identify theft insurance and recovery services at no cost to them, through CSID®, a company that specializes in identity theft protection and fraud resolution.

Were these employees OPM employees or employees from across the executive branch? Was the legislative or judicial branch impacted by this intrusion?

OPM services the Federal workforce so the affected population includes Executive Branch agencies and employees.

Were members of the military affected by the breach?

This incident did not affect military records. No contractors were affected unless they previously held Federal civilian positions. The incident affected current and former Federal civilian personnel, including Department of Defense civilian employees.

Have the police been notified? If so, with which police department and what is the case number?

Since the incident was identified, OPM has partnered with the U.S. Department of Homeland Security’s Computer Emergency Readiness Team (US-CERT), and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to determine the full impact to Federal personnel and investigate the intrusion. Federal law enforcement continues to investigate the matter and assist with remediation efforts. OPM immediately implemented additional security measures and will continue to improve security for the sensitive information it manages.

When did this happen?

The intrusion occurred in December 2014. OPM became aware of the intrusion into its systems in April 2015 after implementing tough new measures to deter and detect cyberattacks.  During its investigation with its agency partners, the FBI and US-CERT, OPM became aware of potentially compromised data in May 2015.

What systems were affected?

For security reasons, OPM cannot publicly discuss specifics of the systems that might be affected by the compromise of personnel data.  Additionally, due to the ongoing investigation, it would be inappropriate to publicly provide information that may impact current work by law enforcement. OPM has added additional security controls to better protect overall networks and systems and the data they store and process.

What personal information was compromised?

OPM maintains personnel records for the Federal workforce.  The kind of data that may have been compromised in this incident could include name, Social Security Number, date and place of birth, and current and former addresses. It is the type of information you would typically find in a personnel file, such as job assignments, training records, and benefit selection decisions, but not the names of family members or beneficiaries and not information contained in actual policies. The notifications to potentially affected individuals will state exactly what information may have been compromised.

How many people are involved?

Approximately 4 million current and former Federal employees are involved.

Why didn't OPM tell affected individuals about the loss of the data sooner?

OPM became aware of the intrusion in April 2015. OPM worked with US-CERT as quickly as possible to assess the extent of the malicious activity and to identify the records that may have been compromised.  During the investigation, OPM became aware of potentially compromised data in May 2015. As with any such event, it takes time to conduct a thorough investigation and to identify the affected individuals.

It is important to note that this is an ongoing investigation that could reveal additional exposure; if that occurs, OPM will conduct additional notifications as necessary. Protecting the integrity of the information entrusted to OPM is the agency’s highest priority.

What is OPM doing to prevent this kind of loss from happening again?

Because cyber threats are evolving and pervasive, OPM is continuously working to identify and mitigate threats when they occur. OPM evaluates its IT security protocols on a continuous basis to make sure that sensitive data is protected to the greatest extent possible, across all networks where OPM data resides—including those managed by government partners and contractors.

Has the information been misused?

At this time, we have no evidence that there has been any use or attempted use of the information compromised in this incident. This is an ongoing investigation and OPM will continue to be vigilant to ensure that necessary security measures are in place to further strengthen and protect our networks, systems, and data.

I did not receive a letter stating that my information was compromised, but feel that I should have. Can you help me?

OPM is aware of the affected data and the networks and the data on which it resides. OPM will begin sending notifications to individuals whose PII may have been compromised on June 8, 2015. These notifications will take place on a rolling basis through June 19, 2015. The email will come from opmcio@csid.com and it will contain information regarding credit monitoring and identity theft protection services being provided to those Federal employees impacted by the data breach. In the event OPM does not have an email address for the individual on file, a standard letter will be sent via the U.S. Postal Service.

What are the risks of identity theft with the information that was compromised?

Receiving a letter does not mean that the recipient is a victim of identity theft.  OPM is recommending that people review their letters and the recommendations provided.  In order to mitigate the risk of fraud and identity theft, we are offering credit monitoring service and identity theft insurance through CSID, a company that specializes in identity theft protection and fraud resolution. All potentially affected individuals will receive a complimentary subscription to CSID Protector Plus for 18 months.  Every affected individual, regardless of whether or not they explicitly take action to enroll, will have $1 million of identity theft insurance and access to full-service identity restoration provided by CSID.

How long will it take to inform all the potential victims involved in the incident?

OPM will begin conducting notifications to affected individuals using email and/or USPS First Class mail on June 8, 2015 and will continue notifications on a rolling basis through June 19, 2015.

Who is responsible for this incident?

OPM does not assign attribution for cybercrimes. That question is best addressed by law enforcement agencies.

What has been the operational or mission impact to OPM?

There has been no operational impact to OPM. OPM has continued to operate at full capacity since the incident occurred.

Can my family members also receive services if they are part of my file/records?

Family members of employees were not affected by this breach.

Reference: https://www.opm.gov/news/latest-news/announcements/frequently-asked-questions/

Message from NTEU
June 11, 2015

Updated Information on OPM Data Breach

NTEU has received regular briefings from the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), with new information being provided almost daily. NTEU understands and shares the high frustration you are feeling at this time. 

The union received an updated toll-free number and new information concerning the credit monitoring and identity-theft protection services being provided. 

Here is the latest information:

• Notifications are being sent to affected individuals, a process that began Monday, June 8 and will continue through Friday, June 19. CSID is a private contractor that OPM is using to assist with responding to the data breach. Notifications will include a PIN that is required when signing up for credit monitoring and identity-theft protection services. 

• Current employees are most likely to receive an email from CSID at their work email address. Notification emails sent by CSID will come from opmcio@csid.com. Employees without a valid email address and annuitants will be contacted by mail. 

• OPM alerted NTEU that the telephone numbers provided in earlier communications are incorrect. The correct CSID toll-free number is 844-777-2743. International callers can call collect to 512-327-0705. 

• OPM advises that it is best for individuals to wait to receive a notice before calling CSID or visiting the CSID web site at: http://www.csid.com/opm/. 

• At no time will affected individuals receive incoming calls or emails from CSID requesting or demanding personal information. While they will receive a notification via email or postal mail, affected individuals must still take action to sign up for credit monitoring—either by visiting the web site or calling the toll-free line—before any request for personal information occurs. 

• When affected individuals call the toll-free line, CSID representatives initially will not ask for date of birth or full Social Security number (SSN). CSID representatives on the toll-free line only have the following information: the names of affected individuals, the PIN that is included in their individual notices, and the last four digits of employees’ Social Security numbers. Representatives will only initially ask for the PIN or the last 4 digits of the SSN to help validate individual identities against the lists that they have. 

• At NTEU’s request, OPM has contacted agencies asking them to allow employees to reach out to CSID while at work and on duty time and to provide Internet access to employees who do not have regular access at work.

OPM Updated FAQ: http://www.opm.gov/faqs/topic/cybersecurityinformation/

The union will continue to urge OPM to share all available information as the situation develops and will keep members informed. 

“...to ensure that every federal employee is treated with dignity and respect.”

ON THIS DAY in Tech History – 1936: Radio station KDKA in Pittsburgh became the first station in the United States to broadcast experimentally with half a million watts of power. The station, then using the call letters W8XAR, tested the 500,000-watt rig between the hours of 1 a.m. and 6 a.m. Eventually, the FCC limited the maximum power for AM radio stations to 50,000 watts.

REGISTER Now: Resilience in LGBT community: Research evidence & conceptual issues, June 17
OBSSR Webinar Series: 
The Cultural Framework for Health – New Approaches 

TITLE: Conceptual issues and research evidence of resilience in LGBT community

REGISTER FOR DIAL-IN INSTRUCTIONS: 
http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07eb3uaah940656794&llr=vykrlptab

Presenters and Topics

Individual vs. Community Resilience in Minority Stress of Lesbians, Gay Men, and Bisexuals, by Ilan H. Meyer, Ph.D., UCLA School of Law and California Center for Population Research

Implications of Childhood Experiences for the Health and Adaptation of Lesbian, Gay, and Bisexual Individuals: Sensitivity to Developmental Process in Future Research, by Margaret Rosario, Ph.D., The City University of New York

In these spaces: Perceived neighborhood quality as a protective factor against discrimination for Lesbian, Gay, and Bisexual (LGB) adults, by Alisia (Giac-Thao) Tran, Ph.D., Arizona State University

A Novel Method and Program for Addressing Health Disparities among LGBTQ High School Students, by Nicholas Heck, Ph.D., Marquette University in Milwaukee

DATE: Wednesday, June 17, 2015 – 2:00 pm to 3:00 pm EDT

REGISTER FOR DIAL-IN INSTRUCTIONS: 
http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07eb3uaah940656794&llr=vykrlptab

Overview
Minority stress theory describes stress processes that stem from stigma and prejudice experienced by lesbians, gay men, bisexuals, and transgender individuals (LGBT) and that place LGBT people at risk for adverse mental and physical health outcomes.  Hundreds of research articles since the 1990s have shown that minority stress processes lead to mental and physical health problems.  Most of this research has focused on LGB people but more recently research on transgender populations has articulated minority stress processes and has demonstrated its impact on the health of transgender people. Minority stress, like general stress theory, also suggests that against minority stress, LGBT people mount coping responses.  According to theory, the impact of stress on health is determined by the countervailing effects of pathogenic stress processes and ameliorative resilience processes. In general, resilience research has shown that in various populations, starting early in childhood, individuals mount significant, sometimes heroic, coping efforts in the face of stress and adversity.  But research on ameliorating (or salutogenic—health inducing) processes in LGBT populations has lagged.  This Fall, a special issue of Psychology of Sexual Orientation and Gender Diversity, guest edited by Dr. Ilan H. Meyer, comes to feel a gap in the literature on resilience in LGBT people.  In this Webinar we will highlight 3 areas of research on resilience that have not yet received much attention.  The areas covered include individual/psychological level resilience, social/community level resilience, and resilience intervention in sexual and gender minority youth.

View presenters’ bios and individual abstracts.
http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07eb3uaah940656794&llr=vykrlptab

Detail Opportunity: Open Data Evangelist for HHS


For those among you who are open data enthusiasts and visionaries...

The HHS Demand-Driven Open Data (DDOD) project is seeking an “Open Data Evangelist” detailee to take this initiative to the next level.  

DDOD reimagines the way HHS agencies (including CMS, FDA, NIH, CDC, AHRQ, ACF and others) deliver value with open data, in the process maximizing economic and public health impact.  At its core, DDOD is a framework of tools and methods to provide a systematic, ongoing and transparent mechanism for industry and researchers to tell HHS what data they need in the form of “use cases”.  With DDOD, open data efforts are managed in terms of "use cases", enabling better allocation of limited resources and ensuring that each release has real and immediate value.  

As Evangelist, you’ll have an opportunity to closely interact with program owners across HHS’s 11 agencies in order to execute on the DDOD use cases.  Your duties will include:
  •   Plan out and manage each use case as an independent project, while looking for efficiencies to improve DDOD scalability.  
  •   Give presentations on the benefits and logistics around DDOD to wide audiences in an effort to built the brand, gain support from program owners and generate new use cases from user communities.
  •   Work with external organizations to understand their requests, set up collaborations on solution implementations, and ensure their needs are being addressed.  
  •   Work with program owners to find incentives for them to actively participate in DDOD, ensure they understand how to work through their use case, and help them arrange collaborations with data requesters.
  •   Document solutions identified in DDOD’s public knowledge base -- both short term workarounds and long term implementations.
  •   Make arrangements for systems implementation, data hosting, additional indexing on HealthData.gov, and validation testing.  

You’ll work out of the HHS IDEA Lab for a period of 6-12 months.  This is an ideal opportunity for an individual with a desire and ability to quickly learn topics in the areas of healthcare and social services.  You’ll return to your home agency with a deeper understanding of processes for leveraging data assets, as well as the experience in working across many agencies to maximize the value of these assets.

Logistics:
  •   Location of detail: HHS IDEA Lab offices (Washington, DC), with telecommute possible
  •   Duration: 6-12 months, but negotiable
  •   Reimbursement: Would need to come from offering agency
  •   Applying: Contact me by June 30 indicating your interest.  Feel free to review the project website at http://ddod.us and contact me with questions.

David  |  HHS IDEA Lab Entrepreneur-in-Residence  |  m: 312.401.0309  |  e: david.portnoy@hhs.gov  |  g: portnoy.david@gmail.com

Hi, a quick question - I'm still a current Fed but a retiree friend just tipped me off she's getting fake emails from the company that's supposed to be helping us if hacked. (Email show show opm, NOT csid apparently).

Meanwhile, she's not getting the longer emails explain some of the related developments (from OPM) and I haven't seen anything official about her fake email, though I've alerted a few.

Thoughts welcome!
